HEADLINE: Into Africa 

BYLINE:  By ADAM BOWLES 

 BODY:
FOR several years Nitzy Cohen-Fitzgerald, owner of International Basics, a company in Westport, tried doing business in Africa.
But poor communications -- it was hard to reach the proper contacts by phone and few businessmen had fax machines -- and little government help at either end kept her from doing so.
 But in 1999, a forum presented by the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development allowed her to finally connect with a Ghanaian man who eventually purchased a cocoa-processing machine from her. Today, she retains the marketing rights to the cocoa powder and butter that will be produced at the plant. Her business exports agricultural commodities and turnkey food processing plants. 
 "I'm a small company so it would be inefficient for me to do business in Western countries; Cargill and ConAgra would eat me alive," Ms. Cohen-Fitzgerald said of the international companies that sell food products. "I can only go to places where it is harder to do business, but where the personal touch would make the deal go. I tried Africa so many times knowing that this was the last frontier." 
Ms. Cohen-Fitzgerald's business, which has worked in Eastern Europe for its first six years of operation, is not the only Connecticut company finding trade success in Africa. A modest, but steadily growing number of small- to mid-sized private companies are working with Africa, a direct result of the state's Africa Trade Initiative. 
In 1999, the Department of Economic and Community Development began the initiative, a market development plan for sub-Saharan Africa that complements existing trade programs in Argentina, Brazil, China, Israel, Germany, Mexico and Turkey. Since then, 40 Connecticut companies, or about 10 new companies each year, have begun trade with Africa. 
Of Africa's $80 billion in annual imports, United States companies account for only $6 billion of the market, having traditionally ceded most of it to Europe and Asia. Connecticut, the 25th largest exporting state to all countries, accounts for about $60 million, or less than 1 percent, of the United States' share of that market. Over all, Connecticut's exports to 120 countries total about $8.4 billion, according to the D.E.C.D.
Still, the awareness of trade opportunities between Connecticut and Africa is growing.
In late February, the state played host to what has become an increasingly popular forum on economic development in Africa. More than 300 people, including the ambassadors of Tanzania and Kenya, diplomats from Nigeria and Ghana, a delegation from South Africa, and dozens of representatives from Connecticut businesses, attended the event.
James Nicholas, D.E.C.D. director of Africa and trade marketing, said although the majority of sub-Saharan Africa remains underdeveloped and lacks infrastructure, regulations and a reliable banking system, the state is convinced that Africa is ripe for business thanks to new federal and state laws.
The federal African Growth and Opportunity Act of 2000 provides favorable export benefits to African nations that reform their economies to become more open. So far, 35 sub-Saharan nations have been deemed eligible for A.G.O.A. 
Mustafa Nyang'anyi, Ambassador of Tanzania, said Connecticut was at the top of a list of states, such as Texas, Georgia and Pennsylvania, that have a proven, successful trade partnership with countries in Africa. Mr. Nyang'anyi added that while A.G.O.A. provided the legal framework that allowed greater trade success between the United States and Africa, negative perceptions of the continent remain a significant obstacle. 
"They shouldn't be led to a perception from the bad news that emanates from Africa that the whole continent is in a chaotic situation," he said. "Far from it." He said only seven of the 52 nations in Africa are hot spots.
Many other nations are stable. Tanzania, for example, has not experienced any political upheaval since it gained independence in 1961, he said. Since that time, several Connecticut investors entered the gold mining industry there. 
And, he added, American businesses are getting returns of 28 to 30 percent on their investments, compared with returns of 12 to 15 percent in most other places of the world. 
"The cost of living index in Africa is far lower than many parts of the world," Mr. Nyang'anyi said. "Labor costs are very low. Therefore, they have the maximum return on their investments even though they are paying better salaries than the average worker in a public firm in Africa."
Mr. Nyang'anyi said most African countries participate in the World Bank's Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, which prohibits governments from nationalizing or misappropriating private property. 
In 1997, Gov. John G. Rowland signed into law An Act Concerning Connecticut Trade With Africa, which mandated that D.E.C.D. and the Connecticut Development Authority provide financial and technical assistance to small- and medium-sized companies that want to do business in Africa.
"We're hoping to increase the number of small business companies that actively participate in Africa," Mr. Nicholas said. "There has been so much misinformation about Africa. They viewed it as a pariah continent, rather than one that provides opportunity."
Connecticut's trade initiative targets the 48 countries in sub-Saharan Africa. Many of these countries have created sub-regional free-trade areas and customs unions. Mr. Nicholas said Connecticut businesses should view this region as a trading block with significant market opportunities. There are approximately 700 million people in Africa's middle class.
The Economic Community of West African States has 17 countries, a population of more than 208 million people and a Gross Domestic Product of more than $76 billion. The Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa has 20 countries, approximately 300 million people and a G.D.P. of $55.6 billion. And the Southern African Development Community has 133 million people and a G.D.P. of more than $170 billion.
About 75 percent of Connecticut's exports to Africa go to South Africa. The state also trades with Ghana, Tanzania, Uganda and Nigeria. Among those exports are airplane parts and airplane maintenance diagnostic equipment, chemicals, paper packaging, electronics and computers.
United Technologies in Hartford exports elevators and air conditioning equipment to South Africa; Tyres 2000 Limited in Hebron has sold tires in West Africa; Xerox in Stamford exports office automation equipment and HSBC Equator (USA) Inc., in Glastonbury exports financial services. Also, First International Bank in Hartford is a leading United States export-import bank lender in Africa.
Smaller Connecticut companies are also getting into the act, though their sales only slightly affects the total value of exports to Africa. 
AQSolutions in New Haven is one example. After the D.E.C.D. officials introduced Awo Quason-Sackey to sources for financing, she left her job as an executive at United Technologies one year ago to start the information technology business, which provides software development offshore.
"I always wanted to do something that would connect the U.S. and my home country," said Ms. Quason-Sackey, a Ghanaian native. She built a software development center in Accra, Ghana, where 25 of her 30 employees work on code for software programs used by Connecticut companies. 
One of her biggest barriers to business is the unfamiliarity Connecticut businesses have toward Africa. "The first question people ask when they come here is, 'Where is Ghana?' and we have to bring out a map," she said. "After we get past all that stuff, they ask if there is an education system that supports this. It is amazing about how much people don't know about Africa. All we hear about is coup d'etat, AIDS, famine and war. Africa becomes a continent to help as opposed as a continent to contribute."
Ms. Quason-Sackey received her law degree from the University of Ghana in 1975 and her master's degrees in business and law from Temple University in 1978. 
Ms. Quason-Sackey added that though she pays the Ghanaian workers relatively high wages by their standards, labor costs are low enough that she is able to offer products at a much cheaper price than her competitors.
"There's so much opportunity there for people willing to explore," she said. 
New cultural ties are also expected to strengthen business relationships between Africa and Connecticut. In 1999, the African National Congress, which led the struggle against apartheid in South Africa and is the ruling party there, selected the University of Connecticut as its partner in documenting and archiving its history.
Mr. Nicholas said the A.N.C.-UConn partnership should lead to better business contacts on both sides.

HEADLINE: LIPA Is Adding Juice But Is Still Thirsty 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
Although electrical capacity is likely to expand by about 15 percent this summer, Long Island may still face shortages, Richard M. Kessel, chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, said last week.
 Mr. Kessel, speaking to the Hauppauge Industrial Association, said the authority would immediately need the planned 730 new megawatts -- 400 megawatts from 10 small on-Island generators and 330 megawatts from a new cross-Sound cable -- to get through the summer. 
 He also said that the Island could not risk depending on private companies to build additional plants needed in the next several years. The authority must aggressively seek a private partner, he said, to build a 500- to 600-megawatt power plant at a yet-to-be-determined location for service by 2005 or 2006. 
The new plant was necessary, he said, because private power companies were canceling projects in many parts of the country because of the economic slowdown, changes in the energy industry and skittishness among investors in the wake of the Enron collapse. He said three companies proposing plants on Long Island might also withdraw, as they had elsewhere. 
Mr. Kessel spoke to the Hauppauge association on Tuesday, a day after the authority and KeySpan Energy agreed to renegotiate and postpone for three years an authority option to buy all 47 KeySpan plants on Long Island. As he has before, Mr. Kessel painted a grim picture of the Island's energy situation.
"Do not believe those who say the energy crisis is over," he told the group. "It is not. We are going to have a tough, tight summer this year."
Mr. Kessel said that even with an additional 400 megawatts of power from 10 small power generators now being built and 330 megawatts that would be imported to Shoreham on the Trans-Energie cross-Sound cable from New London, Conn., the authority would be hard-pressed to meet summer peak demand that he estimated would exceed 5,000 megawatts for the first time.
If demand were to outstrip supply there would be conservation programs and public appeals to reduce electric use, and, potentially, blackouts, rolling blackouts or brownouts.
"We're going to blow by 5,000 megawatts this summer if we have any hot weather, and that's a number we didn't even think we would reach in 2008," Mr. Kessel said, citing an earlier authority projection that peak demand in 2008 would reach 4,795 megawatts.
He said that despite the events of Sept. 11 and the national economic slowdown, electricity demand on Long Island had continued to grow this year at what may be a record pace.
Authority figures showed that commercial demand increased 21.5 megawatts from January to last week, while earlier projections were for growth of 24 megawatts for the entire year.
Joseph S. Fitzpatrick, a senior vice president for American National Power, which is seeking state and federal approvals to build a 580-megawatt power plant in Yaphank, said such a rise in demand showed why Long Island remained attractive to private power companies, even as they pulled back elsewhere in the country. 
"That's the point," Mr. Fitzpatrick said. "There is no one who knows this market who thinks that downstate New York, including Long Island, has ample capacity." He said his company was moving ahead with its plans in Yaphank. 
At the same time, the authority is rushing to bring its own 10 small generators on line. The generators, powered by gas and oil, which will produce 44 megawatts for single units and up to 79 megawatts for combined units, are built or under construction in Far Rockaway, Glenwood Landing, Port Jefferson, Shoreham, Brentwood and Bethpage.
The 79-megawatt level is one megawatt below what would have triggered a full regulatory and environmental review under state law. The Sustainable Energy Alliance, a coalition of civic, environmental and health groups, said the units were inefficient and more polluting than more modern equipment and criticized expediting construction without environmental review.
The Trans-Energie cable, slowed by opposition in Connecticut, now needs only a permit from the Army Corps of Engineers to begin, Mr. Kessel said. He said that without power from the 10 plants and from across the Sound "the lights are not going to stay on this summer."
In the longer term, Mr. Kessel said, under the agreement reached with KeySpan last week the authority and the company could cooperate in repowering existing KeySpan plants that provide more than 90 percent of electricity generated on Long Island. Repowering would involve the refitting of the aging plants to produce more power and less air pollution.
"It may allow us to increase our capacity without having to build all these new power plants in places where people don't want them," Mr. Kessel said. Repowering is backed by environmental and energy groups that praised the postponement of an authority purchase of KeySpan plants they described as "buckets of bolts."
David J. Manning, a senior vice president for KeySpan, said that postponing the takeover decision reduced uncertainties for 600 employees at the KeySpan plants, including senior operators whose familiarity with the plants would be crucial this summer. "Uncertainty can be a villain in this business," he said.
Mr. Manning said the three-year delay avoided a decision at a time when "there is clearly an Enron hangover" in the energy industry. He said the postponement agreement also extended by two years, until November 2008, KeySpan operation of the authority-owned transmission and distribution system on Long Island. "That's a big piece of business for us," he said.

HEADLINE: The View From/Fairfield; 
A Radio Show's Lineup: Women's Sports Only

BYLINE:  By TIM TOWNSEND 

 BODY:
TANDALEYA WILDER never liked being called a tomboy by the kids in her neighborhood in Western Philadelphia. In fact, she hated it.
 "I remember thinking: 'I'm not a tomboy; I'm a little girl who likes to play sports,' " she said recently. " 'And if I could get any other girls around here to play with me, we wouldn't need you boys at all.' " 
 So it may be a vindication of sorts for Wilder that she has grown up to create, produce and be the host of a public radio show called "She Got Game," which is devoted entirely to women's sports. 
For the last two years, the program could only be heard on Wilder's Web site, shegotgame.com., but last month she was given a half-hour time slot each Saturday at 2 p.m. on WSHU (91.1 FM) in Fairfield, where Wilder is also the station's news director. (The show can also be heard on WSUF-FM 89.9 in Long Island on Sunday at 7 a.m.)
Not only is "She Got Game" Connecticut's only radio show dedicated to female athletics, but those at WHSU said they believed it to be the only program of its kind in the country.
"Before we started looking into it, I wasn't aware that this kind of program didn't exist anywhere else," Tom Kuser, WSHU's program director, said. "I would have thought something like it existed on the commercial side, but I actually wasn't completely surprised to find out it didn't.'
Donna Lopiano, the executive director of the Women's Sports Foundation, said, "As far as we know, there are no other women's sports radio shows that run on a weekly basis like "She Got Game."
Wilder, 38, is adamant about making the point that her show will not be "the typical jock show." She said she was aiming to create a program that has more to do with the social, economic and political factors in women's lives than with the sports they play.
"I knew when I came up with the idea I would have something of a niche, because there was nothing else like it out there," Wilder said. "When I started asking people whether they thought a radio show about women's sports would work, so many told me now is the right time."
Wilder said she came from a middle-class, non-athletic family in Philadelphia. She played a lot of sports with the boys in her neighborhood, however, and eventually tennis became her favorite sport.
She made the tennis team in high school and at Temple University where she majored in radio, television and film.
Wilder said she refined her radio skills by working at Temple's station, and by the time she graduated, said she had a vague notion that she wanted to be a sports reporter. But, in the mid-1980's, that option did not seem to be a viable one to her.
"Robin Roberts was just starting to do something with sports reporting then," she said, referring to the ESPN sports anchor. "I had the inclination, but doing it for a living didn't seem all that realistic."
Instead, Wilder said she worked as a news anchor and a reporter covering education and politics for a variety of public radio stations, including WHYY in Philadelphia and WNYC in New York City.
She said she began contributing feature stories to National Public Radio in the early 1990's and, in 1997, filed her first stories to NPR from the United States Open tennis tournament in Flushing Meadows, N.Y. 
In 1999, while working for Connecticut Public Radio, Wilder said she pitched an idea to her producers to commemorate Women's History Month: a one-time show devoted solely to women's sports.
She said listeners responded positively to the program, but it would take a move to different station and another three years before Wilder's "She Got Game" hit the public-radio airwaves last January. In the process, Wilder said she also had to battle with the National Basketball Association for trademark rights to the show's title
Dawn Staley, a guard for the Women's National Basketball Association Charlotte Sting, said: "It's important to have a show about women's sports on the radio.
"There are so many sports radio programs that cater to men's sports and the only coverage that women's sports get on those shows are as punchlines to jokes," said Staley, who is also the head coach of Temple's women's basketball team and has been a guest on Wilder's show. "To have something of our own is special."
Lopiano said: "You'd think sports programs would cover both men's and women's sports. But at best, 8 percent of sports coverage is devoted to women, and it's closer to 6 percent. If you want to fix this, you stop pressing for time within the context of men's sports coverage, and you start your own."
Wilder said: "Public radio listeners are sophisticated and intelligent, and they might not be all that into sports. But they are into good stories, and that's something I never have to worry about. There are so many great stories out there about female athletics."
When Wilder landed at WSHU her bosses said they were familiar with her work at NPR and believed she would be able to pull off a feat many thought to be impractical.
"Depending on who you talk to, common wisdom says sports don't work on public radio," Kuser said. "But we knew Tandi was looking to show people sports in a social context, to tell the story behind the headline, or maybe tell a story that would never make the headlines."
Bill Littlefield is familiar with presenting a sports show for a public radio audience. His weekly one-hour show, "Only a Game," first aired in spring 1993 on WBUR in Boston and is now syndicated each weekend to 138 stations around the country.
"The idea then was that a public radio sports show was an uphill battle," Littlefield said. "Our feeling is that good stories, well told, will resonate with a public-radio audience, even with listeners who aren't big sports fans. If that's what Tandaleya is doing, she should be successful."
So far, according to Kuser, WSHU's listeners seem to be still adjusting.
"We've had response from both sides," Kuser said after the fourth show. "Some say, 'Gee this is an interesting approach to sports.' And then there are some who have responded the way you might think a public-radio listener stereotype would respond."
But Kuser thinks once people listen to the show's segments -- a recent piece, for example, was "Here . . . Now," a tribute to the Olympian Florence Griffith-Joyner, by the jazz composer Wynton Marsalis and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater -- they will understand that "She Got Game" is about more than sports.
"I take it as a huge compliment when someone says, 'I'm not all that into sports, but I like your show,' " Wilder said.
She said she was developing a show dedicated to the 30th anniversary of Title IX, the 1972 ruling requiring schools to provide equal financing for women's sports. Wilder is hoping to become syndicated one day.
Lopiano said: "What's important is not "She Got Game," but what's behind it. Tandaleya is the tip of the iceberg, and what matters is finding the critical mass. Will she start a snowball effect by opening economic doors for others? It's one thing to let girls play, but it's another to let them play in the marketplace."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tandaleya Wilder, the host of "She Got Game," with Tom Kuser, the program director at WSHU. Ms. Wilder, who is also the station's news director, created the sports show. (Photographs by Susan Farley for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Coming of Age, Saxophone in Hand 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS STAUDTER 

DATELINE: CROTON-ON-HUDSON 

 BODY:
FULL of confidence, Loren Stillman, a 21-year-old saxophonist from Croton-on-Hudson, played in the 15th annual Thelonious Monk International Jazz Competition in Washington at the end of last month, hoping he could walk away with the $20,000 first prize.
 The youngest of 15 semifinalists in the contest, which is restricted to musicians under 35 who have not recorded for a major label, Mr. Stillman knew he was competing against the best. But after 16-year-old Sarah Hughes from Long Island beat a field of older, more experienced athletes for a gold medal in figure skating at the Winter Olympics, he figured that he, too, had a shot at the top. 
 So much for storybook endings. The winner this year was Seamus Blake, a 31-year-old tenor saxophonist and member of the Mingus Big Band.
Sponsored by the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, which oversees educational programs, the contest focuses on a different instrument each year. This year is the third time that the saxophone has been featured.
In the past, when economic times for the record industry were brighter, winners and runners-up in the competition, like the tenor saxophonist Joshua Redman, a first-prize winner in 1991, have also won recording contracts. Although a contract is no longer a sure or even likely thing, the competition offers some news media attention along with the monetary prize.
Though Mr. Stillman did not win, he said the experience was rewarding.
"I was nervous beforehand, but once I got on stage I felt everything was cool," he said.
The night of the rehearsals he had dinner with other competitors. At the finals, seated with his parents in the audience, he said he heard a lot of incredible music, including a duet between the pianist Herbie Hancock and the saxophonist Wayne Shorter, who, along with Mr. Redman, George Coleman, Don Braden and James Spaulding, judged the contest.
Mr. Stillman, who was born in England where his father was working, moved with his family to Croton-on-Hudson when he was 3. He began playing the saxophone when he was 7. Focusing on classical music, he continued his lessons through grade school, and also became known locally for his long, green-dyed hair, which he has since shorn and stopped dying, and skateboarding antics in the village parking lots.
A summer spent at the New England Music Camp in Sidney, Me., at age 13 encouraged him to take the saxophone seriously, Mr. Stillman said.
"I had an amazing teacher there at camp, Dan Goble, who was a saxophonist too, and he really believed in me," Mr. Stillman said. "He convinced me that I had some talent, and from that point on, I just started to practice all the time."
Mr. Stillman became so devoted to his saxophone that whenever his parents wanted to punish him for one misdeed or another, they would simply hide the neck piece of his instrument for a few days, he said.
Even before he was in high school, Mr. Stillman attended Wednesday night jam sessions for jazz musicians at One Station Plaza, a performance space in Peekskill, which is where Bob Meyer, a 56-year-old Peekskill native and jazz drummer heard him play. Before long he was chaperoning Mr. Stillman to gigs in Manhattan.
"Loren played way beyond his years," said Mr. Meyer, who plays with Mr. Stillman in Jackalope, a trio that plays in the metropolitan area, including in New York. "His sound was lyrical and beautifully melodic, and it was obvious that he was trying to come up with original ideas."
In 1995, when he was 15, Mr. Stillman recorded a CD, "Cosmos," on Soul Note Records, with a quartet that included Mr. Meyer on drums. It was mentioned favorably in Jazziz magazine and Jazz Times.
After high school Mr. Stillman attended the Manhattan School of Music but left after two years at the urging of his saxophone teacher there, Dick Oatts.
"Loren's the kind of musician who'll answer all of his questions about music by playing sax and writing music on his own," Mr. Oatts said.
In the past few years Mr. Stillman has worked in various bands and performed in most of the jazz venues in and around New York City. Recently, he has been subbing in the horn section of the Vanguard Orchestra at the Village Vanguard in Manhattan on Monday nights.
He has recorded another CD, as yet untitled, which he is trying to sell to a record company. Most of the bigger jazz labels, though, are not signing new artists right now.
"I'm not looking to be the next jazz superstar or anything like that," Mr. Stillman said. "Instead, what I'm interested in is a long career in music and its never-ending beauty. That's what I'd call real success."

HEADLINE: Ever Farther From Queens 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
EVERY Sunday the Sikh Forum of Glen Cove, a temple with about 150 members, becomes a whirl of activity.
 Downstairs in the kitchen, a dozen women form an assembly line to prepare trays of fresh roti, an Indian flatbread. Some of them sing "wahe guru" -- God is great -- as they knead and fry the bread. Not far away, men stir huge kettles filled with lentils and other vegetables cooked with different curries and spices. 
 Upstairs, members gather in the prayer hall as hymns are sung and the priest preaches from the Sikh holy book. On the floor above, some children study the rudiments of their parents' native tongue, Punjabi, and others learn how to play the instruments used in the religious ceremony -- the tabla, a set of drums, and the harmonium, a small reed organ. 
"I look forward to this time every week," Ramita Lamba said as she helped roll out the dough for the roti. "It's to remember our culture and our religion, but there's also the social aspect of getting to see the community and friends."
Ms. Lamba, 34, said there are only two other Sikh families in Glen Head, where she has lived for the last 10 years, so she places great value in being able to come to a place where she can be just one of many. Here, the women's colorful tunics and head shawls do not stand out; nor do the men's turbans or the boys' patkas -- a head covering gathered into a knot on top.
Indians are the fastest-growing Asian community on Long Island, nearly doubling in population from 17,523 in 1990 to 34,333 in 2000, according to the 2000 census. Asian Indians, who include Sikhs, Hindus, Muslims and Christians, are now the largest Asian group on Long Island, followed by the Chinese and the Koreans.
These Asian groups have grown enough in recent years to support their own supermarkets, language schools, churches, temples and mosques on Long Island, making the weekly trips that many families used to make to ethnic enclaves in Queens unnecessary. Many members of these Asian groups say the best restaurants and specialty stores still lie west of Nassau County, and ties to places like Little India in Jackson Heights, Chinatown in Flushing and the Korean areas of Flushing and Bayside have not yet been severed. But the Asian communities on Long Island are well on their way toward self-sufficiency.
Many of the Island's Asian families first settled in the ethnic enclaves in Queens and, following a time-honored pattern, migrated to Long Island in search of the suburban ideal -- a single-family home, a patch of lawn and better public schools.
"When we initially come to settle in this country, most go to the city where they can go easily to jobs," said Harsimran Singh, a trustee at the Sikh temple. "Then when we become financially better off, we move out here." Dr. Singh, a real estate investor, first arrived in Queens in 1973 and moved to Long Island 12 years ago.
But unlike previous generations of immigrants eager to assimilate into mainstream America, these latest arrivals are doing their utmost to hang onto and transmit their cultural heritage to their children.
Asians, including some 16 different census groups, increased by nearly 58 percent on Long Island in the last census, from 62,050 in 1990 to 97,851 in 2000, with about two-thirds of that number residing in Nassau County. Still, Asians only represent 3.6 percent of the Island's population, and many say that if anything, their status as a minority here makes it even more important to find ways to maintain a sense of ethnic identity.
Dr. Singh said there are large Sikh communities in the Richmond Hills and Flushing areas of Queens, but on Long Island, the families are much more scattered. "During the week, everybody is busy," he said. "But on the weekend, we can all come together here as a community."
The largest concentrations of Indians on the Island are in Elmont, Hicksville, East Meadow and North New Hyde Park. In the Herricks school district, which has seen a large influx of Indian and Korean families, the Asian population in the high school went from 5.5 percent in 1985 to more than 36 percent last fall.
Naheed Zara, 35, immigrated to New Hyde Park from India five years ago, joining family members who had arrived on Long Island before her. As she roamed the aisles of the Maharaja Supermarket in New Hyde Park one day recently, she said that before it opened three years ago, she went to Queens regularly for essentials like basmati rice and ginger or lime pickle. But even though her shopping needs can now be met on Long Island, she said, "it's quieter here and sometimes I feel very isolated and homesick. I miss the crowds." So every now and then, she still heads to Jackson Heights, glad to fight traffic and be jostled by fellow shoppers.
In Suffolk County, the State University of New York at Stony Brook has become a magnet for many Asian groups. A university survey in 1997 found that roughly 22 percent of undergraduates were Asian, and the incoming freshman class that year was 30 percent Asian. The changing demographics have led to the creation of programs that position Stony Brook to become an East Coast hub for Asian-American studies.
Kamal Sridhar, a linguistics professor, helped create the Center for India Studies at Stony Brook in 1996. "Students came to me and said there are so many of us, about 2,000, and yet there were absolutely no courses on India," she said. Since then, members of the Indian community in the area have helped raise nearly $500,000 to establish the center, and 10 to 12 courses on India are now taught each semester.
Also in 1996, Gary Mar, a philosophy professor at Stony Brook, approached Charles B. Wang, the chairman of Islandia-based Computer Associates, for help turning an unused hallway into space promoting Asian culture. Their conversations eventually led Mr. Wang, who was born in China, to donate $25 million to the university to create an Asian-American center, which will serve as a cultural home for Asian students and a place to expose non-Asians to Asian culture. The university is now searching for someone to lead a new department that will study Asian civilizations as well as the history of Asians in the United States.
"Students have a real hunger to understand the contradictions in their experience," said Dr. Mar, who started teaching an Asian-American course in 1997. "They want to know how it is they can be considered foreigners even though their people have been in America for a long, long time and why people say to them, 'Are you really American and can we trust you?' "
Dr. Mar said he and others in the Asian community decided to take action after the 1993 suicides of two Asian girls, one Chinese and one Indian, from Ward Melville High School in East Setauket.
"That was a shock to the community, and we all saw a fear of pushing our children to succeed too hard and not being able to deal with discrimination," he said. "We have to teach them about their heritage and about the history of this country to empower them to be agents of change."
His sentiment was shared by parents of children attending the Plainview Chinese School, which opened in September 2000 in a building that also was donated by Mr. Wang. There are about a dozen schools on Long Island that teach either the Cantonese or Mandarin dialects of Chinese, but most of them hold classes in church basements or in borrowed space at local colleges. The Plainview school is the first building dedicated exclusively to teaching Chinese language and culture. It teaches Mandarin to about 400 children each weekend using textbooks and teaching methods from both Taiwan and mainland China.
The Chinese population on Long Island grew 44 percent, from 18,257 in 1990 to 26,338 in 2000. Areas that have seen the largest increases include Setauket and East Setauket in Suffolk County and Hicksville, Syosset and North New Hyde Park in Nassau County. The opening of the Plainview school and of V & T Supermarket, a 35,000-square-foot emporium of Chinese groceries, herbal remedies and porcelains, in Hempstead last December has finally given Chinese families on Long Island services to rival those in Flushing.
Terry Joe sends her 9-year-old son and 11-year-old daughter to the Plainview school, which has three-hour sessions on Saturdays and Sundays. Ms. Joe said that when they moved three years ago from Queens to Manhasset, teaching her children about Chinese culture became a high priority because they were suddenly thrust into a school where there were only a handful of Asians.
"Especially in Long Island, where they are such a minority, it's even more important that they be proud of their culture," she said. "When somebody makes fun of them because of the way they look or what they eat, which happens quite often, I want them to understand their culture so they can defend themselves properly."
Ming-Der Chang, the principal of the school, said that while most parents who send their children to Chinese schools in Chinatown or in Flushing are recent immigrants and expect their children to attain fluency, the expectations of suburban parents are a little different.
"Here, in many cases Chinese isn't spoken at home and they don't expect the children to be Chinese scholars," she said. "To them it's more important their children know the culture than to actually be able to read and write."
Unlike Indians and Koreans, groups that use their places of worship as community centers, Dr. Chang noted that most Chinese are not affiliated with a church or temple. Instead, the Chinese school becomes a place where parents can socialize on weekends while their children are in class. She sent her own children, who are now grown, to a school run out of the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury. "Most of my good friends, I met them in Chinese school," Dr. Chang said. 
Like their Indian and Chinese counterparts on Long Island, many Korean transplants have come from Queens, where there are large concentrations of Korean immigrants in Flushing and Bayside. The Korean population on Long Island increased 40 percent, from 9,024 in 1990 to 12,548 in 2000.
Pyong Gap Min, a sociology professor at Queens College, said that Korean churches serve as the main community centers for Korean immigrants, and that some churches have migrated eastward with their congregations. The Korean Church of Brooklyn, for example, is one of the oldest Korean congregations on Long Island and has shared space with a Presbyterian congregation in Garden City since 1989.
The Rev. Choong Sik Ahn, the pastor, said Long Island had about 10 Korean churches when his congregation arrived, but there are now more than 35. His church has about 250 active members, but its mailing list ballooned from 500 names five years ago to more than 1,000 in Nassau County.
He said moving to the suburbs has introduced socio-economic differences into the congregation that didn't exist when the church was based in Brooklyn Heights. In addition to recent immigrants who live in close quarters in Brooklyn and Queens, he said, there now are "old timers" who have established themselves and moved to the suburbs. "Their lifestyles are different," he said. "They may stay together in church, but sometimes there's a gap between them."
At church, the differences are overshadowed by the desire to worship and break bread with fellow Koreans. The lunchroom after the church service is filled with sounds of Korean chatter and is spiced with the smell of garlic and kimchee. To accommodate English speakers, the church holds an English service as well as a Korean one. The church also holds Korean classes for children of church members and for Korean children who were adopted by non-Korean families in the area.
Borah Kim, 16, said she has learned enough Korean at the church school to help her get by on her visits to family in Korea. But more important, she said, she feels at ease at the church because she is surrounded by so many others like her.
Miss Kim said her family moved to Dix Hills from Queens when she was 4 years old and the transition was not easy. "I never noticed that I was different," she said. "But I could tell they were not really open to the idea that I wasn't white."
Young Sook Kim, 55 and no relation to Borah Kim, said that when her two daughters were growing up in Valley Stream, they frequently were teased about their Asian features and their studious habits. "I said you may have physical small body, but you tell them you have a big mind, and if they call you a nerd, what's so bad about being a nerd?" she said.
Mrs. Kim's daughters are now 18 and 26, and she said she noticed that while most of their friends were non-Koreans when they were at home, they both chose to mingle more with other Koreans when they went away to college. She laughed when she said her daughters now complain, "Why didn't you push us harder to learn Korean when we were young?" 
Mrs. Kim said she was confident that bringing her children to the church had helped give them a clearer sense of themselves. "It gave them faith and the culture, and it also gave them the guidelines to help them overcome problems," she said.
"America used to be called the great melting pot," Mrs. Kim said. "Now it's the great tossed salad. And I think this is better, because melting means you lose yourself, but tossing means you keep your own flavor and taste."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Piscataway; 
An Old Town With High-Tech Ambitions

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
WITH its large corporate tax base providing much of the money and Rutgers University supplying some of the brainpower, the township of Piscataway in northern Middlesex County is becoming an e-government pioneer.
 Over the next three months, T-1 high-speed Internet lines are to be installed in the municipal complex on Hoes Lane. Soon afterward, according to Mayor Brian C. Wahler, businesses and residents will be able to use their computers to pay municipal taxes and apply for building permits and marriage and pet licenses. Police cars will be equipped with global positioning pods to allow dispatchers to pinpoint their locations at all times, and local utility line maps will be posted on the Worldwide Web. 
 In addition, Piscataway is a member of a 13-municipality consortium that is working with Rutgers University, which has two campuses in Piscataway, to draft a three-year $1.5-million federal grant proposal to develop new e-government services. 
"Whether we get the grant or not, we are going forward with e-government," the mayor said. "A grant will speed up certain services, allow us to benefit from economies of scale and help us to develop new services. For instance, people might be able to punch in their addresses and call up maps of the parks nearest their homes, with all of the equipment and ball fields in virtual reality."
Piscataway, a 19.1-square-mile township just across the Raritan River from New Brunswick, feels like an average suburban community, with good schools, a mix of housing priced from about $100,000 to more than $700,000, no central business district and moderate taxes. According to statistics released by Middlesex County, its $4,075 average tax per residence is the median rate among the county's 25 municipalities. 
However, Piscataway enjoys atypically sound financial health, bolstered by a corporate tax base that supplies 40 percent of its $33 million annual budget. During the day, its population swells fivefold with commuters, according to the town's chief financial officer, Ulrich Steinberg. They work at the dozens of high-tech corporations that line Centennial Avenue and at the Busch and Livingston campuses of Rutgers University and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, which together occupy nearly four square miles off Metlars Lane.
According to Robert J. DiLeo, president of DiLeo Realty Associates on Stelton Road, the township has more than 16 million square feet of commercial space. By far the largest taxpayer in town is Telcordia Technologies, which occupies seven office buildings and pays nearly $4 million in taxes.
Last month, the township issued $8 million worth of municipal bonds to cover the technology program, renovations to the municipal complex, road improvements and the reconstruction of 17 of its 26 parks -- all without increasing taxes. The other parks were renovated over the last 18 months.
Jobs, the tax rate and easy highway access -- the town is bisected north-south by Interstate 287 and is near Route 1, Route 18 and the New Jersey Turnpike -- are fueling a housing boom. According to Phyllis Brent, a real estate agent at Re/Max First Realty, many homes sell on the day they are listed. "Anything good that is priced properly will be gone within two weeks," she said.
Quoting statistics released by the Multiple Listing Service, Ms. Brent said that sellers receive an average of 97.5 percent of their asking prices. In many cases, bidding wars among potential buyers push the price even higher. At the end of February, 93 homes, with asking prices ranging from $130,000 to $494,000, were listed for sale on the Multiple Listing Service. Most buyers are professional couples, many from New York City, according to Ms. Brent.
"Recently, a five-lot subdivision with starting prices of $440,000 sold out in less than one month," she recalled. "There was no model house. People just bought off the plans and artists' renderings. I have a list of more than 10 people who want to buy houses in Piscataway."
Some of the most expensive areas of town are the Hillcrest Drive section off River Road, across the Raritan River from New Brunswick, and the Maplehurst Farm area, near the South Bound Brook line. Ten-year-old 4,000-square-foot, four-bedroom homes on half-acre to three-quarter-acre lots in the Hill Crest Drive area can fetch more than $700,000, according to Ms. Brent. Four-bedroom, 3,500-square-foot houses Lilac Way or Goldfinch Court in the Maplehurst Farm area sell in the half million dollar range. Small Capes and older colonials in the Arbor area on West Fifth or West Seventh Streets or the New Market section around New Market Street, both in the northern section of town, sell for $120,000 to $150,000.
Piscataway has just over 2,200 condominiums in nine developments, the largest of which is the 545-unit Society Hill, off Morris Avenue, consisting of two- and three-bedroom, two-story town house-type units and two-bedroom apartment-type units. Recently, a three-bedroom town house sold for $173,500 and a two-bedroom town house went for $168,000. The latest sale of a unit on one floor was for $136,750. 
There are a total of 3,680 rental apartments in 13 complexes, the largest of which is the 1,142-unit Pleasant View Gardens off Pleasant View Drive.
Among those who were attracted to Piscataway in recent years are Sarah E. Grant; her husband, Kevin; and their daughters, Aisha, 10, and Amina, 6, who moved from nearby Freehold Township to a four-bedroom colonial on the east side of town near the Edison line five years ago. Mrs. Grant, an Avon representative, says the couple was searching for a home closer to Mr. Grant's job as an electrical engineer at the Agere Corporation in Murray Hill, about 12 miles to the north. 
Mrs. Grant, who is president of Partners in Education, the parent-teacher organization in Knollwood Elementary School, says she studied the schools before choosing Piscataway. "We wanted a school system that was diverse so that our children could develop tolerance and learn to get along with people from different cultures," she explained. "We also liked the location, which is near New Brunswick, with its theater district. And we wanted the open space. Lately though, more and more housing is being built. There's more traffic, and trees and wildlife are disappearing."
The Piscataway Township School District has 6,759 students in six elementary and three middle schools and the two-building Piscataway High School. Its student body is 35 percent white, 32 percent African-American, 23 percent Asian and 10 percent Hispanic. "We are a community of heterogeneity, with many different races, religions and ethnicities," said the superintendent, Robert L. Copeland.
There is at least one computer and Internet access in every classroom. The average class size is 21.5 in elementary and middle school, which is about the state average, and 24 in the high school. 
In a vote on Tuesday, residents narrowly approved a $52.8 million bond referendum to renovate all of the schools and add a gymnasium, 18 classrooms and two technology labs the elementary schools; 11 classrooms to the middle schools; and science labs, music rooms, a gym and offices to the high school. However, they rejected a $3.7 million bond issue to build a competition-sized swimming pool for the high school. 
According to Mr. Copeland, the district will be reimbursed by the state for about one-third of the cost of the improvements. Officials say the bond issue will raise the average annual residential tax bill by $102. 
Last year, 49 percent of Piscataway High's 481 graduates went to four-year colleges and another 27 percent went to two-year colleges. The district's students scored a combined verbal and math average of 1,004 on the College Board tests, compared with a state average of 1,012. The school offers 12 advanced placement courses in English, statistics, calculus, the sciences, art, history, music and foreign languages.
The town also has five private religious schools: St. Frances Cabrini, a Roman Catholic school, serving prekindergarten through eighth grade; Our Lady of Fatima, a Roman Catholic nursery-to-eighth-grade school; Lake Nelson Seventh Day Adventist, a K-8 school; the Timothy Christian School, a nondenominational K-12 school; and Yeshiva Shaarei Tzion, a Jewish K-8 school.
The largest of the 26 town-owned parks is the 77-acre Columbus Park, off Lakeview Avenue. Last year, its baseball and softball diamonds, basketball and tennis courts were renovated. It has a lake for boating. 
This year, under the bond issue, 17 parks are to be renovated and made handicap-accessible. Roller hockey rinks are to be added to Byrne Park, off Woodland Avenue, and Perrine Park, off Scott Street.
Also in the town are the county-owned 473-acre Johnson Park, off River Road, and the Raritan Landing 18-hole county-owned golf course off Centennial Avenue, where a round costs $24 daily and $26 on weekends.
PISCATAWAY also has a municipal museum, which is in the Metlar/Bodine House on River Road, built in 1728 by Peter Bodine, a wealthy merchant, and later expanded to 14 rooms. It contains local memorabilia, including a wall and fireplace from Ross Hall, a grand mansion built in 1739 and later demolished; a collection of arrowheads; and exhibits on transportation. 
Although she would prefer that the museum be known for its collections, Hara S. Durkin, associate director, acknowledges that 25 ghosts are said to inhabit the house, including those of a woman who reads limericks aloud and a man who leaves the smell of pipe smoke in his wake.
The Metlar/Bodine house, which is open Saturday and Sunday afternoons, was built 62 years after the first settlers arrived in the area under a 300-square-mile land grant from the first British governor of New Jersey, Philip Carteret. The earliest settlers were Quakers and Baptists fleeing intolerance in the Puritan colony in New Hampshire. The township is believed to have been named for the settlers' former home on the Piscataqua River in New Hampshire.
Their early settlement, which was called Raritan Landing, was the fourth oldest settlement in New Jersey, predating New Brunswick, just across the Raritan River. Currently, nine 18th- and 19th-century Raritan Landing homes along River Road constitute a historic district listed on the National Register of Historic Places as the Road up the Raritan. Another Piscataway structure on the National Register, the Cornelius Low House, a Georgian manor built by a merchant in 1740, is now a county museum. 
Piscataway has two supermarkets and a couple of shopping centers, the larger of which is Centennial Square off Centennial Avenue. It also has a battered old business district, which is in need of renovation, on Stelton Road. Mayor Wahler says he is seeking a $1.6 million grant from the New Jersey Department of Transportation to provide new sidewalks, Victorian-type lighting and parking.

A STOP ON THE WAY TO WAR: Camp Kilmer, which straddled the Piscataway-Edison border on Stelton Road, was the largest staging area in the United States for troop embarkation in World War II. From its activation in 1942 until the Defense Department started phasing it out in the 1960's, more than two and a half million troops passed through the base, named for Joyce Kilmer, the poet and New Jersey native killed in World War I. It covered more than 1,500 acres and cost $25 million to build. Much of the land is now used for the Rutgers University Livingston Campus, a campus of the Middlesex County Vocational Technical School, an apartment complex and industrial areas.

HEADLINE: Entering the Era Of Marketing 

BYLINE:  By STUART MILLER 

 BODY:
THE music was salsa, and the art was Soviet. Some people were dancing, and some were content just to look at the paintings. The place? New Brunswick, at last month's edition of the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum's "First Thursdays: Art After Hours," in which the museum, on Rutgers' New Brunswick campus, stays open late on the first Thursday of most months, offering music and guided tours.
 The Zimmerli series, inaugurated in late 2000, is just one example of how New Jersey's museums are attracting visitors through marketing techniques that have long been used by big-city institutions. Throughout the state, museums are adding music and other programs, often during extended hours; building new spaces; opening cafes and gift shops; and generally striving to heighten their visibility while making themselves a destination for local residents. 
 These tactics are "really a national trend, and New Jersey is not necessarily ahead of it," said Ofelia Garcia, chairwoman of the Jersey City Museum's board. She pointed out that government agencies, foundations and philanthropists want museums to prove that they can expand their audiences and earn income on their own. A nationwide survey, conducted in 1999 by the American Association of Museums of 1,800 museums, showed that gift shops and publications bring in more income than admissions. 
Last fall, the Jersey City Museum moved into a new space, which includes a theater that will be used for films, lectures and music programs, some of which, its officials hope, will be presented by outside groups paying a rental fee. Last month, the Montclair Art Museum unveiled the last stage of a major renovation, adding an atrium that will eventually be rented out for readings, concerts, weddings and corporate events.
In late 2000, the Zimmerli redid its gallery space, making room for its First Thursdays and other events; last November, the Zimmerli added a cafe. Princeton's Art Museum began an evening jazz series in late 2000, and two years ago, the Morris Museum revamped its gift shop.
Like Montclair, most of the state's larger museums rent out space for weddings and corporate events, or are planning to do so.
The adoption of these tactics reflects economic realities but also the growth of a sophisticated suburban audience familiar with similar offerings at, for example, the Brooklyn Museum of Art, which is open late on the first Saturday night of each month for special events, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which, under Thomas Hoving, pioneered efforts in this area over two decades ago.
Steve Miller, who became executive director of the Morris Museum in Morristown last fall, said museumgoers no longer viewed cafes or evening programs as added attractions. "They have become basic amenities," he said.
Greg Perry, acting director at the Zimmerli while the director is on sabbatical, said, "The bar has been raised a little bit, even for smaller museums, to cater to visitors as much as possible."
The increase in marketing is also related to the fact that five museums -- in Montclair, Jersey City, Morristown and Princeton, and the New Jersey State Museum in Trenton -- have in the last two years hired new directors with significant administration experience in New York institutions. In New York, marketing has been an integral part of a museum administrator's job since the days of Mr. Hoving, who led the Metropolitan Museum from 1967 to 1977, and is credited with creating the so-called blockbuster exhibition, like the King Tut show.
"Hoving called upon museums to be more relevant as society changed, to be more diverse and more outgoing," said Mr. Miller, adding that administrators who started out during the Hoving era are now leading museums nationwide.
Patterson Sims, director of the Montclair museum since September, said the concept of marketing a museum, once an "alien thought," was now integral to the job. Mr. Hoving agreed.
"Back then, the critics sliced me regularly," he said. "But people have realized that museums are more than just a haven for scholars and that they can carry out these ideas without going down the popular culture drain. Today, any new legitimate source of revenue is welcomed by even the fustiest staff member."
This has not happened overnight. Mr. Miller said New Jersey's museums had been gradually changing in the past decade, joking about the difference between "real time" and "museum time." Restricted by tight budgets, an institutional culture that favors decisions made by committee, reliance on volunteers, and an innately conservative outlook, a museum can take 5 or 10 years to transform itself. It must also deal with its board members, who are generally older than the audiences that administrators want to attract.
"What may be great for a grandchild of a trustee may be appalling to the trustee," Mr. Sims of Montclair said.
Still, boards have become more open to experimentation and even failure.
The Newark Museum, the largest in the state, has had a cafe, an off-site gift shop, corporate events, Thursday late hours and a presence on museumshop.com for years. But it too is aggressively raising its profile, said its director, Mary Sue Sweeney Price, recently running its first print and radio advertisement campaign for a temporary exhibition, and hiring a full-time staff member to coordinate its Web site. The museum also hopes to be the first in New Jersey to sell merchandise on its Web site.
Expanding revenue stream and visibility often begins with the gift shop and cafe, though these present challenges.
The Jersey City Museum has a cafe in its new building, and the Montclair renovation included space reserved for a cafe. But Mr. Sims of Montclair said his budget would not allow for a kitchen. Still, he hopes to make a deal with a place like the nearby Whole Foods store to provide prepared foods.
"The cafe is a good idea, but economically it's difficult," he said, particularly for museums that are not large enough to justify an entire day's visit.
Mr. Miller said that the Morris Museum does not get enough visitors to sustain a cafe economically, but that about two years ago, it transformed its gift shop, adding more upscale jewelry and children's merchandise. The shop sits along a lobby wall, so that locals can come in without going to the museum.
The Zimmerli has had a gift shop for several years. It also has a small display at Johnson & Johnson headquarters in New Brunswick, and Mr. Perry, the acting director, wants to open satellite stores in other locations in that city.
The Zimmerli's cafe has entrances through the shop and the Rutgers art history building, drawing customers not only from museum visitors but also from professors and students. Mr. Perry does not expect to make money from the cafe.
"I'd be happy if we broke even," he said, just to make the museum a destination. 
In planning events, the institutions take different paths, depending on the size, location and demographics of the surrounding communities. For example, as Mr. Miller of the Morris Museum pointed out, events geared to single people may work well at a university museum, like the Zimmerli or Princeton, but not in his institution, which is in an upscale suburban setting.
Meanwhile, Helen Shannon, the executive director of the state museum, said that unlike, say, administrators at the Jersey City Museum, she cannot focus on one geographic area. Instead, she said, she must balance the need to build a local presence in Trenton and to maintain statewide relevance.
At Montclair, Mr. Sims is considering whether to pursue a First Thursday concept. The question, he said, is whether locals will turn out. He pointed out that New Jerseyans are more likely to drive home and stay there, unlike in New York, where people go out after work.
"People are more house-oriented here than in New York," he said.
Last fall, the museum began to stay open until 9 p.m. on Thursdays, with free wine and cheese, but there has been little promotion and not much traffic so far.
Additionally, Mr. Sims is concerned about competition with local institutions. The Montclair Library offers a jazz series, and Montclair State University has a lecture series. He is considering a readings series and an occasional co-presentation with the university because the museum's atrium can hold more people.
Mr. Miller of the Morris Museum is also searching for ways to draw in his community in Morristown. He said he would like to experiment with different genres of music in the museum's theater, and is also thinking about making the museum "a learning center" by having universities from the area or even New York that want to do outreach programs send in faculty for lectures.
Ms. Shannon of the state museum is exploring signing on with Trenton's First Fridays program, in which on the first Friday of each month, local galleries and stores stay open late, and there are jazz performances and readings in various city spaces.
At the Zimmerli, Mr. Perry said the Thursday series has attracted people who work during the day and are busy with errands and family on weekends. In February, the event pulled in about 200 people of all races and ages, regular visitors and newcomers alike, he said.
Renee McKinney, 20, a Rutgers junior, was one of them. She had been meaning to visit the museum but had never made it. She said that although the salsa band brought her in, she spent more time looking at the paintings than dancing. Meanwhile, Earl Thomas, 67, of Highland Park, comes to the museum regularly but had never been to a First Thursday before.
"I like to dance, and this is a lot of fun," he said. "And the music infuses the art with something extra."
At Princeton, Susan Taylor, the director, said the Friday night jazz series, advertised locally, has been attracting 300 to 350 people. Ms. Taylor has plans for other events, like those that go with the show "Anthony Van Dyck: Ecce Homo and The Mocking of Christ," which opened on March 9. The exhibition explores Van Dyck's religious paintings, and so the museum is holding a concert and film series that includes the showing of Martin Scorcese's "Last Temptation of Christ."
These events may bond the museum with its community, but the biggest moneymaker, and the one most museums cannot afford to ignore, is renting out space for parties and other events.
"They can generate a significant amount of money to put back into programming," said Mimi Gaudieri, executive director of the Association of Art Museum Directors.
The Montclair museum has hired a manager of special events, which are held in the museum's atrium. Rates range from $1,500 for a nonprofit group holding a weekday event to $3,000 for a corporation holding a weekend event.
The Zimmerli holds such events in the same space where bands perform on First Thursdays. The museum charges $600 to $1,100 per event. Mr. Perry said demand had doubled since the program began in late 2000.
Meanwhile, new ideas are on the horizon. Mr. Hoving said that improving Web site technology will give museums more options -- including selling work by artists in their collection or by local artists.
Ms. Price, of the Newark Museum, said museums may begin collaborating, doing joint promotional events and campaigns. She pointed out that a member of the Montclair museum is more likely than the "average Joe" to check out an exhibition in Newark or at the Morris Museum.
The biggest danger, Ms. Taylor of Princeton said, is that museums will become so focused on ancillary programs that they stray from their main goals or compromise their mission. But Mr. Hoving said, "As long as they don't go into kitsch -- if the quality is good, then there's nothing wrong with trying something different." He added: "The word 'museum' refers to all of the muses. It's always a question of balance."
