HEADLINE: White House Adds Billions To an Increase In Foreign Aid 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 19 

 BODY:
Ahead of President Bush's visit to a development meeting here, the administration substantially overhauled a proposal to increase foreign aid today, doubling what the president had promised to spend to fight world poverty in coming years.
 The revision came as many officials from both rich and poor nations, while welcoming the first commitment to increase American foreign aid in more than a decade, criticized Mr. Bush's original plan as tepid, especially in comparison with his much more robust commitment to increase military spending. 
 Officials in both Monterrey and Washington said today that the administration now planned to increase foreign aid spending by 50 percent over three years beginning in the 2004 fiscal year. The proposal would raise development assistance to $15 billion, from $10 billion by 2006, the officials said, and would not decrease it thereafter. 
When Mr. Bush announced the original plan last week, he described a $5 billion development fund that would disperse grants for antipoverty projects. Officials said then that the plan would increase foreign aid by 15 percent each year during the three-year life of the fund, and they made no commitment to keep spending more money after 2006.
While the Bush administration called the new total a clarification, it would entail a great deal more spending than the president and his top advisers first stated. If the foreign aid budget is to grow in equal yearly increments of $1.65 billion from 2004 through 2006, as officials said today was likely, the cumulative increase in spending would amount to about $10 billion over those three years, double the initial estimate.
Late today in Washington, Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, confirmed that the administration now favored a cumulative $10 billion increase over three years, bringing the foreign aid budget to $15 billion by 2006. Mr. Fleischer said the White House and the Treasury Department miscommunicated details of the package last week.
Yet last week, administration officials who briefed reporters at the White House were quite clear about the terms of the aid proposal, detailing increases of roughly 15 percent from 2004 through 2006.
Any promise to increase spending in several years is really notional -- Congress controls the purse, and there is no guarantee that Mr. Bush will control the White House throughout the period in question. But the revision illustrates how arithmetic has taken center stage in the first two days of a weeklong session in Monterrey on helping poor nations.
Development experts -- those few who knew tonight about the revised plan -- hailed it as momentous, saying it showed how quickly the United States could commit to mobilize resources to combat poverty when the White House has the political will.
"It's a huge deal," said James D. Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank.
His reaction contrasted sharply with responses to the plan as originally detailed, which many antipoverty experts had been parsing to point out what they called shortcomings. European officials were touting their own proposed increase in foreign aid as far greater than what the Americans promised, both in total dollars and as a percentage of European economic output.
United Nations officials hailed progress in getting rich nations to focus on aid. But Mark Malloch Brown, head of the United Nations Development Program, said before the Bush administration's announcement today that, all told, the pledges were still not "on anything like the scale that we argue is necessary" to cut poverty in half by 2015, a goal set by world leaders in 2000.
George Soros, a financier and philanthropist, belittled the administration's first proposal, saying it was "nicely packaged with too little in the package." The French development minister, Charles Josselin, said the plan fell short.
Former President Jimmy Carter, also responding to the earlier plan, praised Mr. Bush for promising to reverse the decline in aid since the end of the cold war. But he also said the amount the United States spent on aid, about 0.1 percent of national output, was tiny. 
A senior administration official here said that most delegates had reacted positively to the first Bush plan and that the upward revision was not intended to defuse criticism. He said the administration wanted to clarify the terms and amounts of aid.

HEADLINE: MIXED MEDIA; 
America's Real Foodie Bible (It's Not What You Think)

BYLINE:  By REGINA SCHRAMBLING 

 BODY:
TASTE OF HOME is a magazine that does not print certain words. Like confit. Or microgreens, or extra virgin, or fleur de sel. Or, especially, chef. 
 Its photo features on kitchen makeovers are not littered with brand names like Garland and Sub-Zero and Corian. Its travel stories wander no farther afield than rural restaurants where the potatoes are made magical through the whipping in of cheese, butter, cream and more cheese. And its party features combine themes like fish or football with homemade touches like fin-shaped place cards and pigskin birthday cakes. 
 No editor could make this stuff up. 
Maybe it's just a coincidence, but Taste of Home also claims the highest circulation of any food magazine, about 4.5 million, which is more than Bon Appetit, Food & Wine and Gourmet combined. And right now it may be the most talked-about food magazine in the country.
In the last week, the Reader's Digest Association has been reported to be in talks to take over Reiman Publications, the obscure but eminently successful company in Greendale, Wis., that publishes Taste of Home, for at least $700 million. Neither company would comment. 
But if the deal succeeds, what Reader's Digest will acquire is a fiercely loyal following for recipes and ideas from a universe far removed from the one that celebrates chefs and esoteric ingredients. And I have to count myself among those devotees.
Taste of Home has been my guilty pleasure for years, ever since my consort's mother in Buffalo sent me a gift subscription for Christmas and hooked me on its determinedly downscale approach to food. All the recipes are submitted by readers, making it a unique barometer of how America really eats. It's like a Junior League cookbook in installments every other month. 
Taste of Home is just one piece of a unique empire, based in a little town that looks right out of a David Lynch movie but is actually two Interstate exits south of Milwaukee. The magazine has its own visitors' center, complete with a store selling Reiman merchandise, and even has its name on a surprisingly stylish restaurant. I made a pilgrimage there a couple of years ago and am still thinking about it. 
Although the magazine itself has other wacky attributes, the food is the main fascination. I have never actually clipped a recipe for a main course I would serve to company, let alone my consort, but some party staples have been born from the snack columns (Taste of Home does not call such tidbits anything fancy like hors d'oeuvres, or even appetizers). A loaf of round sourdough, crosshatched and stuffed with sliced pepper Jack cheese, soaked in melted butter and baked to irresistible gooeyness, is typical of what I consider crossover cuisine, from the countryside to a Manhattan co-op. Bar cookies -- the heartland's answer to petit fours -- are also generally good bets.
In these pages, one casserole is worth six saute pans, and a can opener is a cook's right hand. Jell-O is not just accepted but venerated, and cream of mushroom soup is as essential as stock. 
But on the whole, real ingredients add up to real food. Ann Kaiser, the managing editor, who also serves as the magazine's spokeswoman, says readers are interested primarily in from-scratch cooking. (A new sister publication that relies on convenience foods, Quick Cooking, has cut into the original magazine's circulation.) 
Almost every recipe is depicted in an elaborately styled photograph, which minimizes the need for detailed directions. The magazine has a huge loft at its headquarters stocked with thousands of cake stands, casseroles, pie plates, table linens, salt and pepper shakers and other accessories to give a country look to the food photos, which are nothing like what you see in Saveur's features on home cooking. 
The writing is as much of a hoot as many of the recipes. No one ever "says" anything; it's always "relates" or "remarks" or "reveals." The "editors" are billed as "a thousand country cooks," all of whom contribute recipes, cooking tips, anecdotes and photographs in return for their names and faces in the magazine. 
In reality, a small staff translates readers' letters into deliberately folksy copy and tests every recipe (after first checking an extensive database to be sure it has not been previously printed). Taste of Home is just as calculated as any glossy urban food magazine.
It does dispense solid information, and with none of the humorless pomposity of Cook's Illustrated. Cooking With Janaan, a question-and-answer feature, reassures a reader wondering if a Bundt cake can be baked in an angel food pan with "yes, indeed" heartiness (as long as the pan is two-thirds full and a foil wrapping keeps the batter from leaking). 
Shortcuts Worth Sharing offers reader advice: "For delectable red cabbage, add a cinnamon stick, admits Catherine Stahlmann of Arlington Heights, Ill." Taking a Trip With Food showcases recipes for ingredients like black walnuts or popcorn from farmers' wives in a particular state, and those are often winners -- who better than a cook with a plethora of carrots to come up with offbeat ways to serve them? 
Taste of Home also publishes features no New York or Los Angeles magazine would dare, like Our Family's Favorite Grace. It acknowledges that America's obsession with fat and sugar is taking a toll by emphasizing recipes for diabetics, and that the economy has not exactly put a foie gras in every terrine by including a column called Feed Your Family for 99 cents a Plate. 
What it does not mention is wine. Apparently this food is meant to be eaten with drinks like the apricot cows in the current issue: apricot nectar blended with ice cream, nonfat dry milk and sugar. 
The magazine has been able to go its own way partly because it answers only to its publisher and readers, not mainstream advertisers. Roy Reiman started the business in his basement in 1970, at a time when farm magazines were cutting out their women's pages because they could not sell advertising. He dreamed up a broadsheet called Farm Wife News that was "dedicated to partners of the nation's farmers and ranchers" and intended to be "a medium for the exchange of good ideas." To subsidize it, he turned to subscriptions and built quite an empire. One that is apparently very appealing to Reader's Digest, which is suffering in the current advertising slump. 
Reiman, which publishes nine other magazines, like Birds & Blooms and Reminiscence, also runs tours and a mail-order business. While it constantly boasts about its lack of advertising, each thin issue of Taste of Home comes in a plastic bag packed with fliers for other magazines and merchandise. Its pages are just free of the Baby Gap and Acura ads that make Food & Wine so hefty. A subscription is $17.98 for six issues, 50 percent more than what Gourmet charges for 12. Newsstand copies are $3.99. Some of the content is also available free online, at www.tasteofhome.com.
Mr. Reiman sold a majority interest in his company in 1998 to Madison-Dearborn Partners but continued to oversee the business, including starting Taste of Home Restaurant. The menu purports to showcase recipes from the magazine, and readers come from hundreds of miles away to eat there. Some even drink wine from a decent list. 
The visitors' center was opened to divert obsessed readers away from the magazine's hive-like offices nearby. It houses a glassed-in demonstration kitchen staffed by women in lab coats who mechanically crank out cookies (MMMinnesota Munchers when I was there; mix for sale). A shop downstairs is heavily stocked with Reiman merchandise: cookbooks, crockpots, baggy, cutesy sweatshirts like the ones on many of the patrons and gadgets like a knife just for iceberg lettuce.
Until I made my odyssey there, I have to admit my fascination with Taste of Home was tinged by a slightly creepy feeling. As a childless urban atheist living in sin, I was suspicious of a magazine in which virtually every face was white, every woman was married, widowed or single for some other good reason, every family had Mom, Dad, kids and usually grandparents at the table and church was mentioned in every fourth paragraph. I could almost see Pat Buchanan behind the Betty Crocker mask. 
But after a couple of days in Greendale, I realized that the magazine literally reflects its readership. The visitors' center and the restaurant were both full of faces straight out of the magazine's cluttered pages. Aside from a couple of bus boys with name tags like Fidel and Fernando, everyone was white. Some were even Amish. 
Ms. Kaiser explained the magazine's appeal simply: "People who are reading it kind of feel that sitting down for a family meal or taking dinner to a potluck at church is a very significant part of their lives." 
While most magazines project fantasy, Taste of Home creates its own reality. Even if it looks a little alien from here in melting pot Manhattan.

Another No-Frills Approach
Robert Parker Jr. also takes an ad-free approach to his latest venture, a Web site with something for everyone, whether the dedicated consumer, the wine geek obsessed with comparing vintages or merely the culinary/oenophile voyeur. 
The site, eRobertParker.com, crams reams of information into an easily navigated format. The home page features include links to news stories about wine, a recommendation for the wine of the day, taken from past issues of the Wine Advocate, and a search service to track ratings of thousands of wines. 
One-week trial subscriptions, with access extremely limited, are free. Subscriptions are $29 a quarter, $99 a year.
For all the detailed information on the site, the Hedonists Gazette is the most fun. Anyone with a taste for over-the-top meals eaten vicariously will not be able to resist the extravagant descriptions of food-and-wine pairings at Daniel, Citronelle, Le Bernardin, Mr. Parker's home and other upscale dining rooms.

SAVORY PARTY BREAD
Adapted from Taste of Home
Time: 35 minutes

1 round loaf sourdough bread, about 1 pound, unsliced
1 pound Monterey Jack or pepper Jack cheese, sliced
1 stick butter, melted
1/2 cup chopped scallions
2 to 3 teaspoons poppy seeds, optional.

Heat the oven to 350 degrees. Crosshatch the bread without cutting through the bottom crust. Insert cheese between the cuts. Combine the butter, scallions and poppy seeds, and pour over the bread. Wrap in foil. Place on baking sheet, and bake for 15 minutes. Uncover, and bake 10 minutes longer, or until the cheese is melted. Serve.

Yield: 6 to 8 servings.

HEADLINE: Dept. of Dysfunction 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A dysfunctional English department at Columbia ("Columbia Soothes the Dogs of War in Its English Dept.," front page, March 17), like the recent flap over African-American studies at Harvard, makes for juicy reading -- the very stuff that might find its way into a mystery by Amanda Cross (a k a the ex-Columbia English professor Carolyn Heilbrun)!

HEADLINE: Calling In the Makeover Medics 

BYLINE:  By LAURA ZIGMAN 

DATELINE: NEWTON, Mass. 

 BODY:
I SUPPOSE you could say I felt the way any troubled person would right before picking up the phone and finally calling for professional help: desperate, resigned, deeply relieved. The help I needed, though, wasn't psychiatric, physical or spiritual (at least, not technically). It was domestic, spatial, aesthetic.
 It was decorating, to be exact. 
 In December, after years of apartment living, I finally moved into a three-story Victorian with my fiance and our 18-month-old son. I had always felt, somewhat smugly, that I had an eye for home decor. But now, whatever eye I thought I had was gone. 
Overwhelmed by the choices (multiple rooms, multiple possibilities) and confounded by a difficult living room (not enough wall space, not enough seating, pocket doors, French doors, lots of toys), I sat on my poorly situated sofa (too close to the curtainless windows, too far from the coffee table) and froze. Putting our house together seemed like a problem involving space and numbers, shapes and flow and placement and cohesion, and I had never been good at physics or math.
Like most of our friends, we thought decorators were for other people. Rich people. But that didn't mean we aspired to be do-it-yourselfers. We craved transformation, reinvention, instant gratification. We needed a house makeover. More specifically, we needed the Redecorators.
Their ad in the back of a magazine promised a flat-fee one-day decorating service that would use the furnishings we already had. I couldn't pick up the phone fast enough.
Dotty Volpe and Dolly Sturman are the Redecorators, and makeovers are what they do. They are also partly handymen and partly mini-contractors. They will rearrange furniture and rehang art, and will advise on window treatments, wall colors, lighting, painters, electricians and plumbers, and bring in furniture and accessories on approval. They will even write a detailed plan for other projects to be carried out when time and money allow.
The first room costs $350; after that the fee per room is $100 to $300. Any new items that are kept are charged to the client, with a 20 percent markup.
(Lauri Ward in Manhattan, a pioneer in the field of restyling, charges $325 for a room less than 19 feet long and $200 an hour for shopping.) 
Although they are based in Boston, Ms. Volpe and Ms. Sturman will travel anywhere in New England and to New York City (at the client's expense), which might explain why there is a wait of up to eight weeks for their services.
One thing interior decorators and redecorators agree on is that business has boomed since Sept. 11. Ms. Volpe points to the slowed economy and the fact that people are staying home more. "Those who were going to do the big family room add-on or big kitchen redo are now saying: 'You know what? We should wait and do that, so let's make our homes more functional as they are.' "
The Redecorators arrived on a cold snowy January morning looking like the odd couple (Ms. Sturman, a brunette, in a long black skirt and impossibly high-heeled boots; Ms. Volpe, a blonde, in head-to-toe Gap) and sounding like the guys from "This Old House" (the thick Boston accents, the good-natured bickering and shop talk).
Fit and attractive at 50-something, they met in 1990 when Ms. Volpe, who has a background in real estate, construction and politics (she did advance work for Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and President Jimmy Carter), was "staging," or styling, houses for sale. Two years later, she and Ms. Sturman, an interior decorator, became partners.
"One reason we've been successful is that people are afraid of decorators," Ms. Volpe said. "They're afraid of being told that everything they have has to go. But we don't do that. People have things they love, and we'll find ways to use them." 
Even if it's something that's ugly?
"Well, if it's something that's really ugly," Ms. Sturman said, "we'll find a way to use it in a corner."
The first order of business was a walk-through of the entire house. This took more than an hour, which surprised me. I wondered if it was because I was trying to run interference between them and my furniture. "We've always hated the color of . . .," I explained. "We're definitely going to get rid of . . . . As soon as we can afford to, we're going to replace the . . . ." Perhaps it was because it was taking time for Ms. Volpe to measure everything -- a rug, an armoire, a chest of drawers -- with her size 11 feet. Then again, it may just have been that Ms. Sturman was having trouble getting up the stairs in her long tight skirt and high-heeled boots.
Actually, this part of the process is often lengthy, Ms. Volpe told me later. "We go everywhere, into every room, and we always find great stuff," she said. "People always tell us there's nothing in the attic and nothing in the basement, but there's always a table, or a chair, or something we can use."
Back downstairs, we devised a game plan: they would focus on the living room (not enough seating), the dining room (too much white) and the foyer (completely empty). They would find (cheap) curtains for the bank of three bay windows in the living room and get a (cheap) slipcover made for an expensive, oversize ottoman stored on the third floor. We also decided to tone down the natural-gumwood trim in the foyer and dining room by getting the walls painted.
Ms. Volpe suggested tannery, a butterscotch-gold, for the living room; safari tan, a lighter shade of gold, for the foyer; and shy cherry, a deep red, for the dining room. She also located a (cheap) team of six painters to do the job in one day, promising that she and Ms. Sturman would return after that "and do our thing."
Restyling has its critics, especially among interior designers who like to start from scratch. Celeste Cooper, the design director of Repertoire, a high-end contemporary furniture store in Boston and in Manhattan, acknowledged that "there's nothing more dreadful than an interior designer who insists that you have to throw out everything you have." But she rejected the theory that "all the things you love will somehow fit together." 
"There's only so much a designer can do to meet your fantasies of what your space could look like by just shuffling around your existing furniture," she said. "It's a question of failed expectations. Eclecticism badly done is a license for chaos."
Elaine Notestine, the owner of the Dovecote, an interior design firm in Dallas, said: "Just as there's a big difference between optometrists and ophthalmologists, and chiropractors and surgeons, there's a big difference between decorators and designers. Most of these 'redecorators' can make things pretty, but they also need to have a knowledge of scale, proportion and good design."
When my redecorators returned to check the paint job and to make their next move, they brought along Tom Greene, a decorator who helps them move furniture and select accessories like lamps and trays. Then they ordered my fiance and me out of the house.
"Some people find change traumatic," Ms. Sturman said. "It's better for them to see the whole thing pulled together, instead of focusing on why we're moving this lamp and that table. I mean, it's not like we're going to do something horrible to your house." (Shades of "Trading Spaces," the hit redecorating show on the Learning Channel.)
Ms. Volpe gave the real reasons: "We move faster if you're not there." And "we swear at each other."
Five hours later we surveyed our made-over rooms. We loved the bold colors on the walls, the sheer cotton-polyester curtains hung on the living room windows ($318 for ready-made panels and hardware) and the white wicker chair from the bathroom, which had been spray-painted black ($15 for three cans) and moved next to the mantel. A black velvet club chair, previously shoved against the nonfunctioning fireplace, had migrated to the radiator. A large wicker trunk from Pier I ($200) held all the toys that used to clutter the floor, and the ottoman, now functioning as a giant coffee table, had been slip-covered in a durable deep rust textured cotton remnant ($25, plus $50 for the seamstress). The rugs had been switched around; a chest of drawers from the guest room had been spray-painted black ($15 for three more cans) and placed in the dining room with a gateleg table unearthed upstairs.
A tableau had been created in the once-barren foyer with more goods hauled down from upstairs: another gateleg table, two chairs, a lamp and a plant. 
Our costs were modest: $750 for their services and $655 for items they purchased. Painting the two rooms and foyer added another $1,600.
We sat blinking and staring for hours. Was this really our house? Where did all the seating in the living room come from? Why couldn't we figure any of this out ourselves? And why do we own so many stupid wicker baskets? Then we realized that having your house redecorated is a little like getting your hair restyled. It's never quite right when you leave the salon. You need to mess it up, wet it down, blow dry it yourself before you really start to love it.
And so, after a little redecorating of our own (we returned some red lacquer vases and sneaked our photographs back onto the mantel) our house finally started to feel like home.
For the first time.

It is By Design Interiors, not Design Interiors.

HEADLINE: Out of Jail and Out of Food 

BYLINE:  By Herman Schwartz; Herman Schwartz, professor of constitutional law at American University, is chairman of the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
After barely two minutes of debate, a floor amendment was added to the 1996 welfare law that denies food stamps and welfare (Temporary Aid to Needy Families) for life to anyone convicted of a drug felony. It is doubtful that the members of Congress realized a large part of this burden would fall on struggling women and their young children.
 A study by the Sentencing Project, a research organization based in Washington, estimates that since the ban went into effect in 1996, 92,000 women have been convicted of drug offenses in the states enforcing it. Of these, about two-thirds are mothers, with 135,000 children among them. 
 Obviously, the only people hurt by this denial of benefits are the poor, which usually means a minor offender who is an addict and out of jail trying to make it. The big operators, the manufacturers and distributors of illegal drugs, don't need government benefits. And offenders in prison are being supported by the state.
States can opt out of this ban, but 42 still enforce it for at least some drug felons. The offender can do nothing to lift the ban, regardless of whether that person is only a minor or a first offender, in treatment or cured, sick or pregnant or supporting a family -- and regardless of whether he or she lives a completely blameless life forever after.
Theoretically, the law denies these benefits only to the person convicted and not to the rest of the family, but this distinction is often meaningless. A single-parent family of three, for example, in which only the two children are entitled to food stamps, will obviously divide the food three ways. And when the mother cannot get welfare benefits she may not apply for them for others in the family.
Many of the women likely to be affected by this rule are among life's saddest victims. A study of 31 women in a drug treatment facility in Philadelphia found that almost all had been sexually assaulted by boyfriends, stepfathers, fathers and others. Many were physically sick -- with diabetes, hypertension and sexually transmitted diseases -- and many were mentally ill.
Ex-prisoners have always had a hard time getting jobs, and because of the recession and Sept. 11, it is now even harder. Few drug offenders have any community help or other supports, and because of their drug convictions they are often unable to get into public housing. Many become homeless.
Residential drug treatment centers are also hurt by this ban. They usually require those they treat to turn over their food stamps and other benefits; the centers use these to supplement their own resources.
The Senate has passed a repeal of the ban as an attachment to an authorization bill for the Justice Department. The House is not likely to follow suit: Chairman Bill Thomas of the Ways and Means Committee wants the issue debated as part of the welfare reform reauthorization coming later this year. Restoration of food stamps to some of the neediest Americans is too important to be tied up in legislative maneuvering. Members of Congress must get together and pass it. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed 

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Effective victory in the war against terror hinges on cutting off resources.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. Both publications are based in Armonk, N.Y. He is an adjunct professor of humanities at Cooper Union. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
THE war against terrorism promises to be a long one, and the horror of Sept. 11 may suggest that pulling out all the stops is justified. But any government policy, including war, has costs and benefits. Can traditional economic analysis provide useful insights into how to fight this war? Relevant analysis has been undertaken at least since the late 1970's, with a number of economists now specializing in this. Their findings are sometimes frustrating, but, by no means conclusive, can be surprisingly useful.
 A first step is to determine all the costs of a terrorist attack. Sept. 11 clearly went beyond the loss of life, however tragic. The attack had serious economic consequences for consumer spending and airline travel. It had long-term consequences for the costs of insurance, new construction safeguards and airline security, to name but a few. It also took an emotional and psychological toll on the nation. In nations where terrorism is more common, experience shows that it deters foreign investment, and probably domestic investment as well. Tourism can be permanently reduced. Thus, however gruesome the calculus is, preventing terrorism has wide benefits. 
 But the more sophisticated economic analysis has to do with how best to fight such a war. One way of looking at terrorists is to understand that, as with consumers, they are constrained by financial resources -- and by the number and skills of their personnel. Also, a terrorist act, like a consumer purchase, has a certain benefit, or utility. For terrorists, the benefit is usually creating political instability.
For consumers, if a product becomes more expensive, we may buy less of it. For terrorists, if an act is made more difficult, or more dangerous, they will perceive that the cost is raised and may be deterred. They cannot afford many failures or the loss of personnel.
The first study to analyze terrorism this way was by William Landes in 1978. He found, for example, that when metal detectors were installed at American airports in 1973, there were far fewer hijackings the next three years.
The success of metal detectors was widely accepted then. But like consumers, terrorists may not merely stop buying a product, they may buy a cheaper substitute. Todd Sandler of the University of Southern California, a pioneer in the field, found that terrorists did just that. In a complex statistical analysis that would not have been clear in a mere eyeballing of the data, he and a co-author, Walter Enders of the University of Alabama, showed that terrorists usually sought ways to circumvent metal detectors. Among the most effective was to make bombs out of liquids. What is most compelling about the findings of Mr. Sandler and Mr. Enders is that the number of terrorist incidents remained about the same, but the techniques were changed to avoid detection. 
Similarly, when American embassies were bombed in the 1980's, the government fortified the compounds. But the consequence, Mr. Sandler and Mr. Enders write, was a "disturbing increase in assassinations of officials and military personnel outside of protected compounds." Now military and business personnel are usually protected, but tourists and civilians remain at risk.
Their analyses also suggest that terrorist activities ebb and flow in cycles. They find that incidents declined sharply in the 1990's, though casualties were higher. The danger is that when attacks decline, a nation becomes lax. In fact, they warned back in 2000 that cyclical patterns suggested that major terrorist activity was due again.
The policy implications are clearly frustrating. Preventive activity, like more elaborate security checks at airports, should be intensified. But Mr. Sandler and Mr. Enders say it is almost inevitable that terrorists will seek new ways to accomplish the same thing. "It's unlikely a terrorist will try to use a shoe again," Mr. Sandler says. Thus, the ideal strategy is something like a full-court press. Adopt measures that address existing terrorist methods, but also try to anticipate new methods and technologies.
The evidence compiled by a range of researchers using these techniques also suggests that immediate military retaliation does not reduce terrorism over time. In the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, retaliation generally seems to encourage further terrorist response. In another example, the United States raided Libya in April 1986 for its suspected engineering of a discotheque bombing in Berlin. But Mr. Sandler and Mr. Enders noted an immediate rise in terrorism aimed at American and British facilities and personnel around the world.
In the Afghan war, some economists, including Mr. Sandler, argue that the cost of terrorism has been raised so high that this retaliation will be more effective than past efforts. At the least, the terrorist organization has been severely disrupted. But Mr. Sandler also predicts that the impact, if more durable than most retaliatory efforts, will be temporary at best.
Thus the best hope of preventing terrorism is to focus on terrorists' resources. A war on terrorism should provide ample means to find and confiscate terrorists' money, and make future financing more difficult. It should also be directed at undermining the training and recruiting of terrorists, including encouraging nations not to harbor terrorists.
International cooperation is crucial in a war against terrorist resources. The Bush administration has made efforts in this direction. But these analyses suggest the efforts should be redoubled. Serious cooperation directed at minimizing terrorist resources may well be more effective over time than military action.
One last point is clear. Among the most important resources of terrorists are unemployment, poverty and underdevelopment. There is deep controversy among economists about the economic determinants of terrorism. But terrorist recruits are often unemployed males. Deep-seated grievances also motivate recruits. If focusing on resources is the best strategy, economic aid and fostering development strategies should be integral parts of it.
At the least, we should be clear-eyed about the probable costs and benefits. Maybe most important, economic analysis of these emotional issues can help us remain objective. A simple eyeballing of the data on terrorism, without sophisticated statistical interpretation, can be highly misleading.

HEADLINE: In Los Angeles, a Traveler's Best Friend 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 20 

 BODY:
Since Sept. 11, airport security officials have been armed with an array of new high-tech weapons in the battle against terrorism. Officer Michael Ahumada of the Los Angeles International Airport police force keeps the most important item in her arsenal tucked discreetly in a pocket just below her gun.
 It is a tennis ball tied to a long orange string. 
 "Here, Jackson," she said to a dog that leaped and snapped joyfully as Officer Ahumada bounced the ball above its head in the international terminal. 
"You can't do anything without this," she said. "But it's her reward for doing a good job."
With little fanfare, bomb-sniffing dogs have become among the most effective, and important, security tools at airports, federal and local airport officials say. They work quickly and have an almost perfect record in separating real explosives from merely suspicious items -- which has made them one of the best friends of harried travelers desperate to avoid the security delays that mar air travel.
While billions of dollars are being spent on devices that peek inside suitcases and carry-on bags, given the new federal mandates on screening all baggage, dogs offer reassurance and are far less intimidating than some of the new measures.
In no city have the dogs made more of a difference than Los Angeles, which faces a far more serious security challenge than any other airport.
Los Angeles has the third-busiest airport in the country in terms of passenger traffic, after Chicago's O'Hare and Atlanta's Hartsfield airports, but it is the busiest in the world as measured by the amount of luggage it handles. The reason: more travelers begin their trips here, rather than merely make connections. That leaves officials with the job of screening roughly 150,000 pieces of checked baggage each day.
It is a task that frequently leaves officials with tough decisions about whether to evacuate terminals each time something unusual is found.
In recent weeks there have been several major disruptions -- one when an officer forgot to plug in a security wand, one when a replica of a grenade was found in a bag, and another when a scanner mistook a coffee grinder for a bomb -- each sending ripples through airports around the country because dozens of flights were delayed.
The issue is particularly significant for Los Angeles because the airport, operating well beyond the capacity it was designed for 20 years ago, generally rates poorly among travelers. J. D. Power & Associates, which runs surveys and rankings, says that travelers rate the airport here below average, in large part because it is aging and, since it is broken up into small terminals, offers far fewer shopping and eating choices than newer airports do.
Using dogs to screen luggage "has been around, but it was not really on the front burner," said Michael DiGirolamo, the airport's deputy executive director of operations. "They were valuable before, but they are much more valuable now. There's no question, the dogs are quicker and they have fewer false alarms."
Frank A. Clark, the executive director of the company that operates the big international terminal here, said: "There is no downside to these dogs. It's all positive because we've got to get away from closing terminals whenever a problem is found. The dogs are a big help in that."
The airport police here had no bomb-sniffing dogs before Sept. 11, but the Los Angeles Police Department rotated a few teams through the airport. Since then, the airport police have bought five dogs, for about $11,000 each, including training, and five more are on the way.
Jackson is a 3-year-old, female Dutch-born Belgian Malanouis, one of the most popular breeds because of its sensitive nose and cheerful manner. The airport also has some German shepherds. Federal officials said that Labrador retrievers and even standard poodles are being trained for airport duty around the country.
The Transportation Security Administration, the new federal agency overseeing airport security, estimates that the number of the dogs nationwide will rise to 300 in about two years, from 175 now, spread over 80 airports.
Officials here say the dogs may prove the salvation of travelers because they may do more to prevent unnecessary terminal evacuations and other security delays than many of the expensive new devices, like the massive CTX machines, which run a CAT scan of luggage. The airport here has 13 of the machines -- each weighs about 8,000 pounds and is roughly the size of a hefty sport utility vehicle -- with more on the way.
"Where they really help the most is in that gray area, when we're asking, 'Should we or shouldn't we evacuate?' " Sgt. Blair Lindsay of the airport police said of the dogs. "They're so good. We always trust them."
Officer Ahumada said that on several occasions Jackson has cleared suspicious bags that, without the dog, might have prompted an evacuation. The dogs are trained to identify 13 varieties of explosive, including gunpowder and C-4.
"They're mobile and they can lead you to the source of a problem," said Rebecca Trexler, a spokeswoman for the Transportation Security Administration.
They also cheer people up. Strolling through a terminal here with Jackson was like being with Julia Roberts on a crowded city street. Nearly everyone who noticed her responded with a smile or an outstretched hand, followed by kissing sounds. Three Japanese travelers rushed over and cooed, "Kawaii," meaning, "Cute!"
"We chose these dogs in part because we want this," Sergeant Lindsay said. "People feel good around them."
Travelers said the dogs gave them a visceral sense of security that the machinery did not.
"I just thought immediately when I saw the dog, 'This is very good,' " said Robert Prokop, a businessman from Germany. "Everyone likes dogs, but you know what they can do. It's safer."
Nearby, a young couple smiled at the lanky dog and gave her a little scratch.
"To me it's a lot more reassuring to see them, and they don't carry machine guns," said Kelly Farnsworth. "It's more efficient, too."
David Hicks, a visitor from New Zealand, said, "It's a great idea, much friendlier."
Even the officers said that they felt more relaxed.
"I don't know how the machines work," Sergeant Lindsay said. "Somehow I feel better knowing a brain is thinking about this and continually separating out the small things. I really have a lot of confidence in these dogs."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS; 
Dow and Nasdaq Both Retreat as Investors Take Profits

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A weaker outlook for Intel and the possibility of higher interest rates prompted investors to collect profits yesterday, pushing the markets sharply lower.
 Wall Street's losses widened as the session went on, with the Dow industrials falling more than 130 points. The Nasdaq composite index posted its weakest close this month. The drop followed the Federal Reserve's decision on Tuesday to leave interest rates unchanged, although the central bank hinted of possible increases later this year. 
 "There's a lot of concern that when rates go up, the recovery will slow down," said Stephen Carl, head of United States equity trading for the Williams Capital Group.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 133.68 points, to 10,501.57. On Tuesday, the Dow closed at its highest level of the year. The index has advanced for five weeks on increasing signs that business is improving.
Stocks rallied on Tuesday after the Fed's move affirmed that the recession could soon be over, but investors were cautious yesterday, said Alan Ackerman, executive vice president of Fahnestock & Company.
"Economists believe the Fed will reverse last year's trend of rate cuts with a rate hike in June or September," Mr. Ackerman said.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 48 points, to 1,832.87, its lowest level this month. The last time the Nasdaq ended lower was March 1 when it stood at 1,802.74. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 18.44, to 1,151.85.
Traders said they were concerned that the Fed would increase interest rates before corporate earnings improved, which would make it difficult to justify the prices of some stocks.
Shares of Intel fell $1.19, to $30.53 after its second-quarter earnings and revenue estimates were lowered by Salomon Smith Barney. Shares of a rival, Advanced Micro Devices, dropped 62 cents, to $14.17.
Other technology companies reporting lower share prices included Microsoft, down $2.13 at $60.10, and I.B.M., off $1.99 at $105.50. Analysts said the technology sector would be the last to emerge from the recession as it waited for other companies to resume spending on computers and networking equipment.
Investors in the last month have heard upbeat reports from old-economy sectors including manufacturing. So yesterday's report that construction of new homes rose a bigger-than-expected 2.8 percent in February, to its highest level since December 1998, failed to encourage much buying.
Home builders also traded lower, which analysts attributed to the prospect of higher interest rates. Shares of Lennar fell $2.17, to $52.62, despite the company topping first-quarter earnings estimates by 4 cents a share.
Shares of the Biopure Company jumped $3.13 yesterday, or 39 percent, to $11.15, after reporting on a clinical trial in which 59 percent of the orthopedic surgery patients receiving Hemopure, its artificial blood substitute, had not needed human blood transfusions during surgery or a 42-day recovery period.
One big loser was Bristol-Myers Squibb. Its shares fell nearly 16 percent, down $7.57 at $41.08, after disclosing that tests of its blood pressure drug, Vanlev, was no more effective than existing treatments. --------------------

Treasury Prices Decline
By Bloomberg News
Treasury notes fell sharply yesterday on reports that housing starts grew sharply in February, fueling expectations of an increase in interest rates. 
Investors sold Treasury notes a day after the Federal Reserve said that economic risks were now more evenly balanced between inflation and weakness. 
"The major catalyst for these sizable liquidations was the housing- starts statistics," said William Sullivan, director of money market research at Morgan Stanley. "The market hit a brick wall in response to the report, and we saw a cascade to lower prices." 
The 10-year note dropped 29/32, to 96. Its yield increased to 5.4 percent from 5.28 percent. The 30-year bond dropped more sharply, declining 1 6/32, to 93 26/32. Its yield rose to 5.82 percent from 5.73 percent.

HEADLINE: Kidnappings By Koreans Have Angered The Japanese 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 20 

 BODY:
From a courtroom here, new details about a North Korean program to kidnap Japanese citizens in the 1970's and 1980's are stoking animosity in Japan.
 Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi met Tuesday with Japanese citizens who say their relatives were kidnapped by North Korean agents during that era. Mr. Koizumi said he wanted North Korea to understand the seriousness of the matter. 
 "The problem involves not only the family members, but the whole state of Japan," he said. 
Japan has been lukewarm about the Bush administration's grouping of Iraq, Iran and North Korea as an "axis of evil." But the court testimony last week strengthened sentiments here against North Korea.
In court, Meguni Yao, the former wife of a Japanese leftist, said that when the couple lived in North Korea during the 1980's, she tried to lure lonely Japanese students, some of them studying abroad, to North Korea. There they were to either join a government-supported "Japan Revolutionary Village" or to train North Korean spies for work in Japan.
Ms. Yao said that in 1983 she lured one woman, Keiko Arimoto, then 23, from London, where she was studying English. Once in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, she was forced to marry a Japanese man who had also been lured there. On Saturday, Ms. Arimoto's parents said that Ms. Yao had told them that she had also lured two other Japanese women to North Korea.
"I am responsible for destroying the life of Arimoto," Ms. Yao, now 46, said in court. "I have brought about tremendous pain on her as well as her parents. I did something unforgivable for a human being."
The Japanese police say they have 13 cases of Japanese citizens who are presumed to have been abducted to North Korea. At a human rights conference here last month, advocates said they knew of 73 cases.
With public anger mounting, Prime Minister Koizumi met Tuesday with Ms. Arimoto's parents and with family members of Megumi Yokota, who disappeared at age 13, in 1977, from a beach facing North Korea. Her parents say she has been spotted in Pyongyang.
"We must take resolute measures in the abduction cases," the Mr. Koizumi told Parliament last week, outlining an interagency task force to study the abductions.
Japan was already moving toward isolating North Korea. After giving it more than 1.1 million tons of food aid from 1995 to 2000, Japan ended food aid last year. In Tokyo, the police are poring over the books of a failed credit union that is suspected of funneling millions of dollars to Pyongyang in the 1990's.
Using intelligence from American military spy satellites, the Japanese Coast Guard keeps a close watch for North Korean spy boats that approach Japanese territorial waters. 
Japan's nationalist right is demanding that Japan salvage a suspected North Korean spy boat that sank in an economic zone claimed by China in December after a firefight with Japanese Coast Guard boats.
"If the government fails to raise the ship in deference to China, the Koizumi cabinet will not last for long," Shintaro Ishihara, governor of Tokyo, threatened this month.
For a while, North Korea's Red Cross Society said it was searching for the missing Japanese, a search it angrily abandoned after the police arrested officers of the North Korean-affiliated bank here on embezzlement charges.
"Reactionary organizations and riffraffs in Japan are these days making much fuss about the issue of 'suspected kidnapping,' a fiction, at the connivance and instigation of the government authorities" to get on North Korea's nerves, a Red Cross Society press statement said.
Yomiuri Shimbun, a conservative Japanese daily, responded in an editorial headlined "Pyongyang's Deceit Exposed: North Korea Biting Hand That Feeds It."
North Korea's refusal to account for the missing Japanese or allow them to correspond with their family members may stem from the fact that the kidnapping program was elaborated in the mid-1970's by Kim Jong Il, the son of Kim Il Sung, North Korea's leader, shortly after he took over direction of the North's espionage efforts. The younger Mr. Kim is now the North's leader.
Kim Jong Il ordered that foreigners be kidnapped to educate North Korean spies in foreign languages and customs, said Tstutomu Nishioka, an executive of a private group here, the National Association for the Rescue of Japanese Kidnapped by North Korea.
The association has 26 chapters across Japan. It has obtained 1.6 million signatures on a petition asking the Japanese government to put pressure on North Korea to account for the missing Japanese.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Rise To Three-Year High, Bolstering Economy 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20 

 BODY:
Housing starts rose in February to the highest level in more than three years, government figures showed today, suggesting that the construction of new homes will underpin a rebounding economy.
 At an annual pace, builders began work on 1.769 million homes last month, up 2.8 percent from a 1.721 million rate in January, the Commerce Department said. That is the most homes started since December 1998 and reflects the fastest pace of single-family housing construction in more than 23 years. 
 "America wants to buy a home," said Stuart Miller, the chief executive of the Lennar Corporation, the large home builder. "As the economy remains, within a range, fairly strong, as interest rates remain historically low, I think the consumer continues to make the decision to own a home."
The report suggests that the economy's recovery will be stronger than expected and may prompt Federal Reserve policy makers to raise interest rates by midyear.
The 30-year mortgage rate rose to 7.08 percent last week, according to Freddie Mac, the large buyer of mortgages. Rates may keep rising after Fed officials indicated on Tuesday that they had dropped their 15-month-old view that weak growth was the biggest threat to the economy.
Rising interest rates will not necessarily choke off the housing market. A record number of houses were sold last year -- in the first recession in a decade -- as 30-year mortgage rates averaged 6.97 percent. That was down from 8.05 percent in 2000, the third-best year for combined new and sales of existing homes in history.
Analysts had expected housing starts to fall from a previously reported rate of 1.678 million units in January.
Starts of single-family homes, which account for about 8 of 10 houses being constructed, increased 7.4 percent in February, to a rate of 1.457 million units. That is the fastest since December 1978, Commerce Department officials said. February starts of multifamily homes, like apartment buildings and town houses, dropped 14.3 percent, to a 312,000 annual rate.
Building permits, an indicator of future construction, increased 1.8 percent, to 1.752 million units at an annual rate, the fastest in a year, after rising 4.1 percent the previous month.

HEADLINE: Commissioner Defends Plan For Garbage and Recycling 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City's sanitation commissioner, facing sometimes heated questions at a City Council budget hearing yesterday, said that cutting the recycling program in half and transferring garbage from one borough to another for cheaper disposal were the least painful ways to keep his department's budget solvent through the city's financial crisis.
 The alternative, said the commissioner, John J. Doherty, is a dirtier New York, with possible reductions in the frequency of trash pickup and cutbacks in street cleaning. He vowed repeatedly that the Fresh Kills Landfill in Staten Island would never be reopened, but said that the reality of the city's budget dilemma was forcing many choices he wished he did not have to make. 
 "We can play around the fringes," Mr. Doherty said, in response to a question about how he might find savings other than his proposed cuts. "But the only other big dollar amount is picking up the waste every day." 
Mr. Doherty's comments, the first detailed defense of his department's proposed budget since it was released last month by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, evoked the specter of a New York that had seemed left in the long ago past of the 1970's, when garbage piling up in the streets became one of the symbols of a fiscal crisis that touched just about every function of government.
But his nearly two-and-a-half-hour appearance before the Council's Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management also raised again and again the question of whether budget cutting -- however dire the emergency -- could justify rethinking what many council members said were political and philosophical issues that had seemed long settled, like the value of recycling.
"Recycling is not a budget issue, it's a policy," said the committee's chairman, Michael E. McMahon, a Democrat from Staten Island.
Mr. Doherty agreed that the suspension of recycling for metal, glass and plastic, which would save the city about $56 million in the fiscal year beginning on July 1, was painful for him to contemplate because it seemed to back away from the city's commitment to long-term waste reduction.
"But at one point do you say this is ridiculous -- we can't pay that much money?" he said of recycling. "A of people feel good about it, they feel happy about it, and you know, it's an ideal thing to do, but at what cost?" 
Some of the council members also expressed dismay about the Sanitation Department's proposed plan to move about 1,500 tons of trash a day -- about one-eighth of the city's residential daily total of just over 11,000 tons -- from Queens to the Bronx, where cheaper contracts were negotiated for waste disposal. And once again the questions were not so much about the dollar savings as they were about what many members of the committee said would be a shift in policy and a reneging on old promises. When Fresh Kills was closed last year, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that under the replacement plan each of New York's five boroughs would be self-sufficient in trash disposal so that no borough would become a dumping ground, as Staten Island was for nearly half a century.
One council member, James S. Oddo, a Republican from Staten Island, said he feared that changing the system to allow interborough garbage transfers would give life to "conspiracy theories" in Staten Island that Fresh Kills, even if it is not reopened for actual dumping of trash, might at some point be used as a giant collection site for transport out of the city by truck or barge.
Mr. Doherty said that the idea of borough self-sufficiency had been a "goal," and that it would remain the city's long-term policy. Budget pressures had forced its reconsideration only for the short term, he said. 
"Our long-term plan will continue to be one that has been approved, that we will not export waste from one borough to another, but one has to keep an open mind on all these things," he said. "I think everybody really thought we could live by it, but we're faced with a situation."

HEADLINE: Study Ranking Utility Polluters Aims to Sway Emissions Debate 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
As debate flares anew over White House plans to revise air pollution regulations, a study that ranks the biggest air polluters in the power industry is expected to be issued today. 
 The study was conducted by two environmental organizations and a large New Jersey utility and uses government data. It contends that a handful of companies accounts for at least half of the industry's most noxious emissions, including those that contribute to smog, acid rain and possibly global warming. Moreover, the study shows a wide disparity in the relative level of emissions produced by power plants, a gap that the authors say reflects the level of investment that companies have made toward improving their environmental performance. 
 The report's release is timed to sway the current discussion about revisions to air pollution rules.
One author, David Gardiner, said such changes could end up protecting the biggest polluters and removing incentives for the industry as a whole to reduce its rate of emissions.
"The very large disparity between the cleanest and the dirtiest companies," said Mr. Gardiner, one of the report's lead authors and the former director of climate change policy in the Clinton administration, "demonstrates that a large number of companies are relatively clean, and a relatively small number are responsible for the vast portion of emissions. It shows that clean electricity is both possible and profitable."
The study, "Benchmarking Air Emissions of the 100 Largest Electric Generation Owners in the U.S. -- 2000," is a collaboration between the environmental groups, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies, and the utility, the Public Service Enterprise Group, based in Newark.
P.S.E.G., as the utility is known, reached a settlement in January with the federal Environmental Protection Agency that calls for the company to invest more than $300 million in the next decade to reduce emissions from its coal-fired plants in New Jersey. 
The study relies primarily on data that companies provided to the E.P.A. and the Energy Department for 2000. It details which corporations are the largest polluters and the relative emission levels of various pollutants by companies. In gross terms, the biggest polluters tend to be the companies that have the most power plants and that generate the most electricity. 
The three largest electricity companies in the United States -- American Electric Power, the Southern Company and the Tennessee Valley Authority -- together accounted for 17 percent to 24 percent of total industry emissions of the four pollutants tracked in the study. Those are sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides, which contribute to acid rain and haze; mercury, which is toxic to humans; and carbon dioxide, which is widely linked to global warming.
Southern, the Tennessee Valley Authority and other energy companies high on the study's list have lobbied the Bush administration strenuously to ease air pollution regulations, according to environmentalists, government officials and Washington lobbyists.
The study also ranks companies based on the amount of pollution produced relative to their power output. By that measure, Basin Electric Power Cooperative, a relatively small utility in Bismarck, N.D., that relies primarily on coal-fired power plants to supply over 100 rural electric co-ops, was identified as producing the highest output of carbon dioxide per megawatt-hour of electricity. But the company contends that its plants are among the cleanest coal-burning plants in the nation.
Similarly, Aquila, a midsize utility in Kansas City, Mo., was 52nd among the 100 companies for the total amount of nitrogen oxides emitted, which reflects how many fewer plants it has, compared with the likes of American Electric Power. 
But Aquila's plants emit significantly more nitrogen oxides than American Electric Power's for each measure of energy generated, the study's data show. Aquila, formerly known as Utilicorp United, ranks third among companies that have the highest relative level of nitrogen oxide emissions, while American Electric Power ranks 11th.
The study points out that relative pollution levels vary according to the kinds of power plants. For example, utilities with a preponderance of plants using natural gas or nuclear fuel produce smaller relative pollutant levels than those with mostly coal-fired plants. Yet even among coal-fired plants, Aquila ends up third for nitrogen oxide emissions, according to the study.
The companies cited in the study did not have the opportunity to read it before its official publication. But based on information he received about the report, Ethan Hirsh, a spokesman for Aquila, contended that it failed to take note of how his company had improved its environmental performance. "We're constantly improving our emissions reductions," Mr. Hirsh said. "Looking strictly at the numbers would fool you a little bit."
Pat Hemplepp, a spokesman for American Electric Power, said the study was "giving you a snapshot of a year rather than a movie of what's been happening over the last decade." He noted that the industry had to function within Clean Air Act requirements, which grow more stringent with time, and that his company had reduced its emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides since 1990 and would continue to do so. 
But Mark Brownstein, director of environmental policy at P.S.E.G., noted that such a benchmark report was routinely done in the industry to compare companies on things like safety or earnings. P.S.E.G. itself fell within the 25 companies with the highest rate of sulfur dioxide emissions at their coal plants, a result that showed the company how much work it still had to do, he said.
"This is to get a sense of companies that have made investments in cleaner technology versus those that haven't," he said. "It asks: 'What kind of company are you? How are your investments paying off?' "

HEADLINE: In Twist, Idahoans Fight Toxic Cleanup 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SMELTERVILLE, Idaho, March 20 

 BODY:
Nancy Slaight knows that the federal government wants to spend big money in the Idaho Panhandle -- as much as $1.3 billion over several decades -- to clean up toxic mining waste in the Coeur d'Alene River Basin. But no thanks, she says.
 "We're not going to eat the dirt, so let it stay there," said Ms. Slaight, 65, a cashier at the Wayside Market here. "Leave it alone." 
 She is one of many here who oppose the government's plan to create one of the largest Superfund sites ever. The plan would vastly expand a 21-square-mile site, where children once had some of the highest levels of lead recorded, and remove lead and other mining wastes in a watershed stretching from the Montana border into Washington. 
Many towns have fought industry or government to force them to clean up pollution, but something very different is happening here in northern Idaho. Convinced that the government's plan is a huge overreaction and that designation of the area as a Superfund site would frighten away tourists and new businesses, many towns have joined a lawsuit to block expansion of the cleanup. 
Town or city councils in Smelterville, Wallace, Osburn, Mullan and Pinehurst have voted to back the lawsuit, and the fight is intensifying as the Environmental Protection Agency nears formal approval of the plan, expected in late spring. 
Many residents strongly support the cleanup, but others say the government is creating more problems than it is solving. 
Officials at the environmental agency say they have worked with local officials to define the problem and forge a solution.
"If contaminants are above a certain level, we can't ignore it," said Bill Dunbar, a spokesman for the agency's Northwest regional office. "We'd get sued by the good number of people there who do want a cleanup, and who want it sooner rather than later." 
The worst of the pollution has been the object of a cleanup project that began in the 1980's, after tests showed that residue from the area's giant silver smelters and the mine tailings were causing sharply elevated levels of lead in local residents, especially children. High levels of lead can cause developmental problems affecting children's growth, mental abilities and behavior. 
Here in Smelterville and nearby Kellogg, government workers wearing respirators dug up residents' lawns and replaced the lead-laden soil in a roughly 20-square-mile area. They scoured the sidewalks and capped huge piles of mine tailings, or residues, along the freeway. The smelters closed, and, in 1996, the giant stacks that had been local landmarks came down. 
Nearly all recent tests have shown a decline in blood-lead levels to roughly the national average, though how much of the drop can be attributed to the cleanup and how much to the decline in mining and smelter activity is arguable. Still, many seem to blame the government for the area's continuing economic distress and low property values. 
"They came in here and turned everything upside down, ruined our yards -- they're full of weeds, and I don't know what for," said Joe Alder, 80, a 43-year veteran of one of the mines who said he was skeptical that there was ever much of a pollution problem. "I've lived here all my life and I'm fine. There are kids here who've grown up to be teachers, or lawyers. They seem fine." 
Others are not so sure about the absence of a problem.
Jacob Brewer, a lumber-mill worker whose wife, 36, was born and raised here, said she had suffered from migraine headaches and thyroid problems for years. She had a battery of tests in the seventh and eighth grades that showed she had significantly elevated levels of lead. 
"I think it would take an awful lot of extensive medical tests to prove that lead did it," Mr. Brewer, 40, said of his wife's health problems. 
A large welcome-to-Smelterville sign just off the freeway depicts "our past" of smelters and "our future" of satellite dishes and other symbols of high technology. 
Whether Smelterville and other old mining towns can attract such business is an open question: but now, as the government seeks to expand the cleanup to areas that have less severe lead contamination, many seem convinced that the term "Superfund" will discourage businesses from coming and harm a small but growing tourist industry. 
"We're trying to diversify, we're trying to revamp an economy," said Bill Dire, a city councilman in Wallace. "But you go out and try to attract a company, and if they look at the Silver Valley and it's a Superfund site, well then you're automatically dropped in the tank. With tourists, it's exactly the same thing. Nobody wants to come to a place they feel is unsafe."
The environmental agency unveiled a $359 million expansion plan last October that seeks to clean up areas that continue to send lead and other dangerous metals into the Coeur d'Alene River Basin. The river transports those metals into Lake Coeur d'Alene, and into Washington via the Spokane River.
The plan would remove contaminated soil from about 1,000 more homes and along dozens of miles of streams and rivers.
Officials in many Idaho towns have demanded a new scientific review of lead pollution, which they are convinced will show that the problem is under control. But other residents are outraged by this bid for a delay. 
Barbara Miller, the director of the Silver Valley People's Action Coalition, which favors the cleanup, said many residents had been brainwashed into denying that lead pollution was much of a problem. 
"There's a real company-town mentality, the idea that for 100 years, Bunker Hill gave everybody a job, it can't be a bad thing," Ms. Miller said, referring to the local smelter site. "But there are real health problems, and the fact is, this cleanup is also the greatest economic opportunity this county has ever seen." 
But 40 miles downstream, where Lake Coeur d'Alene is the center of a growing business in conventions and tourism, many say that expansion would damage the economy without bringing major health benefits. 
"We don't think it's a selfish thing to admit or say we're worried about the stigma of the term 'Superfund,' " said Bret Bowers, director of Community Leaders for E.P.A. Accountability Now, a Coeur d'Alene group that opposes the Superfund expansion. 
"Superfund by its very nature implies that there are a multitude of problems that need to be cleaned up," Mr. Bowers said, "and what we're saying is we don't believe the E.P.A. science justifies the scope of the work."

HEADLINE: Jump in Health Care Lobbying, Then in State Health Care Spending 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20 

 BODY:
In the year before state lawmakers approved a huge increase in health care spending, the powerful hospital workers' union and allied hospitals spent almost $4 million lobbying for that increase, far more than any other interest group spent to influence the state.
 The union, 1199/S.E.I.U., and the Greater New York Hospital Association spent more than twice as much on lobbying in 2001 as they did in 2000, most of it going to television and radio ads to sway public opinion, which they expected would in turn influence legislators and Gov. George E. Pataki. 
 The figures were released today by the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, in its annual report. 
The investment apparently paid off. In January, the Legislature and the governor approved a sweeping health care law that increased payments to hospitals and nursing homes by $1.7 billion, with most of the money earmarked for salary increases for 1199's members.
The report provides new illustration of the extraordinary power of the union and its leader, Dennis Rivera, who only yesterday endorsed Mr. Pataki, a Republican, for re-election. Democrats complained that the endorsement was nothing more than a political payoff for the health care deal by a traditionally Democratic, heavily minority union.
"It's often said that you can't connect the dots between money spent lobbying and legislation," said Rachel Leon, executive director of Common Cause New York, a group that advocates more disclosure of lobbying expenses, and tighter restrictions on lobbyists. "Well, if you look at the No. 1 spender, 1199, we see a direct link. If you want a quid pro quo, there you go."
Mr. Rivera did not return calls seeking comment.
In a year when the governor and the Legislature approved the biggest increase in gambling since the creation of the state lottery in 1966, gambling interests spent $3 million on lobbying in 2001, double what they spent in 2000. After heavy lobbying by casino developers, Indian tribes, gambling machine makers, race tracks and others, lawmakers approved development in October of up to six Indian casinos, installation of slot-style machines at race tracks and expansion of the lottery.
Today's report also shows the astonishing rise as a lobbying power of Patricia Lynch, who set up shop as a lobbyist in January 2001, weeks after leaving her job as a top aide to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver. Patricia Lynch Associates became one of the 10 highest-income lobbying firms here in its first year, at $1.14 million, largely a result of her access to Mr. Silver and other state officials. By year's end, she had 31 clients, including the Long Island Power Authority, Madison Square Garden, Avis, ABC, CBS, NBC, the Seneca Nation of Indians and major developers.
Lobbying commission members said today that for the first time, they would ask the Legislature to give them the power to ban people from lobbying, even permanently, for serious violations of the lobbying law. Historically, the Legislature has been reluctant to expand the commission's power, even refusing to make it a permanent state agency, but rather subject to renewal every few years.
The commission's executive director, David M. Grandeau, said that if the commission had had the power, he would have advocated lifetime bans against Donald J. Trump and Sharon Portnoy, a lobbyist for Philip Morris, the tobacco company, for recent violations. "There's nothing in the act right now that prevents people of bad character or who have done bad acts from lobbying," Mr. Grandeau said.
Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts and related groups paid $250,000 in fines in 2000, and Philip Morris and Ms. Portnoy paid $90,000 in 1999, in both cases for concealing lobbying expenses from the commission and filing false reports. Ms. Portnoy agreed not to lobby the state for three years, but the commission had no power to force that restriction on her.
In all, the commission found, a reported $80 million was spent on lobbying the state last year, up from $66.3 million the year before, continuing a steep upward curve that has seen lobbying expenses double every six to seven years. Those figures do not include lobbying to influence the state's purchasing and contract awards, which does not have to be reported.
1199/S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union, and the Greater New York Hospital Association, which includes most hospitals in the New York metropolitan area and many nursing homes, have repeatedly demonstrated their political influence through their lavish, unorthodox lobbying expenses.
Rather than simply pay lobbyists to persuade elected officials, as most interest groups do, they buy advertising to sway public opinion and ask the public to put pressure on their representatives. They also, at times, threaten that if they do not get what they want, they will use ads that attack those officials directly, and will put 1199's formidable political phone bank operation to work against politicians.
In 1995, their barrage of ads against Mr. Pataki's proposed health care cuts was followed by the governor's partial retreat. In 1999, they mounted a $10 million advertising campaign, by far their biggest, to help win passage of a major expansion of health programs for the uninsured.
Last year, they feared deep budget cuts caused by the recession and the Sept. 11 attacks and wanted to find a way to pay for new contracts between the union and the hospitals and nursing homes. After another ad campaign, they won a major increase in health care spending by the state, in a year when money for many programs is being cut.
For 2001, the Healthcare Education Project, a joint effort of 1199 and the Greater New York Hospitals Association, reported $2.85 million in lobbying expenses, nearly all of it on ads, the most by any interest group. That figure does not count the amount spent after Dec. 31, in the final, most intense weeks of negotiating the health care package.
The hospital group and the union spent an additional $1 million on their own, for a total of $3.85 million last year. In 2000, they spent $1.6 million.
Several others among the top lobbying spenders, including other hospital and nursing home groups, pushed hard for the January health care law and benefited directly from it. Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield ranked second in lobbying spending, at $1.4 million. The law allows Empire to convert from being a for-profit company, which will allow it to raise billions through the sale of stock, in return for giving about $1 billion of that to the state.
