HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
A Power to Fascinate, Whatever Her Station

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
OF all the dead white male geniuses floating around in the fabulous ether of art history, few are as sympathetic and compelling, or as familiar, as the Spanish painter and printmaker Francisco Goya y Lucientes (1746-1828). Emerging from his eventful journey from tapestry designer to court painter to tormented visionary is an artist who seems strikingly modern, not only in style but also in consciousness. 
 Goya's prodigious artistic gifts and ego always seem subsumed within a more urgent project that was partly forced on him by events. History was not so much on his side as at his heels: the French Revolution, the occupation of Spain by France, the revolt of the Spanish against the French and, finally, the return of the oppressive Spanish monarchy. 
 These brought unimaginable changes during Goya's lifetime, as well as unspeakable suffering, privation and violence. As he progressed, he became increasingly an intrepid explorer of two limitless realms: the expressive potential of art and the complex, conflicted nature of the human animal. 
This encompassing view of humankind included quite a bit of womankind. In fact, it could be argued that no artist before Goya portrayed women in as many different roles and circumstances, and with as much psychological complexity. This premise is convincingly illuminated by "Goya: Images of Women," an extraordinary exhibition at the National Gallery of Art here. 
From queens to murderers to murder victims, from laundresses and prostitutes to hoary celestinas (procuresses) and witches, Goya depicted women often throughout his career. It undoubtedly helped that he lived in a period when women were becoming more independent and more visible in society. But he also seems to have liked and respected women more than most men of his time did. One of his closest friends, most important patrons and a possible lover was the strong-willed, impossibly beautiful, eccentric Duchess of Alba, whose body may have been the model for Goya's most famous painting, "Naked Maja." 
In addition there was his relentless curiosity: about male and female, rich and poor, young and old, good and bad. It was all part of the mix, as was the deformed race of gnomes, mutants and demons he devised to vent his despair. Occasionally these worlds collided. In one of the "Caprichos" engravings, the Duchess herself is carried aloft by three hurtling goblins, and it is hard to know who is taking whom where, or why.
"Goya: Images of Women" includes 133 works spanning the late 1770's to the mid-1820's; it is almost a retrospective. Organized with the Prado Museum in Madrid, it includes several paintings that have never been on this continent. The exhibition has a tremendous sweep. It begins with Goya's first days in Madrid, as an aspiring young painter from Aragon who was lucky enough to land a position painting tapestry cartoons for the royal workshops.
The tapestry cartoons, which dominate the show's first two galleries, reveal that nearly from the start Goya had a keen grasp of the world's workings and more than an inkling of its tragedies. In some, he perpetuates the lighthearted frivolities of Rococo -- the ladies in rustling silks, the lap dogs, the feathery trees and sunny skies. With their rich but light palettes, these works can be great fun, especially seen side by side, as they often are here, with the resulting tapestries. 
But "The Crockery Vendor" is almost Cecil B. DeMille in its scope, with the full range of society teeming beneath its sparkling sky.
The cloistered park has given way to a market at the edge of town -- the only dog here is curled up on the dirt -- and the air is alive with fleeting vignettes, exchanges and uncertainties. The stacked china on the blanket conjures up abrupt changes in fortunes; the figures in the background suggest a certain chaos; and the rooflines of the city, thrown into silhouette by the sunlight, at first resemble ruins. The precariousness of life is evident.
The tapestry cartoons established Goya's reputation and his career as an ambitious portraitist -- first of Spanish royalty, then of the aristocracy and finally of individuals who were, like him, well-off members of the bourgeoisie, sometimes his friends. 
The cartoons had made him practiced in rendering rich satins and patterned silks (which the weavers often elaborated upon), but female power had so far been mostly metaphorical, as in the cartoon of four women tossing a male manikin on a blanket. The commissions brought him in contact with real women with real power.
They also sharpened his attention -- and his awareness of his sitters' attention -- to the pleasures and codes of Spanish fashion, a micro-battlefield of English, French and nationalist tendencies, changing social mores, economic realities and political stances.
The confluence of many of these forces is exemplified by the costume of the Maja, favored by the Duchess of Alba. Inspired by gypsy dress, its tight waist, trim open jacket and towering mantilla were a way for upper-class and aristocratic women to flout social convention. In addition, especially during the French occupation, Maja garb became a statement of national pride, not unlike the Scottish tartan.
Goya's skills at depicting breath-taking finery is exemplified by his portrait of the Marchioness of Pontejos, which shows her decked out in a confection of ribbons and bows. But the face framed by such finery is grave and assessing, and this gaze is encountered many times throughout the exhibition. It is evident in the 1795 portrait of the gently aging, quietly commanding Marchioness of Villafranca, the Duchess of Alba's mother-in-law, and in the family portrait of the Duke of Osuna and his family, dominated by the duchess holding a letter, an attribute of executive authority.
Not that Goya's aristocratic women were always so dignified. His 1804 portrait of the next, much younger Marchioness of Villafranca, who was an artist and is shown painting her husband, is stiff and doll-like; her husband, visible in the unfinished portrait beside her, is eerily real. Nor did formality always prevail. His immense, cinnamon-colored group portrait "The Family of the Infante Don Luis" centers on the young wife. She is seated, looking sadly out toward us, wearing a housedress while being tended by her hairdresser.
The exhibition also attends to Goya's all-important uncommissioned works, which began with the small "cabinet paintings" of the mid-1790's, when he was recovering from a nearly fatal illness that left him deaf. We sense the liberating effects in a tiny picture of the Duchess of Alba, which shows her from the back (extremely rare for aristocrats) as she playfully torments her old servant, called "la Beata," with a tiny piece of coral meant to ward off witches. 
The cabinet paintings came to cover an increasingly harrowing range of subjects -- the chained inmates of mental asylums, for example. Among the most painful ones here are two set in black caves: one shows a brigand stripping a woman, the other shows her being stabbed after being raped. The cabinet paintings led to a raft of sketchbooks and studies from life (many of the Duchess of Alba). Their influence culminated in the searing, often brutal images of the "Caprichos" and in "The Disasters of War," the portfolios of engravings unpublished until 1863, decades after his Goya's death.
Women populate these famous images as heroines, victims and empty-headed coquettes. They are also villains or simply vilified. One of the most powerful drawings in the show is the ink study titled 'Dream. Of Witches . . . Running an Errand." It shows a naked woman on a broomstick abducting a scrawny, naked old man -- toward sin, or hell, one assumes -- aided by a mob of demons depicted in sharp, scratched lines that fill the sky. In one print, Goya returns to the theme of the women tossing the manikin with the blanket, only now there are several manikins and they are accompanied by a donkey.
The show even includes tiny (very tiny) hints of the haunting "Black Paintings," which Goya painted during his final days in self-imposed exile in France. These come in the form of small images rubbed into ivory covered with carbon, with added touches of watercolor. The technique gives an apparitional transparency to close-up views of a Maja and her celestina, and especially the gaunt, animated faces of a monk talking to an old woman. 
Shakespeare put the complexity of the human psyche on paper, describing a full range of psychological neuroses several centuries before Freud. Rembrandt painted the essential pain of the human condition with a new sense of depth, most emphatically in his self-portraits. Goya did a little bit of both. His sensitivity was not concentrated on himself; it turned outward like a big spotlight on life, all 360 degrees of it. He extended pain to the whole world, and gave it legs -- that is, a sense of plot, of cause and effect, of everyday truth and consequences.
His work teaches that in art the relief of pain, however temporary, lies in form; that oppressive subject matter can be balanced by the mode of depiction. In the small paintings of murder and rape, chevrons of burning white light cut through the black caves, broadcasting a sense of both alarm and warmth that far exceeds their size. Perhaps the most important of Goya's many lessons was that art can mirror the nightmare of life in its imagery, while mitigating it with the liberty and optimism of its very pictorial nature.
Goya's consciousness was in some ways a product of England, the most democratic of the European monarchies, and it is interesting to consider him in conjunction with two other artists whose work bookends his: Hogarth and Turner. Goya replayed Hogarth's sharply tuned farce as tragedy, aided by a sensitivity to the human face and form that would be matched by Turner's uncanny grasp of the nuances of light and atmosphere. Like Turner, Goya found chaos at the furthest extremes of his subject, although nature's force was somehow less terrible than the horrors people unleashed upon one another.

"Goya: Images of Women" remains at the National Gallery of Art, Fourth Street and Constitution Avenue NW, Washington, (202) 842-6353, through June 2.

HEADLINE: Rebound Helps Gucci Beat the Pessimistic Expectations 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 21 

 BODY:
There will always be someone who just has to have the latest Gucci handbag or a slinky little number from Yves Saint Laurent -- or so went the message from the company behind those products today, as it reported much better results for 2001 than analysts had expected.
 In theory, the global economic slowdown and the terror attacks of Sept. 11 should have dampened the appetites of even the most ardent followers of fashion. But the company, the Gucci Group, managed to increase its sales and post earnings that handily exceeded forecasts. The company also reported progress in resuscitating Yves Saint Laurent, the battered fashion brand that it bought in 1999 for $1 billion. 
 Gucci did not get through the tough climate of the last six months wholly unscathed; no luxury goods company was immune. LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the giant of the field, avoided a loss for the year only through capital gains on the sale of a block of Gucci stock it received in a settlement of a long takeover battle.
Gucci said today that its profits fell to $278.4 million for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 from $336.7 million the year before. Per-share earnings were $2.74, 13 cents more than the consensus forecast. Revenue grew 1.2 percent, to $2.3 billion.
"People had been prepared for something worse," said Simon Raggett of the Williams de Broe brokerage firm in London. "Rather than making the numbers from profits on investments, it is through the core business."
Domenico De Sole, Gucci's chief executive, spoke cautiously of the company's near-term prospects, warning that it might be a while before business really rebounded. The company expects sales at the core Gucci division to rise modestly in the current year.
"The United States economy is heating up," Mr. De Sole said in an interview. "But for us it will take a little time. Hawaii, for instance, is dependent on Japanese tourism, and that has not come back yet."
In spite of the difficult market environment, the company said, operating margins at the Gucci division widened slightly, and losses at Yves Saint Laurent narrowed.
"It is always a good surprise to see turnarounds exceeding expectations," said Scilla Huang Sun of Clariden Bank in Zurich, which owns some Gucci shares. "Normally it is the opposite."
Yves Saint Laurent lost $67.9 million for the year; the company had forecast a $75 million loss. And the signs remain positive: revenue for Rive Gauche, the ready-to-wear line, rose 218 percent, to 110 million euros ($97 million), in the six weeks ended March 16, in part because of the introduction of accessories like the Mombasa, an African-inspired handbag with a horn handle, for $595.
"We are further ahead than most people thought we would be with YSL," Mr. De Sole said. "It reminds us of Gucci in 1995, when every day sales were doubling."
Mr. De Sole and Tom Ford, the company's creative director, are trying the same formula on Yves Saint Laurent that they used to reinvigorate Gucci. They are cutting loose from unprofitable licensing agreements and setting trends with must-have items like a $1,575 black cotton off-the-shoulder peasant blouse that has been widely copied. If it works, the company's stable of fledgling brands -- including Bottega Veneta, Stella McCartney, Alexander McQueen and Boucheron -- will get the treatment next, a process that will take time and money.
For now, investors seem convinced that Gucci's customers will keep shopping. Its American depository receipts rose 1.8 percent today, to $92.50. "Gucci has proven to be very strong," Ms. Huang Sun said, "even in difficult economic times."

HEADLINE: Medicare Needs Fixing 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 "Many Doctors Shun Patients With Medicare" (front page, March 19) exposes a growing threat to our ability to provide quality care for older Americans. Physicians want to care for our nation's elderly, but too many are finding the financial losses unsustainable. 
Physicians face Medicare payment cuts of nearly 20 percent over four years. At the same time, they are dealing with sharp increases in their practice expenses, including skyrocketing liability insurance premiums in many states. 
 At the heart of the problem is a flawed Medicare payment formula that defies logic and ignores economic reality. We strongly support the Medicare Physician Payment Fairness Act, which tackles the immediate Medicare payment cut problem and rejects the flawed formula. This bill has overwhelming bipartisan support. Congress must act now so our nation's elderly can continue to rely on Medicare for the care they need.

TIMOTHY T. FLAHERTY, M.D.
Chairman
American Medical Association
Chicago, March 19, 2002

HEADLINE: Retail Prices Rise 0.2%; Other Indexes Largely Flat 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose in February for a second consecutive month and fewer workers sought unemployment benefits, according to one measure, offering additional evidence that the economy is growing and that higher interest rates are possible. 
 The Consumer Price Index, the most widely watched gauge of inflation, rose 0.2 percent in February, reflecting higher prices for housing, food and clothing, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. 
 Excluding food and energy prices, the Consumer Price Index rose 0.3 percent, slightly higher than the 0.2 percent economists expected. Energy prices fell 0.8 percent in February after rising 0.9 percent in January. Food prices edged up 0.2 percent after rising 0.3 percent. 
Some companies may want to raise prices and increase profits, but economists said that increases would be restrained by competition, low-price imports and expectations that there would not be much pent-up demand from consumers who have kept buying through the economic slump. 
While the rise in consumer prices was expected and aroused little worry that inflation was becoming a threat, it somewhat increased expectations that the Federal Reserve would raise rates in the months ahead. "My best guess is that the Fed will start to raise rates, but cautiously," said Oscar Gonzalez, economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston.
The Conference Board reported today that another barometer of economic activity, the index of leading economic indicators, held steady in February after four months of gains.
The Conference Board, a private research group based in New York, said the index remained steady at 112.4 after a revised 0.8 percent increase in January. Analysts had forecast a 0.1 percent gain. The index tries to measure where the overall economy is headed in three to six months.
Economists said they were not worried about February's flat performance in light of the gains in previous months. The index rose 0.8 percent in November and 1.3 percent in December. "The economy is recovering but is still fragile," said Mark Zandi of Economy.com in West Chester, Pa.
In still another report, the Labor Department said the number of first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell by 12,000 in the week ended March 16, to a seasonally adjusted 371,000, which was below Wall Street expectations. The four-week moving average of jobless claims, considered a more reliable measure because it irons out weekly fluctuations, edged up to 379,000 from 376,500, but remained under the 400,000 level that some economists regard as recession territory.

HEADLINE: Universities Report Record In Private Contributions 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Despite an economic downturn and a choppy stock market, contributions to American colleges and universities rose to a record in the year that ended on June 30, according to a study to be released today by the Rand Corporation Council for Aid to Education.
 Giving to institutions of higher education by foundations, individuals and corporations increased by $1 billion in the year, to $24.2 billion, confounding Rand researchers and others who had worried that philanthropy had slowed sharply. 
 Although the amount was a record in absolute dollar terms, the rate of increase in giving did slow, to 4.3 percent from 13.7 percent a year earlier.
"It wasn't a banner year," said Ann E. Kaplan, the survey director, "but it was still a lot better than it might have been." 
Contributions from foundations accounted for much of the increase, reflecting huge growth in foundation assets over the last four years. Foundation giving to higher education grew 18.1 percent, to $6 billion, according to the survey, which reflects reports from 85 percent of colleges and universities in the United States.
"I expected growth in giving by foundations to be there, but I didn't expect it to be nearly as high as it was," Ms. Kaplan said. "There was so much bad news in the stock market, especially during that fiscal period, with the Standard & Poor's index, the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq all down."
After religious organizations, educational institutions receive the most charity.
Harvard University, which pulled in $683 million in contributions in the last school year, returned to its position as the biggest fund-raiser, pushing Stanford University, the top fund-raiser the previous year, into second place, with $469 million. Columbia University ranked third, raising $359 million.
"Last year was our eighth record year of growth in a row," the president of Columbia, George Rupp, said. 
Nine years ago, when Mr. Rupp arrived, fund-raising brought in $116 million.
A $105 million grant from the Lilly Endowment vaulted Indiana University into first place among public universities, at $301 million. Lilly has a $15.6 billion endowment as of Dec. 31, 2000, the last date for which audited figures are available. 
The donation was the biggest single grant in Lilly history and reflects the robust fortunes of foundations over the last several years. Foundations now account for one-quarter of contributions to higher education and are fast closing the gap with the largest group of donors, alumni.
Alumni contributions were basically flat at $6.83 billion, and donations from individuals who are not alumni fell 4.1 percent, to $5.2 billion. Corporate support grew 4.8 percent, to $4.35 billion.
Before the Indiana grant, Lilly's biggest outlay was $60 million to the United Way of Central Indiana in 1999. It also granted the Hispanic Scholarship Fund $50 million that year, and in 1998, it gave the United Way $50 million. The growing size of the foundation was cited as a big reason for the trend in Lilly's giving.
"Just to give you an idea of what's behind that, in 1996 the asset value was $6.8 billion," a spokeswoman for Lilly, Gretchen Wolfram, said. "In 1997, it was $12.7 billion." 
All those grants were record-setters when given. According the Foundation Center, foundation assets doubled from 1996 to 2000, and because foundations have to donate at least 5 percent of their assets to retain their tax exemptions, giving grew, too. Even though foundation assets have shrunk somewhat because of weakness in the stock market and the economy, the giving continues apace. 
"Typically, as foundation endowments grow, giving will increase, but at a slower pace," said Steven Lawrence, research director at the Foundation Center. "It's only over time that giving catches up to the growth."
Ms. Kaplan cautioned that the line between foundations and individuals was blurring, as more families establish foundations. The council has been asking universities to break out family foundations for four years, and she estimated that 20 percent of the foundation dollars in the last four years came from those sources. 
"This is an important point to make about personal giving over all," she said. "Each year, more and more of it is filtered through organizations such as foundations, charitable gift funds and the like."
Emory University is a case in point. The university, in Atlanta, leaped into the ranks of the top 10 fund-raisers because of a large donation from a family foundation that requested anonymity. The university cannot divulge the sum, but reports have put it at up to $150 million.
Emory raised $298 million in the year, compared to its normal average of $100 million to $125 million.
"We received some remarkable gifts from a number of individuals and foundations," said William H. Fox, an Emory official. "I wish I could say we would do that well every year, but I would be dishonest if I did."

HEADLINE: Bush Seeks $27 Billion Emergency Fund 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
The Bush administration asked Congress today for $27 billion in emergency funds to strengthen domestic security, rebuild New York and wage the war on terrorism, including plans to expand that conflict beyond Afghanistan.
 More than half the money, $14 billion, would go to the Pentagon, mostly to pay for military operations in Afghanistan, where the United States has stationed more than 4,000 troops and continues to fly scores of combat air patrols daily. The request indicates the White House does not expect war costs to taper off from their current rate of more than $2 billion a month. 
 President Bush's proposal includes $5.6 billion in aid to New York, fulfilling Mr. Bush's pledge to give the city at least $20 billion to help rebuild from the attack on the World Trade Center. 
The size of the request generated grumbling among Democrats on Capitol Hill who said it would increase the deficit and take money from domestic programs. But it is likely to draw broad support from both parties in Congress.
"My most important job as your president is to protect Americans from any attack," Mr. Bush said today in El Paso as he was traveling to Mexico. "I expect the United States Congress to honor my request for this important reason: any time we put a U.S. soldier into harm's way, we expect that soldier to have the best equipment, the best training, an additional pay raise."
The $14 billion request for the Pentagon, intended to last through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30, comes on top of $17.5 billion allocated to the military late last year for emergency war costs. Between Sept. 11 and Jan. 30, the Pentagon estimates it spent $11.8 billion for waging war in Afghanistan and flying air patrols over American cities.
Most of the $14 billion would go for basic military costs, including fuel, spare parts, ammunition and salaries for the 80,000 National Guard and reserve troops who have been activated since Sept. 11. But the plan also requests more than $150 million to speed up development of experimental weapon systems that performed well in Afghanistan, possibly including unmanned aircraft, Pentagon officials said.
The plan includes $5.2 billion for domestic security programs, most of which would go to the new Transportation Security Administration to improve screening at airports.
It also provides more than $1 billion in aid to countries identified as major allies in the war on terrorism, including Afghanistan, Pakistan, Turkey, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Yemen, Oman and the Philippines. 
The assistance to New York includes $2.7 billion to reimburse the city for overtime costs and cleanup of the World Trade Center site; $1.8 billion to rebuild the subway and PATH lines in Lower Manhattan and $750 million to reconstruct Con Edison and Verizon facilities.
"From what I can tell, the president is living up to his commitment to New York," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, who with Gov. George E. Pataki of New York lobbied the White House for the additional money.
Included in the spending request is a provision that would authorize the Pentagon to train Colombian military units in counterterrorism, lifting a Congressional restriction.
American military units are already working with the Colombian government to fight drug trafficking, but the Bush administration contends that there is significant overlap between drug smugglers and antigovernment guerrillas and that training should therefore reflect that problem.
Though it is likely to receive broad bipartisan support, the president's request is sure to be closely scrutinized by Democrats, particularly in the Senate, where the chairman of the Appropriations Committee, Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, has signaled that he intends to question the administration closely over its war-fighting and spending plans. 
Democrats also criticized the administration today for having blocked their efforts last fall to appropriate money for many of the same purposes, especially for domestic security programs, on the grounds that the president, not Congress, should set spending levels for the campaign against terrorism. 
"After Sept. 11, Democrats begged the president to support bipartisan legislation to enact much of this additional security funding immediately," said David J. Sirota, a spokesman for Democrats on the House Appropriations Committee. "Instead, the White House played politics and forced an unnecessary and dangerous delay."
In the House, the spending bill will probably become enmeshed in a separate issue, Mr. Bush's urgent request that Congress raise the legal limit on the national debt. The Treasury Department is already scrambling to avoid breaching the current limit, which is $5.95 trillion. 
But many Republicans in the House are reluctant to vote for an increase in the debt after campaigning on pledges to reduce it. So Republican leaders have signaled that they will attach the debt-level increase to the military spending bill to give their members political cover. 
If Congress gives Mr. Bush the full $27.1 billion he is seeking, it would leave the government with a deficit this year in the range of $70 billion, assuming that most of the $27.1 billion is actually spent by the end of the fiscal year.
But some of the spending could spill over into next year, putting further pressure on the budget deficit. The two parties are already battling over who is to blame for the reappearance of budget deficits. On Wednesday, the House approved a $2.1 trillion Republican budget plan for next year that would yield a deficit of about $80 billion using economic and technical assumptions developed by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.
Today the Senate Budget Committee approved, on a 12-to-10 party line vote, a Democratic budget resolution that would result in a $92 billion deficit next year. 
The Democratic plan would meet Mr. Bush's spending requests for the military and domestic security for next year, but would add money for education and health spending while promising to reduce the national debt more over the next decade than the House Republican plan.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Chief Acknowledges 'Debate' on Global Crossing Deals

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
The chief executive of Global Crossing acknowledged to a House panel today that "there is now a debate" as to whether disclosures about some transactions by the company "may in some fashion have misled the market."
 But the company's executives defended their business practices, saying that the deals in question, in which the company swapped fiber optic capacity with other telecommunications companies, did not cause Global Crossing's collapse and were accurately disclosed. The swap deals are a focus of investigations by federal prosecutors and the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 Shares of Global Crossing, one of the largest stock market highfliers in the technology boom years, have dropped from a high of more than $60 two years ago to pennies today. The company sought bankruptcy protection in January, citing the soft economy and a huge debt load. With lawmakers preoccupied with inquiries into Enron, Congress has not focused on Global Crossing until now. But the company faces many of the same accusations as Enron, including charges of improper accounting and the enrichment of executives as other employees lost millions. 
The specific swap transactions at issue are contemporaneous back-and-forth purchases and sales of "indefeasible rights of use" -- ironclad contracts that allow one carrier to use capacity on the other carrier's network for long periods to carry calls, data or video transmissions.
Investigators are examining whether these were honest transactions or sham deals that allowed Global Crossing to inflate its revenue significantly. In written testimony submitted today to the subcommittee on oversight and investigations of the House Financial Services Committee, the company's chief executive, John J. Legere, and its chief financial officer, Dan J. Cohrs, said there were "fewer than two dozen" of these deals in 2000 and 2001.
"Neither these transactions nor our accounting for them have anything to do with the telecommunication industry's -- or our company's -- difficulties," they said.
They acknowledged, however, that "there is now a debate as to whether the disclosures concerning these transactions may in some fashion have misled the market." They noted that the company's board was reviewing the deals with the company's lawyers and auditors, examining in particular "their business justification as well as the manner in which revenue and expenses were recorded and disclosed."
Today, some lawmakers said it appeared that the company's disclosures were improper.
Representative Sue W. Kelly, a New York Republican who is chairwoman of the subcommittee, sharply criticized Global Crossing's use of "pro forma" financial statements, which she said may have "misinformed investors and employees" by "pumping up earnings by nearly 50 percent as a result of controversial swaps activities."
"It appears that swaps are being used as a quick and easy way to inflate earnings and make a company look more profitable than it really is," Ms. Kelly said.
Representative John J. LaFalce of New York, the ranking Democrat on the full committee, said it was not clear whether Global Crossing had "engaged in fraudulent accounting practices." But he said "there are certainly very serious questions as to whether it engaged in practices that had far more to do with meeting analysts' earnings estimates than with economic substance."
The Financial Services Committee called the hearing today as part of its study of what new accounting and financial disclosure laws are needed in the aftermath of the collapse of Enron, and now, Global Crossing. The committee also heard testimony today from senior executives of WorldCom and Qwest Communications International, whose own accounting has come under scrutiny amid the sharp downturn in the telecommunications industry.
Generally, the executives said that accounting concerns were not the primary source of the industry's troubles. Instead, they cited huge overcapacity, softness in the economy and what some suggested was the failure of federal regulators to create a marketplace where competitive telecommunications companies could prosper.
Scrutiny of Global Crossing may now shift to the House Energy and Commerce Committee. Its chairman, Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, is demanding extensive records of the swap contracts.

HEADLINE: Fed Weighed a Shift in January 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
At its first meeting this year the Federal Reserve decided to leave interest rates unchanged, halting an aggressive string of rate cuts. Members expressed surprise at how strong economic growth appeared to be, according to minutes of the meeting released today. 
 Fed policy makers also discussed shifting their statement of possible future actions to a neutral stance, but made no change because of concerns about disrupting markets. 
 The group of Fed board members and regional bank presidents, which meets eight times a year to set interest rates, voted 10 to 0 at its Jan. 29-30 session to keep rates steady. 
The Federal Open Market Committee cut rates 11 times in 2001, first in a failed effort to prevent a recession and then after Sept. 11 to bolster an economy shaken by the terrorist attacks. While the Fed in December was still concerned about a deepening downturn, policy makers showed more optimism in January, the minutes show. 
"Members commented that the recent information was more positive than they had anticipated and seemed on the whole to indicate that economic activity was bottoming out and a recovery might already be under way," the minutes show. 
The committee supported the decision to leave the federal funds rate, the interest rate that banks charge each other, at a 40-year low of 1.75 percent. 
The minutes did show there was a split about whether the Fed should change the part of its statement indicating what the committee considered the greatest risks facing the economy in the future. 
In the end, the group did not alter the wording of the statement -- that economic weakness rather than the threat of higher inflation posed the greatest risks.

HEADLINE: More Entreaties in Monterrey for More Aid to the Poor 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 21 

 BODY:
World leaders implored rich nations today to give far more aid to the poor, warning that grinding poverty converts needy countries into incubators for terrorism and chaos.
 "No one in this world can feel comfortable or safe while so many are suffering and deprived," said Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general. He called poverty and inequality the greatest threats to world peace. 
 Doubling development aid to the world's poorest nations and halving global poverty by 2015 are among the aims of the United Nations conference here, where more than 50 presidents and prime ministers have gathered this week. 
The meeting, which ends Friday, has already pushed the United States to promise billions in new aid, reversing its post-cold-war policies. The European Union has pledged billions as well. But their promises would provide no more than one-quarter of the $50 billion a year in new funds Mr. Annan seeks.
The conference has also compelled the leaders of the World Bank, the World Trade Organization and the International Monetary Fund, gathered together for the first time, to address the poor in terms rarely associated with high finance. The W.T.O.'s director, Mike Moore, called global poverty "a time bomb lodged against the heart of liberty."
Above all, Mr. Annan said, the conference would increase and "maintain the pressure on our leaders and politicians" to find more ways to aid 2.5 billion people living on $2 a day or less.
"Two weeks ago no one was even thinking about an increase," said the World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn. Today the United States and Europe are "prepared to write checks," he said. "That's not a Hollywood step, that's a real step."
This morning, Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, opened the day's session by calling the world's efforts on behalf of the poor to date "meager, tardy and disheartening."
The president of the United Nations General Assembly, Han Seung Soo, quoting the Mexican poet, Octavio Paz, said the richest nations could no longer afford to be "islands of abundance in an ocean of universal misery." The consequence, he said, would be the poorest nations becoming "the breeding ground for violence."
Then Peru's president, Alejandro Toledo, took the stage. Hours earlier, a car bomb had exploded in front of the United States Embassy in Lima, Peru's capital, killing nine people.
"Poverty conspires against democracy," he said. "Global security is inextricably linked with the health of the world economy," and helping the poor is inseparable from "a strong and determined fight against terrorism."
King Abdullah of Jordan, an important American ally in the Arab world, called poor nations "breeding grounds for conflict" between "Western haves and worldwide have-nots."
The weapons for a "victory over terror," he said, must include financial aid from rich nations.
Mr. Bush has not drawn quite so direct a link between economic suffering and political rage.
"Poverty doesn't cause terrorism," he said last week in announcing that he would increase the foreign aid budget by 50 percent bringing it to $15 billion by 2006.
Mr. Bush arrived here this evening on Air Force One and headed immediately into a 45-minute meeting with Mr. Fox and Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said the leaders talked about border security and trade. Tonight Mr. Bush was attending a reception for heads of state. On Friday he is to deliver a speech on American foreign aid followed in the evening by a news conference with Mr. Fox.
The Bush administration has said, and most of the Monterrey conferees agree, that increased development aid should flow only to deserving nations that will spend the aid wisely. Europe has promised roughly $20 billion in aid spending over the same period. Still, those sums far fall short of what the Monterrey conference says is needed. 
Foreign aid dropped off sharply after the cold war ended. Many governments believed that globalization and the increased flow of capital and trade across international borders had greater benefits than official loans and grants. But the Monterrey conferees, with the exception of a very few, say that trade cannot supplant aid.
Some of the most fierce critics of the wealthy world at their conference today were its own leaders. Guy Verhofstadt, the prime minister of Belgium, said today that "the collective selfishness of the rich world" has contributed to "the despair of hundreds of millions of people -- alone, dispossessed, powerless."
But fiercest of all was Fidel Castro of Cuba, dressed in battle fatigues, whose short but scathing critique of the world powers assembled before him led the American contingent to walk out of the closed conference hall.
"The world economy today is a huge casino," Mr. Castro said, run by the self-appointed "masters of the world," whose "traditional offers of assistance, always scant and often ridiculous, are either inadequate or unfulfilled."
Mr. Castro departed before President Bush's arrival, saying "a special situation created by my participation in this summit obligates me to immediately return" to Cuba. Officials said Mr. Castro may have taken offense at remarks by Mr. Bush's aides, who had said in no uncertain terms this week that the two men would not meet at Monterrey -- publicly, privately or accidentally.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Among those meeting in Monterrey yesterday were, left, Secretary General Kofi Annan and James D. Wolfensohn of the World Bank. Mexico's leader, Vicente Fox, right, and his wife, Marta Sahagun, looked on. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Doctors Face A Big Jump In Insurance 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Doctors in the New York area face sharp increases in their medical malpractice insurance costs, which are already among the highest in the country.
 Insurance rate increases, most of them ranging from 10 to 40 percent, are already taking effect in New Jersey and Connecticut. In New York State, a majority of doctors are likely to pay at least 20 percent more in premiums over the next year. Those premiums are already substantial; for obstetricians and neurosurgeons, they can run to more than $100,000 annually. 
 The increases are being driven by larger jury awards and settlements for medical mistakes, as well as by the insurance companies' poor earnings on investments during the weak economy. 
Higher malpractice insurance rates are likely to add to rising health care costs, although managed care has limited doctors' ability to pass along their higher expenses. Beyond that, rising malpractice rates have caused some doctors to quit practicing or to practice medicine defensively, ordering extra tests or choosing procedures that limit their risks. 
"The situation is very ominous," said Gerry Conway, the director of government affairs for the New York State Medical Society. "Increases like this cannot be absorbed by physicians."
In New Jersey, some doctors, especially those with a record of being sued, are struggling to find coverage at any price, as some insurers try to reduce their risk and others pull out of the business entirely.
Costs for doctors in states like Pennsylvania, West Virginia, Mississippi and Florida have been soaring for two or three years, but until now, premiums in New York and neighboring states had been rising only modestly. 
Doctors say they feel trapped. "The medical malpractice insurance companies want more premium while the H.M.O. companies and Medicare are decreasing their payments to doctors," said Dr. Ruth J. Schulze, an obstetrician and gynecologist in Ridgewood, N.J.
Dr. Schulze, who is also the president-elect of the Bergen County Medical Society, said two of the six doctors in her group had quit delivering babies to save on insurance costs.
To renew the coverage for Dr. Schulze's group this year, Zurich Insurance asked for a nearly 90 percent increase in premiums to $382,984. After several weeks of negotiations with two other companies, she said, the group was able to get $2 million in coverage for each of the six doctors for $227,400, a 20 percent increase and $77,400 more than the group pays annually for rent and utilities for its offices.
One factor that may work to keep the rates lower in New York is the gubernatorial race. Gov. George E. Pataki, and many other political figures, would like to avoid raising rates and that might bring angry protests. The problem is that the companies will have a hard time functioning without a rate increase. 
Prices across the country are rising at an annual average of 30 percent, according to the Medical Liability Monitor in Chicago, but some increases are much higher. 
"This is a problem that month by month is getting worse across the whole country," said Richard F. Corlin, the president of the American Medical Association.
The association and the insurers say the crux of the problem is the ballooning cost of awards to victims of medical errors. Between 1995 and 2000, for example, the average jury award jumped more than 70 percent to $3.5 million, and a few claims in 2000 even ran to more than $40 million, according to Jury Verdict Research in Horsham, Pa.
The association and the insurers have begun lobbying Washington and state legislatures for tort reforms to limit awards for pain and suffering to $250,000, a standard adopted in California in the mid-70's that insurers say has helped keep costs there manageable. 
"Everybody is suing doctors because they are not getting absolute positive results every time," said Dr. Sultan Ahamed, the chairman of the Connecticut Medical Insurance Company and a board member of the Connecticut State Medical Society. 
The problem, however, goes far beyond big jury awards. To a large extent, it was created by fierce competition by many insurers for new customers, industry experts said. Driven to keep pace with health care groups that were expanding across the nation in the mid-90's, many of the insurers moved into new territories as well, said James Hurley, an actuary for Tillinghast, an insurance consulting firm. Flush with earlier profits, executives of the companies were also bent on building bigger businesses, said David O. Lewis, an insurance analyst at SunTrust Robinson Humphrey in Atlanta.
To win customers in new territories, the insurers underpriced their rivals, and, as a result, many sold coverage for less than the ultimate cost of claims. Then, as lawsuit costs rose and investment earnings dwindled, the insurers began using reserves of money they had built up during profitable years in the late 1980's and early 1990's, said Blair Sanford, an insurance analyst at Cochran, Caronia Securities in San Francisco. Now those reserves are gone.
The biggest malpractice insurer in New York, the Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company, and the biggest one in Connecticut, the Connecticut Medical Insurance Company, were both founded by doctors and operate as co-ops with their doctor-owners as shareholders. They have resisted a national trend among similar doctor-founded insurance companies to restructure as public companies and issue stock. Because their doctor-owners were their only shareholders, they were under less pressure to expand in search of greater profits. But even without joining the cost-cutting frenzy, they are now reporting losses.
As losses among the insurers have been growing, several have collapsed or abandoned their customers to save themselves. The biggest commercial insurer in malpractice coverage, for example, the St. Paul Companies, announced late last year that it was getting out of the business, leaving 42,000 doctors around the country to scramble for coverage. 
The biggest insurer of doctors in Pennsylvania, the Phico Group, was taken over by regulators last year, as was the Frontier Insurance company in upstate New York.
Just last month, in New Jersey, the MIIX Group reported losses for 2001 of $157.6 million, which cut its net worth in half. That prompted talks with regulators on a new business plan and a rating downgrade by the A. M. Best Company, the insurance rating agency, to a level below the minimum required by many health care organizations.
Patricia A. Costante, MIIX's chief executive, said that following a plan worked out with regulators, the insurer was pulling out of 21 states and would concentrate on New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Delaware and Maryland. "MIIX is clearly experiencing difficult problems now," she said, "but when you look at the medical malpractice industry as a whole, companies are really struggling to regain their footing."

HEADLINE: Meeting on Indian Point's Fate Draws Overflow Crowd From Both Sides 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, March 21 

 BODY:
In a sign of the growing frustration here, more than 700 people jammed into the Westchester County Center tonight for a public meeting on whether the Indian Point nuclear complex should remain open after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 So many turned out that the meeting room was packed, and the overflow crowd of about 200 was relegated to the lobby downstairs. They clapped and chanted to be let in. 
 The crowd upstairs was generally orderly, but broke into loud boos at times to drown out speakers who took the microphone. Many residents and environmentalists pointed to safety lapses at Indian Point and demanded that it be shut down, while many plant workers and others defended the nuclear operations and rattled off their economic benefits. 
"I want to show support for my livelihood, and for a plant that is vital to the economic vitality of this state," said Stephen McGuire, 39, an engineer at the Indian Point 3 unit.
But Maura Costello, 36, a mother of three in Yorktown, said she had grave concerns not only about the safety of Indian Point but also about whether families could be safely evacuated in case of a disaster. "I don't sleep at night thinking about what could happen," she said.
The meeting was the latest in a series of public events that have been held around the county in recent months to address widespread concerns about the two active nuclear plants (a third is currently not in operation) in Buchanan, about 35 miles north of Midtown Manhattan. But unlike some earlier events, tonight's meeting seemed to be roughly divided between supporters and opponents, with neither side seeming to have the upper hand.
Two committees of the Westchester County Board of Legislators held the meeting to discuss two proposed resolutions. One called for closing and decommissioning Indian Point and, if possible, converting it to natural gas or alternative fuel operation. The other urged an evaluation of Indian Point's emergency plan by an independent group outside the government. The resolutions are expected to be voted on in the next month.
But even if county legislators adopt the more forceful resolution calling for the closing of Indian Point, it would be largely symbolic. Though it would be a first for Westchester, the Rockland County Legislature and many towns and villages in both counties have passed similar resolutions, with little effect.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, the federal agency that oversees Indian Point, has approved its operations, though the commission has also given it the highest scrutiny of any nuclear plant in the country because of recent mishaps there.
Michael B. Kaplowitz, the county legislator who proposed the Westchester resolution, said he hoped tonight's hearing would increase pressure on federal officials and others to close the nuclear operations and convert the site to something safer. "When a little snowball starts down the side of a mountain, once it has momentum, it gets bigger and bigger," he said. "I think this is a mainstream, soccer-mom issue now." 
The Entergy Corporation, which owns Indian Point, has maintained that its operations are safe, and plant workers and others have increasingly mobilized to counter what they call "misinformation" that has alarmed the public. 
Jim Steets, a spokesman for Entergy who attended the hearing, said that shutting down the nuclear operations would displace 1,500 plant workers; cut off a source of 2,000 megawatts of electricity, or enough power for two million homes; and result in a sharp rise in electric rates. He said that converting the site to alternative sources of energy like natural gas would be difficult, costly and impractical.
"The support for this resolution comes from people who've always wanted to shut down the plant, and they see Sept. 11 as a way to finally accomplish that," he said.
Mr. Steets added that he did not object to the resolution calling for an independent evaluation of the emergency plan for Indian Point.

HEADLINE: Italian Terrorists Say They Killed Economist 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: ROME, March 21 

 BODY:
An offshoot of the Red Brigades terror group said today that it was responsible for the shooting death on Tuesday of an Italian economist who was working on bitterly contested changes in Italy's labor laws. The group also said the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States were a model of effective terrorism. 
 A 26-page communique portrayed the slaying of the economist, Marco Biagi, as part of a global struggle against "imperialism." 
 Mr. Biagi, 52, was gunned down Tuesday night outside his home in Bologna by two men on a motorbike. The next day, Italian officials blamed the Red Brigades.
The document claiming responsibility was posted on the Internet.
Regarding the Sept. 11 attacks, the document said the hijackings showed "how it is possible to carry out highly destructive attacks in enemy territory, with destabilizing effects, without the use of technologically advanced weapons."
The communique, signed by the Red Brigades for the Building of the Fighting Communist Party, claimed responsibility for killing Mr. Biagi, a university professor who advocated loosening Italy's labor market, one of the most rigid in Europe. 
In 1999, a group using the same name said it killed Massimo D'Antona, an economist working on labor reform in this country where laws give millions lifetime job security.
The slaying of Mr. Biagi stunned the country, and tens of thousands of people took to the streets on Wednesday to protest political violence.

HEADLINE: Audit Adds to Ovitz's Troubles in Hollywood 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB and ANITA M. BUSCH 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 21 

 BODY:
The film unit of Michael Ovitz's Hollywood management company is facing a potential financial crisis amid growing concerns from a major investor, the Canal Plus Group of France.
 The parent company of Canal Plus, Vivendi Universal, began a routine audit of the film company, the Artists Production Group, in early February that has escalated to a fuller inquiry. At issue is at least $1 million to $2 million allocated for films that may have been used for other expenses. 
 "Money is missing -- the facts are the facts," said one executive engaged in the audit. "We're trying to figure it out." 
The audit of the film division is the latest setback at Mr. Ovitz's firm, the Artists Management Group, which has had a stream of executive departures and has suffered the costly collapse of its television unit.
Jon Vein, the chief operating officer of Artists Management, acknowledged that the audit was being conducted, but said, "Everything was done appropriately and completely above board and in concert with our partner, StudioCanal."
In 2000, Mr. Ovitz's company entered into a three-year venture with the production arm of Canal Plus, StudioCanal, to make 12 to 15 films. No films have been produced under the deal.
Under the agreement, Canal Plus provided $8 million a year to the Artists Production Group, $4 million for development costs and $4 million for overhead.
Development costs would involve acquisitions of properties and payments to screenwriters. The audit was conducted by a financial executive from Vivendi Universal who set up an office inside the Beverly Hills office of Artists Management. Specifically, the executive focused his inquiry on part of the $8 million that was intended to serve as overhead and development costs for the movie division.
The audit came as the future of StudioCanal's American office has come into question. With the merger of USA Networks, run by Barry Diller, and Vivendi Universal three months ago, several executives said that StudioCanal's office could be shut in the United States as the parent company reorganized its many film units. Should the office close, Mr. Ovitz would be forced to find a new investment partner for his film unit. 
Mr. Ovitz, a former talent agent who was once viewed as one of Hollywood's most powerful executives, has had trouble regaining that status since he left his post as president of the Walt Disney Company in 1997 after 14 tempestuous months.
He founded Artists Management in 1999 with two talent managers, Rick Yorn and Julie Silverman-Yorn, hoping to manage entertainers, music stars and athletes, and produce television shows and films. Other than managing stars like Cameron Diaz and Leonardo DiCaprio, Mr. Ovitz's agency has had little to show for its efforts, except the collapse of the television division last year, which led to a $60 million loss, and the shrinkage of its music and sports unit, which led to the departure of several executives. An executive at Artists Management said the company was considering a spinoff of its sports unit. 
The most recent departure was Jill Smoller, a sports manager, who is joining the William Morris Agency next month and taking along several clients, including the tennis players Pete Sampras and Pam Shriver and Rick Fox of the Los Angeles Lakers.
The companies from which Mr. Ovitz unsuccessfully sought financial backing included AT&T and -- before its collapse -- the Enron Corporation, a former executive said. So, it was a success at a crucial moment for Mr. Ovitz when Artists Management forged its film production deal in 2000 with Canal Plus.
Even if Mr. Ovitz loses the French company's financing, which is a possibility, the film company could remain afloat with another partner, like a film studio or another investor. But Mr. Ovitz's previous efforts to lure studios and networks as investors have not succeeded.
Mark Canton, the recently appointed chairman and chief executive of the film unit and a former chairman of Columbia Pictures, said the company had about 20 film projects in various stages of development.
"We are in a uniquely advantageous position," Mr. Canton said, "because of the number of projects we have and the talent we represent. That would make us very attractive for people to want to invest in."
Mr. Canton was brought into the company because of his relationship with actors like Jack Nicholson as well as his experience in the movie business. 
Mr. Canton said the real issue for the Artists Production Group might be the restructuring by Vivendi Universal. He said the management from Vivendi Universal, including Canal Plus and USA Network, had just completed a series of meetings in Deauville, France, to discuss financing strategies for the company and a restructuring. 
Canal Plus declined to comment on its relationship to Mr. Ovitz's company, the audit or whether or not StudioCanal would continue to operate in the United States.
Mr. Vein, the chief operating officer at Artist Management, insisted that the company was not scaling back on its staff, but was actually adding managers. Mr. Ovitz's company has no chief financial officer: the last two have departed. Mr. Vein himself has taken on additional duties that a chief financial officer would normally perform.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow Falls, but Late Buying in Technology Stems the Loss

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped yesterday as investors tried to lock in profits for a second day, selling on concerns about rising interest rates. But some buying late in the day allowed the technology sector to advance and kept the Dow industrials from a triple-digit loss. 
 Analysts said that while investors think the economy is strengthening, they are worried that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates before business fully improves. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 21.73 points, or 0.2 percent, at 10,479.84, a considerable rebound from an earlier loss of 146 points. 
"The bigger picture is that there is recovery in the economy," said Kevin Caron, an associate strategist at Gruntal & Company. "We will see a shift to more positive days than negative days. If the Fed raises rates a point or two it's not going to choke off an expansion." 
The broader market finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 35.96 points, or 2.0 percent, to 1,868.83 after falling 48 points on Wednesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 1.74 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,153.59. 
Selling was strong early in the session because of worries about higher interest rates; the Fed hinted at the possibility on Tuesday. 
Investors were also down about several disappointing economic reports. The biggest blow, analysts said, was a smaller-than-expected increase in the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's business index, which is considered a harbinger for the national economy. The index's reading for March was 11.4, which still indicates an expansion in business but missed the 18 level that analysts were expecting. 
Still, analysts said some selling was to be expected given the increase in the market in February. 
Shares in General Electric fell yesterday, down $1.35, to $37.45, after a mutual fund manager criticized the GE Capital unit's reliance on short-term debt. The remarks came from William Gross of the Pacific Investment Management Company, which manages the Pimco Total Return fund, the country's largest bond fund.
Blue-chip stocks sensitive to interest rates, including financial and retailing issues, also fell. American Express was off 82 cents, to $41.02, while the electronics retailer Best Buy declined $1.04, to $79.01. 
The chip maker Intel rose 87 cents, to $31.40, recouping some of its $1.19 loss of Wednesday. --------------------

Treasury Prices Increase
By Bloomberg News
Treasuries rose as a government report showed business in the Philadelphia region expanded less than expected, prompting some investors to bet the Federal Reserve may wait until the second half of the year to raise interest rates. 
Investors bought the benchmark 10-year notes, pushing their yield down, as the Federal Reserve's report suggested the recovery may be slower than some anticipated.
By late in the day, the two-year note rose 2/32 , to a price of 9826/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.66 percent from 3.7 percent.
The 10-year note increased 10/32 , to 96 10/32 . Its yield dropped to 5.36 percent, from 5.4 percent. The 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to 94 9/32 . Its yield fell to 5.78 percent, from 5.82 percent.

HEADLINE: Senators Assail Corporate Use Of Bermuda As Tax Shelter 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21 

 BODY:
Senior senators from both parties used blunt language today to denounce companies that use Bermuda as a mail drop to reduce their American income taxes by tens of millions of dollars, calling them "greedy" and "unpatriotic" tax evaders whose actions could not be tolerated "in a time of war." 
 Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of the Finance Committee, and Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, the committee's ranking Republican, said they would introduce legislation next month to end the Bermuda tax break. 
 Such legislation would face an uncertain fate in the House, where the Republican leadership is skeptical of many proposals to close loopholes, contending that they may effectively be tax increases.
Companies including Ingersoll-Rand, Accenture, Tyco International and Seagate Technology reorganized to create a nominal headquarters in Bermuda or the Cayman Islands, which have no corporate income taxes, while maintaining their working headquarters in the United States. 
Senator Grassley labeled the Bermuda moves shams and warned executives contemplating such reorganizations that "you should proceed at your own peril." 
Mr. Grassley said that Stanley Works, whose shareholders will vote next month on a Bermuda tax move, and Ingersoll-Rand, which became a nominal Bermuda company in December, have about 300 total contracts as government suppliers.
Holding up a Stanley Works saw, he said anyone thinking about buying Stanley Works tools should consider that the company is "evading U.S. taxes and making profits off the taxes of middle-class Americans who are paying their taxes honestly."
"This is corporate greed," Mr. Grassley added.
Gerard J. Gould, a Stanley Works vice president, said he had not known about the hearing. The company, he said, "feels there is nothing unpatriotic about following existing law and reinvesting the tax savings to grow the company for all of its shareholders."
In a statement, Ingersoll-Rand said, "Our move to Bermuda was approved by our shareholders, was a taxable transaction and is consistent with U.S. laws."
"We believe that upon further analysis, the committee will conclude that aspects of the U.S. tax law drive U.S. companies to change their place of incorporation in order to compete on a level playing field with international peers," it added.
The two senators also criticized Treasury Department tax policy officials, who testified about their plan to combat what they said was growing tax evasion by corporations and wealthy individuals. The senators called the plan late, weak and lacking goals and a timetable by which its effectiveness could be measured.
When Treasury officials said they needed another year of corporate tax returns to analyze the nature of abusive tax avoidance, Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, asserted that he was astonished the "Treasury could be ignorant" of how companies cheat.
Mark Weinberger, the Bush administration's tax policy chief, said the best way to end the Bermuda moves, as well as abusive corporate tax shelters, was to simplify the tax code and make it more compatible with a global economy.
But under current law, he said, the best policy would be to require companies to disclose tax-avoidance deals to the I.R.S., combined with stiffer penalties for hiding abusive transactions.
Mr. Weinberger said that if a tax shelter promoter, its corporate client and the company's tax advisers "feel comfortable entering into a transaction," then they should be equally comfortable telling the I.R.S. about it.
Abusive transactions are "eroding the public's respect for the tax law," he said, adding, "As long as the tax law retains its current complexity, promoters will continue to develop these transactions."
Mr. Weinberger said many promoters were not cooperating with rules that they disclose tax shelters, in some cases carrying them out through separate businesses they shut down as soon as the deals are done so that no one is responsible for complying with existing disclosure requirements.
When Mr. Baucus pressed for a timetable for results in cracking down on abusive transactions, B. John Williams, the Internal Revenue Service's general counsel, said "the problem is we don't know what the universe is" of tax cheats. Mr. Williams said that only 99 of the 100,000 corporations likely to be solicited by tax-shelter promoters had come forward under an amnesty plan to disclose questionable transactions.
Senator Baucus asked for specific measures of Treasury success in stopping tax shelters. "I want a timetable," he said. "A month? Two months?"
When Mr. Weinberger said that fighting tax avoidance never ends, Mr. Baucus responded: "That's a little bit of a weaseling out. We need some accountability here."
The Treasury Department's plan was also criticized by Representative Lloyd Doggett, a Texas Democrat who has been a prominent critic of corporate tax abuses. The Treasury, he said today, "confuses modest, common-sense improvements with the comprehensive reform necessary to deter abusive tax shelters."
Mr. Baucus said the Treasury's failure to shut down tax shelters forced "honest companies to consider setting up a shelter of their own to avoid being placed at a competitive disadvantage" to companies that cheat.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: THE MIDEAST; 
JERUSALEM BOMBER KILLS 3 AND SHAKES U.S. PEACE EFFORT

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET with TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Friday, March 22 

 BODY:
A Palestinian suicide bomber killed three Israelis in Jerusalem on Thursday afternoon, prompting Israel to cancel truce talks and jeopardizing the Bush administration's tentative overture to restoring relations with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.
 Senior administration officials said it now appeared highly unlikely that Vice President Dick Cheney, just back from the Middle East, would return for a meeting with Mr. Arafat by early next week, as had been hoped. "We're not ruling it out," an official said, "but this doesn't help." 
 In sharp rebuke to Mr. Arafat, the State Department moved to designate Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, the Palestinian militia that claimed responsibility for the bomb attack, as a foreign terrorist organization. 
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, traveling with President Bush aboard Air Force One to El Paso on the way to an economic summit meeting in Mexico, telephoned Mr. Arafat from the plane, demanding a public statement, in person and in English and Arabic, condemning the bombing, officials said.
"It was as tough a message as we've ever sent to Arafat, about the urgency of the situation, what we expect, and frankly, the limits of our ability to help if this keeps up," an official said. "Part of the message was: Look, you control your fate here. Help us to help you. But until you do that, we're not going to be able to help you."
The attack, the second suicide bombing in Israel in two days, returned the antagonists to the brink of all-out conflict. Israeli officials have suggested that if the truce talks break down completely, they will see little alternative to attacking Mr. Arafat's governing Palestinian Authority directly.
But such a surge of violence here would undermine the Bush administration's efforts to build Arab support for a possible strike on Iraq.
In a sign that Mr. Arafat had not exhausted his chances, Israel's leadership indicated early today that it would not strike back immediately in reprisal for the latest attack, which also wounded more than 40 people. The explosion, of a nail-packed bomb, resounded across Jerusalem and spattered blood three stories above King George Street, in a once-bustling shopping district that has been struck repeatedly during the 18-month-old conflict.
In a statement released early this morning by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's office, Israel held Mr. Arafat "solely responsible" for the bombing. It said that "Israel will be unable -- for long -- to persist in a unilateral effort" to achieve a cease-fire.
Although a suicide bombing on Wednesday, carried out by the Islamic Jihad, elicited only a tepid rebuke from the Palestinian Authority, Mr. Arafat was clearer on Thursday. After Secretary Powell's call from Air Force One, the Palestinian leader said in a statement: "We strongly condemn this military operation that took place in West Jerusalem today, especially since it was against innocent Israeli civilians. We will take immediate and required steps to put an end to these actions and those who stand behind them."
The Islamic Jihad is not directly linked to the Palestinian Authority, and Palestinian security chiefs argued to Israel and the Bush administration after the Wednesday bombing that they could not control every militant from that organization. 
But Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades is connected to Fatah. Members insist that they respect Mr. Arafat but do not take their orders regarding attacks from him. But Israeli officials say Mr. Arafat controls the organization and has encouraged its violence.
Al Aksa Brigades, a group of loosely affiliated militias most active in the West Bank, has increased the number and deadliness of its attacks against Israeli soldiers and settlers since Jan. 14, when Israel killed a popular Aksa leader in the West Bank city of Tulkarm. As the group has eclipsed Islamic organizations like Hamas and Islamic Jihad, it has rebuilt Fatah's popularity, raising questions about Mr. Arafat's power to restrain it.
The bomber was identified as Muhammad Hashaika, 22, from a village near the West Bank city of Nablus. He had been held for a month recently in a Palestinian prison in Ramallah, on suspicion that he was about to carry out such an attack. But after Israeli ground forces attacked Ramallah this month, he was released, Palestinian officials said.
Israel said that after he was arrested, Mr. Hashaika had admitted under Palestinian interrogation that he intended to blow himself up in an Israeli mall, and that he even turned over the explosive belt he had planned to use.
Officials said Secretary Powell had taken the first step to list Al Aksa on the department's formal roster of some 30 terrorist organizations on Tuesday, and had notified Congress on Wednesday. The designation will become official on its publication in the Federal Register next week. Last week, more than 200 members of Congress wrote Mr. Bush urging that the brigades be added to the list. 
"The designation of the Al Aksa Martyrs' Brigade as a foreign terrorist organization is welcome if long overdue," said Representative Tom Lantos, Democrat of California, the ranking member on the House International Relations Committee. 
An Israeli diplomat in Washington also praised the move, which Israel had long sought in routine and high-level meetings. "It took them a long time to do this, and the reasons are clear," the diplomat said. "There's no clear wall separating Al Aksa and Fatah, and everyone knows that; it's all very fluid. The minute you say Al Aksa is on the list, the question becomes where does it start and where does it stop. This is a direct message to Arafat."
The group is named after the Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem, which has become the rallying point for the revolt, called by the Palestinians the Aksa intifada. 
Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the Bush administration's envoy, has been here for a week, in a renewed bid for a truce after two previous failures. And Israeli officials have been quick to point out that since his arrival, Palestinian militants have killed at least 11 Israelis with at least five suicidal attacks. Security officers say they have stopped several more such attacks. 
But some Palestinian leaders complain that General Zinni is neglecting their political grievances while emphasizing Israelis' demands for an end to violence.
After the suicide bombing on Thursday, Marwan Barghouti, the West Bank leader of Fatah, said, "The mission of General Zinni was expected to fail, because he came in order to impose the Israeli position, ignoring that the Palestinians are under occupation."
Speaking on the Arabic satellite channel Al Jazeera, Mr. Barghouti said that a truce was in the interest only of Mr. Sharon's troubled government, and that continued fighting was the Palestinians' surest path to statehood. 
"We refuse to throw the rope of survival to the government of terror that is sinking in the sea of resistance," he said. "Our resistance is the shortest road to end the occupation."
Under pressure from Arab nations to address the conflict and ease Mr. Arafat's isolation, the Bush administration has made the Palestinian leader's acceptance of a formal truce plan its condition for the proposed meeting next week between him and Mr. Cheney.
The Israeli government has imposed the same requirement as a condition for permitting Mr. Arafat to travel next week to an Arab League summit meeting in Beirut, Lebanon. 
Israeli officials involved in the talks have insisted on strictly addressing security concerns, demanding an immediate and durable cease-fire, while Palestinian officials seek rapid progress to substantive political negotiations over their demands for territory and statehood. "One side wants a more narrow definition, the other wants a political horizon," a diplomat here said, speaking on condition of anonymity. 
At least rhetorically, the Bush administration has been seeking to emphasize the political benefits to Palestinians of a cease-fire, but it is not clear if it has sought to offer them anything tangible in the negotiations. General Zinni has been seeking to carry out the so-called Tenet working plan, which both sides agreed upon nine months ago but never put into action. The plan -- named for George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, envisions a series of reciprocal measures to restore the status quo before the current conflict and permit an eventual return to negotiations. 
Under the plan, Mr. Arafat and his security chiefs would be obliged to arrest militants and seize illegal weapons. Israel would be obliged to pull back its forces from what by treaty is Palestinian-controlled territory, to the positions they occupied on Sept. 28, 2000, before the conflict began. 
Palestinian officials argue that the whole process should take about 10 days or two weeks, while Israeli officials are arguing for at least four weeks.
