HEADLINE: The Middle East's Failed Leaders 

BYLINE:  By Anthony H. Cordesman; Anthony H. Cordesman, senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, is author of "Peace and War: The Arab-Israel Military Balance Enters the 21st Century."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney's visit to the Middle East has made it even more obvious that forging an Israeli-Palestinian peace is a vital American strategic priority. We cannot serve any of our other interests in this region, which has nearly 70 percent of the world's proved oil reserves, unless we are seen to do everything possible to win a just peace. We cannot take action against Iraq with the regional support we need, roll back proliferation of nuclear weapons or even sustain our military presence.
 In fact, growing regional anger at the Bush administration's perceived failure to strongly support the peace process threatens our victory in Afghanistan and our ability to win the war on terrorism. 
We will need both a lasting cease-fire and a real peace if we are to protect our strategic interests. To forge such a peace, however, we are going to have to be far more realistic about the role each side has played in creating and escalating the conflict.
Yasir Arafat does deserve much of the blame. If he had responded positively to the opportunities offered him during the negotiations sponsored by President Bill Clinton at Camp David in 2000 and had made a clear and public commitment to the proposals made at Taba, Egypt, in January, 2001, we might already have an agreement on a just peace. Unfortunately, Mr. Arafat, if he did not exactly choose violence, has accepted and used it. Ever since the second intifada began in September 2000, he has never truly led in seeking a meaningful cease-fire. He has reacted only opportunistically.
That said, Mr. Arafat is only one of three failed leaders who must shoulder blame. The second is Benjamin Netanyahu. His effort to block progress toward fulfilling the Oslo Accords -- his tactic of renegotiating by delay and obstruction -- fueled Palestinian anger and hopelessness even before the start of the second intifada. He wasted the two most precious commodities in moving toward peace: hope and time.
The third failed leader is Ariel Sharon, who may be a tactical genius but has always been a failure at strategy. He has never known when to stop or how to set realistic political and strategic goals. He dragged Israel into a war in Lebanon that it lost after nearly two decades but that led immediately to major acts of terrorism on both sides, with many civilian deaths.
In the current violence, Mr. Sharon's demand, only recently withdrawn, for an impossible Palestinian effort to halt all violence as a precondition for a cease-fire, his willingness to escalate without meaningful strategic and tactical purpose, his carelessness in using violence in areas where civilians are present and his talk of forced separation and occupation all mirror Mr. Arafat's own narrow opportunism.
No one can condone the loss of a single civilian life on either side, but we need to realize that the situation has essentially become asymmetric warfare rather than Palestinian terrorism and Israeli counterterrorism. Each side has escalated the violence using the methods available to it. For the Palestinians, this is suicide bombing and smuggled arms. For Israel, it is tanks and attack helicopters. In both cases, civilians die, hatreds grow and the level and sophistication of the fighting increases.
Facing these realities goes against the grain of American domestic politics and against an international climate in which the United States takes the side of Israel while Europe and Arab moderates back the Palestinians. This dynamic has to change if America is to have an effective role in brokering a peace. 
It seems clear now that any move toward a cease-fire and peace settlement will have to be politically imposed from the outside on two sets of failed leaders and the influential people who support them at home. The Israel of Mr. Sharon and Mr. Netanyahu is not the peacemaking Israel of Yitzhak Rabin and Ehud Barak. The United States must openly and constantly condemn every intensification of the conflict by either side when civilians die.
Exhortation, of course, is not enough. America must define a detailed peace settlement and push for it in the face of Israeli and Palestinian political opposition.
The United States must seek international support in putting political and financial pressure on both sides. Israel depends on the United States for billions of dollars' worth of military and economic aid each year. The Palestinian Authority is dependent on hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of American, European and Arab aid and has no hope of ever building a viable national economy without even more. This aid could be used as leverage to push both sides to end the attacks and return to negotiations.
An effective peace effort may also require supporting the deployment of international observers and peacekeepers to enforce a cease-fire and a peace. But first the United States must separate its firm commitment to Israel's security from any commitment to the failed policies of Israel's leaders -- just as it must separate its condemnation of Mr. Arafat from a commitment to justice for Palestinians.

HEADLINE: Reeling From Blast, Peru Prepares for a Visit From Bush 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, March 21 

 BODY:
Dark memories of terror came alive in Peru today after a huge car bomb exploded outside the United States Embassy late Wednesday, killing nine Peruvians, wounding 30 other people and marring an upbeat atmosphere on the eve of President Bush's visit to the country.
 Mr. Bush, speaking this morning at the White House, told reporters that he had not changed his plans to come here on Saturday for a meeting on trade and security issues with President Alejandro Toledo and the leaders of three other Andean countries. 
 "No two-bit terrorists are going to prevent me from doing what we need to do, and that is to promote our friendship in the hemisphere," said Mr. Bush, who would be the first American president to visit Peru while in office. "You bet I'm going," he said. 
However, the bombing outside a hotel and a string of shops across the street from the embassy has sharpened security concerns around Mr. Bush's visit and cast a cloud over this nation of 24 million people, which thought it had put away the bombings and assassinations that marked its turbulent past. 
No one claimed responsibility, but government officials and political analysts said the bombing could be the work of the Shining Path, a Maoist rebel organization that carried out a string of urban terror attacks in the 1990's before being decimated by state security forces.
"We were supposed to have seen the last of this," said Victor Delgado, 30, a tourist agency worker, as he watched crews clear away the glass and rubble at the scene of the bombing this morning. "This is the kind of barbarism we lived with for so many years."
Mr. Toledo, speaking to reporters in Monterrey, Mexico, where Mr. Bush and the hemisphere's other leaders convened today for a United Nations development summit, said his government would "not yield even a centimeter to terrorism."
Mr. Toledo cut short his Mexico trip to return home today. "The courageous Peruvian people will not allow terrorism to return to Peru," he said before leaving Monterrey.
He added: "We will apply one heavy hand, and with the other, the law. We will apply all the necessary firmness and all the weight of the law."
Meanwhile, security in Lima was heightened as grim-faced government officials insisted that the city was safe.
Authorities placed the police on a "red alert" as the historic heart of the city was sealed off, the vendors and smoke-belching buses replaced by light armored vehicles and security forces. Mr. Bush, who is scheduled to arrive from Mexico on Saturday afternoon, is to meet with Mr. Toledo and the presidents of Colombia, Ecuador and Bolivia in the national palace, which faces the normally crowded Plaza de Armas.
Authorities are also moving forward with security plans developed before the bombing, deploying 7,000 police officers to guard main avenues and banning flights over Lima during Mr. Bush's stay.
"Security efforts have been redoubled in various places in the city," said Fernando Rospigliosi, the interior minister. "We will not drop our guard."
In El Salvador, where Mr. Bush will travel on Sunday morning, security had already been heightened before the bombing in Peru. Almost 1,700 police officers and 4,000 soldiers were assigned to presidential security, with another 7,000 police officers on alert. 
Salvadoran officials emphasized today that their political situation could not be compared to that of Peru. A decade after peace accords ended the civil war, the former combatants have devoted themselves to political rather than armed struggle.
In Peru, many people were unnerved today by all the talk of terrorism and the new, albeit temporary, security restrictions. Their uneasiness was not surprising in a country that lived through a brutal conflict that claimed 30,000 lives from 1980 through the late 1990's.
"It is hard to overstate how Peru was torn apart and traumatized by Shining Path," said Michael Shifter, a senior fellow who follows Peru for the Inter-American Dialogue, a policy analysis group based in Washington. "Precisely for that reason, Peruvians are perhaps more sympathetic than other Latin Americans to the U.S.-led campaign against terrorism."
Some Peruvians said the bombings heightened their concern about Mr. Toledo's government, which has plummeted in popularity because of a sluggish economy and a perception that the president lacks decisiveness.
"He does not have the capacity to deal with this," said Mariano Torres, 40, an accountant. "Sadly, I see him as just a president of words, and this shows it."
The attack took place at 10:50 p.m. on Wednesday when the bomb, which weighed more than 100 pounds, was detonated next to the Best Western Polo Hotel, just 150 feet from the 20-foot, drab-gray walls surrounding the fortresslike United States Embassy. Bodies were thrown about, with one man, his leg missing, landing more than 160 feet away. Windows were shattered and parked cars were reduced to charred heaps.
"I feel so indignant seeing this, " said Beatrice Ibanez, 28, as she watched cleanup crews today. "I'm scared because now we do not know what is going to happen. There is all this uncertainty."
Since Mr. Bush's visit was announced last month, many Peruvians had been eagerly looking forward to it as a sign of Washington's interest in Mr. Toledo's efforts to create a more stable, democratic government for Peru. 
Analysts here said the bombing could have been carried out by a new radical group, by Colombian guerrillas or even by people tied to the former president Alberto Fujimori and his intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos. A wide-ranging corruption scandal prompted Mr. Fujimori to flee Peru for Japan, his ancestral homeland, while Mr. Montesinos was jailed, leading to the election of the reform-minded Mr. Toledo last year.
But Dennis Jett, the American ambassador to Peru from 1996 to 1999, said, "If you sort of rounded up the usual suspects, Shining Path would be at the top of the list. 
"They are trying to send a message," Mr. Jett said, "that this is our welcome message for Mr. Bush, perhaps trying to recall the image of the chaotic situation of the past."
However, jailed rebels from Shining Path, which waged war against Peruvian governments in the 1980's and 1990's, told reporters by telephone today that their group was not responsible.
"We are not in accordance," said a rebel leader, identified as Commander Hugo. "This does not serve a purpose. All it does is create hate."

HEADLINE: City Is Losing Jobs Despite Signs of a Rebound on the National Level 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The co-op market is heating up, the stock market is picking up, and Alan Greenspan's mood is perking up. So the recession must be over, right?
 Not so fast, New York. The most crucial measure of economic growth is the number of jobs, which has started rising nationally -- but not here. 
 In fact, New York City lost roughly 14,000 private-sector jobs last month, according to a new report from William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller, even as the number of jobs rose at the national level. The city's job losses were worse than in January, and hit hard in two areas economists consider bellwethers for the local economy: Wall Street and temporary help agencies.
The unemployment rate in the city edged up, to 7.2 percent from 7.1 percent, even as the national rate edged down, to 5.5 percent from 5.6 percent, according to data released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. The unemployment rate in New Jersey also rose, to 5.2 percent from 4.9 percent, as the number of jobs fell by 4,600 after seasonal adjustment.
The numbers did not exactly surprise many students of the city's economy, but they did disappoint them. "Everybody had themselves thinking that there would be a visible improvement in February," said James P. Brown, an analyst at the State Labor Department.
But no. The private-sector job losses, which exclude gains in government hiring, were the largest since October, according to the comptroller's office, which adjusts state data for seasonal factors. 
To be sure, the regional economic situation is not as dire as many people, economists or not, expected a few months ago. Predictions that the city would fare as badly as it did in the early 1990's or the 1970's -- when hundreds of thousands of jobs disappeared and unemployment routinely ran in the double digits -- have not come true.
And there are some signs of improvement. Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues at the Federal Reserve have continually cut interest rates, which have given a boost to housing in New York and across the country. Tourism has also picked up, in part because of special incentive packages and advertising, but foreign tourists, who spend far more than domestic visitors, have not returned to the city in large numbers.
The number of people filing initial claims for unemployment insurance in the last month is about 17 percent higher than in the same stretch a year ago but far below the almost 100 percent increases that occurred late last year. And some tax receipts are coming in a little higher than forecasted.
But for any economy, "the best arbiter is jobs, and the New York economy is still losing jobs," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist for Economy.com, which specializes in regional analysis. "It's fair to say that its worst economic days are behind it, but the city is still struggling."
The parts of the country where the economy is rebounding are those with a lot of manufacturing, particularly car making, he said. Many of those areas went into recession in late 2000, whereas New York did not start declining until last spring. "First in, first out," Mr. Zandi said.
Manufacturing tends to be more sensitive to economic trends than services, economists say, especially now that companies do not build up big inventories of unsold products. If a gadget company cannot sell gadgets, it lays off gadget makers. Once the warehouses are empty and sales improve, the company will call employees back to work. But it probably will not spend money on things like advertising or travel until profits pick up.
And advertising, travel, consulting, accounting and financial services of all stripes are New York City's specialties. Wall Street, in particular, is an important driver of the city's economy.
Though the stock market has been moving mostly upward in the last two months, securities firms are not expecting a banner year, and employment at the firms, already down by more than 16,000 in the last 12 months, is likely to fall further.
In February alone, Wall Street shed 2,300 jobs, according to the comptroller's office. Business services, which includes advertising and temporary agencies and computer consultants, lost 4,800 positions. Legal services also declined slightly.
Of course, New York is experiencing economic problems that the rest of the country is not for reasons no one who lived through Sept. 11 will forget. Small businesses near the World Trade Center closed, many for good; garment factories in Chinatown closed, many for good; restaurants and limousine services and the like lost months of income and many valued customers.
Some Wall Street firms moved to New Jersey or Connecticut, and only a small proportion of them have come back, at least so far. More ominously, brokerage houses and investment banks are increasingly convinced that they must spread out their employees, making it more likely that firms will move more employees from Manhattan, industry experts say.
Several economists suggested that New York City's job picture would depend in part on how successful the state and local government were in creating incentives for businesses to stay in the city or even to relocate here. "Employers are probably waiting until there is more certainty about the status of Lower Manhattan, especially in terms of the incentives," said Barbara Byrne Denham, economist for The New York Stat, a newsletter analyzing the city economy. "This uncertainty is weighing down the economy."
Even so, it seems likely that the pickup in the national economy will give a boost to the city's later this year, said Rae Rosen, senior economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. She predicts that the city's job count may begin to improve in the second half of the year. By the end of 2003, she said, the city may even have recovered all the 100,000 or so jobs it has lost.
But in the short run, she said, "a good sign would be if the rate of decrease lessened."

HEADLINE: Citigroup Raises $4 Billion In Travelers Stock Offering 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Taking advantage of a likely boom in profits at commercial insurance companies, Citigroup sold 21 percent of its Travelers Insurance unit yesterday in the largest initial public offering this year.
 The sale of 210 million shares at $18.50 raised $3.89 billion, making it the biggest initial public offering of an insurance company and the seventh largest among all industries. 
 Investors reacted with enthusiasm to an opportunity to invest in an established company with a strong earnings record.
"People are buying a winning franchise, and the timing is certainly right,' said Randall Roth, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, a research and investing firm in Greenwich, Conn., that specializes in initial public offerings. 
Just last week, people close to General Electric said it was considering selling its commercial insurance company, the Employers Reinsurance Company, partly because the insurance market is so ebullient. After suffering estimated losses of $50 billion in the September terrorist attacks, insurers have been rebounding, doubling or even tripling their prices for many lines of coverage.
Some investors said they hesitated to buy Travelers stock because Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chief executive, is regarded as such an astute buyer and seller of companies. If Mr. Weill was selling, the thinking has been, would you want to be the buyer? But the performance of Travelers appeared yesterday to overcome most doubts.
Analysts said that while selling an insurer in the current climate would mean giving up substantial earnings from the higher insurance prices, it would be more profitable to sell now than wait until the market peaked.
Mr. Weill has said that he expects to make Travelers completely independent by the end of the year, by giving most of the rest of the insurance company to Citigroup shareholders. Citigroup would continue to hold about a 9 percent stake. 
Analysts said that Citigroup got a good price for its Travelers stock, but that the shares seemed to have plenty of room to grow. Citigroup initially offered the stock in a range of $16 to $19, but in the last few days the minimum was raised to $17.50, suggesting heavy demand.
The price of $18.50 a share was nearly twice the book value of Travelers -- about the same ratio as the Chubb Group, one of the most highly regarded commercial insurers. But Harry Radovich, an analyst for Merrill Lynch's Basic Value Fund, said that considering its strong history of earnings growth, Travelers was priced at a slight discount to its peers. "This company," he said, "has the potential to be a premier insurance holding."
Travelers was the 14th initial public offering this year in a markedly subdued atmosphere that contrasts sharply with the Internet mania. In 1999, there were 486 initial public offerings, many of them involving young companies with little or no earnings. This year, analysts say, there may be no more than 60 or 70 initial public offerings unless the economy picks up sharply.
Mr. Roth of Renaissance Capital said the new-issues market had turned decidedly deliberate. Almost all of the companies brought to market this year, he said, have been like Travelers: older companies with strong performances.
"These are not fly-by-night enterprises," he said. 
With a total market value of about $20 billion, Travelers becomes one of the most valuable commercial insurers and a likely candidate for eventual inclusion in the Standard & Poor's index of the 500 largest companies.
Mr. Weill said he was selling Travelers in part because, even as a stellar insurance company, its profitability was lower than that of other businesses in his financial conglomerate, like banks and brokerage firms. The lower earnings have been a drag on Citigroup's price-to-earnings ratio, which analysts say Mr. Weill seems obsessed with raising.
Another reason for selling, analysts said, is that the earnings of property and casualty insurers is inherently volatile, while Mr. Weill's goal is steady, high returns.
Marc Baum, the chief executive of the IPO Group, which follows initial public offerings, suggested that the insurance losses in the September attacks may have badly shaken Mr. Weill and the G.E. executives. Unlike career insurance executives, he said, they may want to make sure their future operations are more predictable.
"You have to wonder," he said, "if after Sept. 11 these people are thinking about what might come next as an even bigger risk."

HEADLINE: Central American Gains 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Central America's Cities Grow Bigger, and Poorer" (news article, March 17) depicted bleak outlooks for city dwellers and farmers alike. Yet there are also striking examples of effective international assistance resulting in a sense of promise. 
 In Cuscatlan, El Salvador, where half the homes were destroyed by earthquakes last year, I recently saw an innovative collaboration among local people, Save the Children, the Agency for International Development, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Peace Corps that is building anti-seismic homes and sanitation systems. 
 In a tenement neighborhood overlooking Tegucigalpa, Honduras, I saw a pilot vocational center -- a collaboration between Save the Children and the Honduran National Institute of Professional Formation -- that gives older girls and young women training in tailoring, and the chance to get micro-financing to start in-home sewing businesses. 
The dismal outlook for Central America can be counterbalanced by accounts of people achieving better lives through effective relief programs.

STEPHEN BORNEMEIER
Director of Planned Giving
Save the Children
Westport, Conn., March 19, 2002

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Impose 29% Tariff On Canada Building Lumber 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 22 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it would impose duties totaling 29 percent on softwood lumber -- the kind used to build houses -- that is imported from Canada, infuriating Canadian industry and government officials.
 The new tariffs will take effect on May 8, assuming the United States International Trade Commission decides by then that unfair Canadian trade practices have injured the American lumber industry. The commission, appointed by the United States government, concluded last year that Canadian mills had benefited from unfair subsidies and had priced their exports to the United States below production costs, leaving little doubt about how it will rule now. 
 Pierre Pettigrew, Canada's trade minister, called the new lumber duties "obscene" and said he was sorry that "the United States government did not have the nerve to confront its protectionist lumber producers."
Mr. Pettigrew said Canada would challenge the duties before the World Trade Organization and through the dispute-resolution provisions of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
But he stopped short of threatening retaliatory measures, noting that Canada now runs a large trade surplus with the United States. "We have to be careful," he said. About 85 percent of all Canadian exports go to the United States.
In recent years, Canada has supplied about one-third of America's softwood lumber, or $6 billion worth a year. The Canadian industry says the new duties will force sawmills to close and eliminate thousands of jobs.
Representatives of the home-building industry in the United States also reacted angrily today, saying the tariff amounts to a hidden tax on new houses and complaining that, because different kinds of trees predominate in Canadian and American softwood forests, American lumber is not always a satisfactory substitute for Canadian.
Most of the new 29 percent duty is meant to offset subsidies that American officials say Canadian mills receive, notably through the very low fees provincial governments charge for the right to harvest trees on public land, known as stumpage. The rest of the duty is meant to penalize Canada for "dumping" lumber on the American market below cost, a practice the Canadians deny.
A senior American trade official said earlier this week that the administration's goal "is to get the Canadians to operate in a way where the market determines the price." Washington had proposed that Canadian provinces levy an export tax on lumber until their forestry pricing policies could be revamped.
But Mr. Pettigrew said today that accepting that proposal would mean giving up the chance to fight the duties under W.T.O. and Nafta rules. "The litigation route looked more and more interesting," he said.

HEADLINE: Russia Imposes Flat Tax on Income, and Its Coffers Swell 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 19 

 BODY:
The American publishing billionaire Steve Forbes once trumpeted a flat-rate income tax so simple you could fill it out on a postcard. The Russian government recently took his advice about the flat tax to heart.
 But instead of a postcard, Russians are filling out 12 pages of forms. 
 Still, Russia is reporting stellar first results from a bold experiment, a 13 percent flat-rate income tax. The centerpiece of the government's tax reform program, it is the lowest rate in all of Europe and the envy of American right-wingers. 
Personal income tax revenues jumped by 47 percent in 2001. Tax collection over all was up by half last year and, despite a small dip in February figures, the Russian Tax Ministry expects it to rise by more than that this year.
"The January figures made us happy," said Anna P. Komardina, deputy head of the individual income tax department at the ministry. "We have nothing to be sad about here."
The early success is leading economists to wonder if Russians, who rate the taxman one notch below the dentist, have leapt out of the shadows into the government's collection net. Or is the rise simply because traditional payers -- oil and gas companies -- are getting richer and paying more?
Either way, last year's figures are quite an improvement over those of the 1990's, when state tax authorities could not, no matter how they tried, beat taxes out of this stubborn economy. They begged. They pleaded. When all else failed, they sent in men with guns. 
Finally they abandoned the old system, three different rates running as high as 35 percent, and turned to the flat income tax to offer a carrot. 
In truth, it was not really that people had refused to pay. The economy, quite simply, was paralyzed. There was no cash. Companies paid one another in pigs, tires and teakettles, making taxes nearly impossible to calculate, never mind collect. 
An economic explosion in 1998 solved that problem. "The cash came back," said Christof Ruehl, the World Bank's economist in Moscow.
Unlike Americans, the vast majority of Russians are not required to file an income tax return because their taxes are deducted from their wages. That makes life easy for most. For those who do not have taxes deducted, the procedure, which is not likely to impress Mr. Forbes, goes like this:
First, pick up forms from the tax inspector, since they are not available in post offices. Then read 32 pages of instructions and fill out the 12-page form. Print carefully -- a misplaced mark is ground for rejection. 
Next, hand deliver the forms, which are truly considered filed only after the tax inspector signs them. (Translation: forms lost in Russia's spotty mail system are your fault.) Finally, to pay, go to the state-owned savings bank Sberbank (but not during its lunch break) and fill out the same form twice. Carefully copy the 20-digit number across the top.
Exhausting? Russian accountants think so. Some carry gifts to soften surly inspectors, perfume for women and whiskey for men. Others come prepared with tranquilizers.
Svetlana, a 45-year-old accountant who takes on private clients in addition to her day job at a store that sells Italian bathroom fixtures, says she drinks a drop of Valerian, a homeopathic sedative, before making her case to the tax inspector. On a recent visit to the social security office, she was told, after waiting in line for over three hours, that she had incorrectly filled out one of her forms.
"I asked, 'Please show me how to fill it out,' " she said, on the condition her last name not be used. "They told me, 'That's not our job.' They told me to come back when I got it right."
Income tax is a small piece of the government's pie. Revenues from the tax make up about 13 percent of income, compared with more than 50 percent of all government tax revenues in the United States. The state here takes a much larger chunk in other taxes.
The other taxes are the heart of the problem. Long before employers deduct income tax from workers' wages, they must pay the government for pensions, social security and health care. As a result, businesses like to hide the true value of the wages they pay.
Take Oleg, 40, whose small Moscow company makes women's coats. He agreed to speak on the condition his last name not be used. Oleg's 36 seamstresses each earned $200 a month last year. But in tax filings, he declared that he paid them only $66. 
On every dollar he pays his seamstresses, he must pay 35 cents in social taxes to the government. His conclusion? Don't tell the whole story.
"It's just not realistic," Oleg said. "Income tax comes after all the other wage taxes. They haven't changed. Why should I?"
But government policy makers are working hard to change the system. The new income tax is a sign of that to Vladislav L. Korochkin, the owner of a 450-employee company that grows and sells garden seeds. 
Mr. Korochkin, 38, thinks that top officials have become more responsive to criticism. He even stated his complaints about the arduous accounting requirements of a new corporate tax to President Vladimir V. Putin at a meeting with a small-business lobby group in December.
"It hasn't gotten worse and that's pretty good," said Mr. Korochkin at his company's Moscow headquarters, where the walls are lined with brightly colored seed packets.
According to government records, more businesses are standing up to be counted. Finance Minister Aleksei L. Kudrin said recently that 400,000 new businesses were registered in the year and a half that ended last July, a rise of 11 percent. 
Mr. Ruehl, the economist, advises caution. "There is no evidence that the increased tax collection is a result of people suddenly becoming happy taxpayers," he said. "The happy taxpayer is a person we have never met, which is weird because he should be very public."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vladislav L. Korochin, who runs a seed company in Moscow, says top officials have become more responsive to criticism of the tax system. (Yuri Kozyrev for The New York Times) Chart: "ADDING IT UP: Russian Taxes"Federal taxes collected last year nearly tripled what they were in 1999. Graph tracking the federal taxes collected since 1995. *The ruble devalued in 1998.(Source: European Center for Economic Policy)

HEADLINE: A Bias Toward Waste 

 BODY:
Detroit's latest automotive brainchild appears to be an updated version of the old family station wagon. The automakers say the new cars are designed to attract drivers who want the space of an S.U.V. plus the handling and looks of a luxury car. As a report in The Times by Danny Hakim makes clear, however, these vehicles will also allow manufacturers to exploit a loophole in the government's outdated fuel economy standards to sell inefficient -- if highly profitable -- cars. 
 The Senate had a chance last week to tighten these standards and do something meaningful about global warming and the country's dependence on foreign oil. It surrendered instead to a fear campaign mounted by the companies and the United Automobile Workers. The net result is that industry can continue to devote its energies to gaming the system instead of building cars that could save money, energy and even the atmosphere. 
 The new "crossover" vehicles are the latest products of this system. Whereas traditional station wagons were classified as ordinary cars under federal fuel economy rules, these new vehicles will be classified as light trucks, a category that includes pickup trucks, minivans and S.U.V.'s. Vehicles in the standard passenger car category must meet a fleetwide average of 27.5 miles per gallon; vehicles in the light truck category must meet a less exacting average of 20.7 m.p.g. These new wagons will look less like trucks than the S.U.V.'s do; nevertheless, they will be measured by the same lenient standard, at considerable cost to the environment and even to national security -- though at considerable profit to the automakers, who make most of their money on the gas-guzzlers.
A bill sponsored by Senators John McCain, John Kerry and Ernest Hollings would have ended this nonsense. Over time it would have eliminated the distinctions between light trucks and passenger cars, meanwhile requiring a gradual increase in average fuel efficiency for all vehicles to 36 m.p.g. by 2016. This was not a radical proposal. A cautious report last year from the National Academy of Sciences suggested that such gains were well within Detroit's technological capacity, even without cutting-edge vehicles like electric/gas hybrid cars. Indeed, the automakers themselves had promised, during a flurry of one-upmanship two years ago, to produce a 25 percent increase in fuel economy without federal prodding. Yet to listen to the unions and manufacturers, you would have thought the bill would bring the entire economy of the Upper Midwest to its knees and squeezed American drivers into dangerous little mini-cars.
Their victory may be illusory. At the moment, with gas prices low, Detroit can count on the indulgence of consumers who seem unconcerned about fuel efficiency. Yet history suggests that things will change; the oil shocks of the 1970's caught the automakers woefully short of efficient cars. Industry and labor's present intransigence could cost them heavily down the road, especially if the only fuel-efficient cars in the showrooms turn out to be Japanese.
Another of history's lessons is that Detroit will respond to timely regulation. Though industry lobbyists almost always predict bankruptcy when Congress demands change, the engineers on the shop floor almost always find a cost-effective solution. Unfortunately, apart from one lonely tax credit, the Senate has produced an energy bill with no incentives for innovation and a bias toward waste.

HEADLINE: The Wrong Way to Remember Sept. 11 

 BODY:
There is no easy way to memorialize an event as ineffably sad as the loss of 3,000 innocent lives in New York last Sept. 11. The New York State Assembly has, however, seized on precisely the wrong way, passing a bill sponsored by Speaker Sheldon Silver to create an official holiday and a day off for state workers. 
 Relieving people of work does not necessarily move their thoughts in a desired direction. The talk on Labor Day is of barbecues, not the victories won when workers unite. Few people caught up in Memorial Day traffic bestir themselves to remember the Union's Civil War dead. Vacation days lend themselves less to sentiment than to pragmatism. It seems inevitable that, following the model of the birthdays of our first and 16th presidents, this new holiday would soon fall not on Sept. 11 but on the closest Monday to it. 
 The State Senate, pointing out that a holiday would mean millions of dollars in lost revenue for the New York economy, has passed its own bill that would make Sept. 11 a day of remembrance, when the American flag would be displayed across the state, and flags would fly at half-staff. This is a much better way to encourage a statewide commitment to remember the dead.
In attacking the World Trade Center, the terrorists were partly taking aim at America's, and New York State's, proud role in the global economy. One important way we can defy their dark vision is by doing precisely what they don't want us to do -- go to work.

PERSON: Robin Anderson 

HEADLINE: Robin Anderson, 51, Creator Of Documentaries on Australia 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 22 

 BODY:
Robin Anderson, an Australian filmmaker whose award-winning documentaries ranged from examinations of tribal life in Papua New Guinea to social and political controversies in Australia, died here on March 8. She was 51.
 The cause was cancer, her family said. 
 With her husband, Bob Connolly, Ms. Anderson made five full-length films on difficult, seemingly unpromising issues, each of which took several years to film.
The latest, "Facing the Music" (2001), about student and employee campaigns at Sydney University to defend the music faculty against being dismantled by financial cutbacks, received its premiere at the Sydney Film Festival in June on the day after Ms. Anderson's illness had been diagnosed as fatal. She lived long enough to know that a private benefactor who saw the film offered money to save the music school. 
Ms. Anderson, born in Perth, Western Australia, earned a degree in economics in Australia before receiving a master's in sociology from Columbia University. After two years in New York, she returned to Australia as a television researcher and married Mr. Connolly, a director of documentaries and profiles of rural life for public television.
In addition to her husband, Ms. Anderson is survived by her brother, Michael, and her daughters Katherine, 14, and Joanna, 10. 
The first Anderson-Connolly film, "First Contact," made from 1980 to '82, was nominated for an Academy Award. It introduced the couple and their audiences to remote regions of Papua New Guinea.
The film's success led the team to make "Joe Leahy's Neighbors" (1989), about the political and cultural struggles of a mixed-race coffee planter, and "Black Harvest" (1992), about land and money disputes and their escalation into tribal warfare.
The films established the team's international reputation, with each one winning a major prize at the Cinema du Reel festival, which honors documentaries.
Their best-known work, assembled from hundreds of hours of candid film, was "Rats in the Ranks" (1996), an often hilarious close-up look at small-town political infighting. Reviewing the film for The New York Times, Janet Maslin said that "Rats in the Ranks" appreciates "the dauntless energy and sheer Shakespearean conniving it takes to stay afloat" in the "shark-infested waters" of local politics.

HEADLINE: Palestinian Group Says It Will Increase Bombings 

BYLINE:  By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: NABLUS, West Bank, March 22 

 BODY:
A day after the United States said it would add their group to its list of terrorist organizations, leaders of a Palestinian militant movement defiantly said today that the listing would prompt them to carry out more suicide bombings in Israel.
 "We have tens of people who are ready and willing," said Naser Badawi, who said he was a political leader of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, which the United States on Thursday said it would classify as a terrorist group. "We are talking to young people all the time. We will continue our operations, and to respond to the American position, there will be even more actions." 
 The group's statement said "it is an honor for the brigades" to be added to the United States list of terrorist groups, given that "America is the greatest sponsor of terrorism in the world." The statement cited American military actions in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, today condemned the latest suicide bombing by the group, on Thursday in Jerusalem, and called for an end to attacks on civilians. But Mr. Badawi said the Aksa Brigades would ignore that.
"He does not support what we are doing," he said with a shrug, sitting on a sofa in his living room with a large-caliber pistol stuffed between the cushions just to his right. "But we believe this is our national responsibility. We respect our leader, but the decisions to carry out attacks remains with the Aksa Brigades leadership."
The group grew up last summer, starting here in the Balata refugee among members of Fatah, Mr. Arafat's movement, who did not believe that he was acting forcefully enough. Soon it spread throughout the West Bank and Gaza.
Last fall, the group's leaders said it would target only soldiers and Israeli settlers. But that view changed early this year, in part because Hamas, the militant Islamic group, had raised its standing among Palestinians with its suicide attacks, and Fatah was losing influence.
"What America did gives new legitimacy to Al Aksa Brigades," said Hussam Khader, a Palestinian legislator representing Nablus who opposes the suicide attacks. "Politically, this gives them a real boost to be the real representatives of the Palestinian people."
Mr. Badawi said, "The Palestinian people can now begin to believe that there is a force that can confront the Israeli force." The group decided to broaden its attacks, he added, because "we reached the conclusion that in Israeli society there are no civilians. We tried to create that separation, but then we see that even 12-year-old Israeli boys are given weapons."
Mr. Badawi, speaking through a translator, was interviewed for an hour this afternoon in his home in the Balata refugee camp. He said he had met with a few other journalists earlier in the day. He had intended simply to issue the brigade's statement, he said, but he made other remarks after long questioning.
The brigades have claimed responsibility for several recent suicide bombings, including one in an ultra-Orthodox religious neighborhood in Jerusalem on March 2 that killed nine Israelis, including six children.
Bashir, a 27-year-old fighter in the Aksa Brigades who would not give his last name, said he agreed with the decision to attack Israeli civilians because "wherever there is an occupier, we should consider them a target. Besides, Israel sees all of us as targets."
Bashir, who was injured by Israeli gunfire late last month and still walks on a crutch, was sitting with Mr. Khader, the legislator, who interjected to say: "I don't agree with that, and I tell them that all the time. If we keep going this way, the situation will only grow worse."
Mr. Khader's view, while not unique, is not widely shared. In talks with many Palestinians across the political and economic spectrum in recent days, most wholeheartedly support the suicide attacks and say they are helping to bring concessions from the Israelis.
"That is why agreeing to become a martyr" in a suicide bombing "has become a general phenomenon among our people," Mr. Badawi said. Just outside his home, his 8-year-old son had used chalk to write the phrase "Sharon the butcher" in Arabic on the sidewalk.
Mr. Badawi says everyone in the Aksa Brigades considers Mr. Arafat "the leader of the Palestinian people, a symbol. And we do not want to be in contradiction with him." 
But both Mr. Badawi and Mr. Khader said the group's leaders do not communicate with Mr. Arafat. Mr. Badawi said Mr. Arafat had never approached anyone from the Aksa Brigades to ask them to stop the suicide bombings in Israel -- although the leader did make a public statement to that effect on Thursday.
He added that if Mr. Arafat reaches an agreement for a cease-fire, the Aksa Brigades will decide independently whether to abide by it.
Mr. Khader said he worried that alienating the United States will leave the Palestinians in a hopeless situation. Mr. Badawi agreed in part, saying, "Of course it is important to have this support from the United States. But we don't want just verbal support. We want action. And now we see that the United States is just following what Israel wants."

HEADLINE: Europe Lists U.S. Imports It Plans to Tax 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, March 22 

 BODY:
The European Union has drawn up a list of imports from the United States, worth about $2.1 billion annually, to penalize in retaliation for the Bush administration's recent imposition of tariffs of up to 30 percent on some imported steel.
 American steel, textiles and citrus fruit are among the items that would face punitive duties, officials said. 
 The European Union has threatened sanctions if the United States does not agree to pay compensation for its measures to protect the struggling American steel industry. Under World Trade Organization rules, the union is permitted to impose sanctions as harsh as a 100 percent import tariff almost immediately, if the United States "safeguard" measures for steel cannot be justified. 
The union is confident that the Americans will not be able to justify them, an official said, speaking on condition that he not be identified. But the official said rapid action was looking less likely.
Instead, he said, the union will rely on the more thoroughgoing but slower dispute- resolution system at the trade organization. Under the procedure, the trade group conducts hearings in Geneva and then rules on what sanctions the union can impose. The process takes about 18 months.
"There is a lot of frustration in European public opinion," said Pascal Lamy, the union's trade commissioner. The feeling, he said, is that "if we wait for the judge for 15 months, we are crazy or naive or weak." He continued: "But it's a political decision on our side. I want to stay within the international rules."
Under the trade group's dispute procedure, which began this week, the union has until May 20 to submit a list of products to be sanctioned. The draft list is now being circulated among the union's member states for comments before it is submitted to the trade group.
 In Washington, an American trade official said the Bush administration had hoped that the European Union would allow the dispute-resolution process to go forward before drawing up plans for retaliation. American officials have already begun discussions with the Europeans and with other countries, including China, over the steel tariffs and demands for compensation.
 "We're disappointed because we're still in the consultative phase at the W.T.O.," the American official said. Any retaliation now, he said, was "definitely premature." 
The European official who spoke about the way the union was proceeding said the list of products to be sanctioned was drafted with American domestic political impact in mind. Citrus fruit is on the list because of its importance in Florida, where the 2000 presidential vote was extremely close, the official said; steel made the list because of its importance in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, and textiles because of North and South Carolina, four important battleground states in midterm elections this year.
Separately, the union is putting final touches on protective measures for its own steel industry, which it will activate as soon as next week if it sees a risk of a surge in cheap steel diverted from the United States reaching its shores.
The union is expected to set up quotas based on average annual imports over the last two or three years, and then impose "safeguard" tariffs on imports above the quotas. The tariffs will be lower than those of the United States, the official said, because the point is to maintain current trade patterns and keep them open, not to disrupt them, as the American measures will.
The steel tariffs and threats of retaliation come as another trans-Atlantic trade dispute is also at a critical stage. The union has applied to the World Trade Organization for authority to impose $4 billion in trade sanctions on the United States to compensate for the unfair tax breaks the United States gives its exporters. Washington has said that the harm done to the union by the tax breaks is closer to $1 billion. The panel hearing the dispute is scheduled to reach a decision next month.

HEADLINE: No-Tax Pledge By McGreevey Faces Test 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 22 

 BODY:
In the final weeks of last year's governor's race, and the heady days immediately following his landslide victory at the polls, James E. McGreevey made a sweeping promise to New Jersey residents that he would not raise taxes. 
 Less than three months into his term, however, Mr. McGreevey is struggling to close a steep budget deficit, and his administration has been steadily trying to prepare the public for an increase in the cigarette tax and changes in the corporate business tax, which will bring an additional $700 million to state coffers. 
 Mr. McGreevey is not scheduled to outline his budget plan until he addresses the State Legislature on Tuesday, but as details of the plan have begun to emerge, elected officials from both parties are eagerly awaiting the public reaction to the governor's likely reversal on taxes. 
Even Mr. McGreevey's critics concede that he has been remarkably disciplined in reminding the public that he inherited the deficit from the Republicans, who controlled Trenton for the past decade, and in arguing that they should bear much of the responsibility for the painful moves to come. He has also tried to create some political wiggle room for himself since taking office by refining his no-tax pledge and saying that he was only referring to the sales and income taxes.
But no elected official in Trenton has forgotten that in 1990, Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase cost Democrats the governor's mansion and control of both houses of the Legislature. Especially not Mr. McGreevey. At a press conference in the State House last week, the governor was asked whether his shifting position on tax increases was similar to Mr. Florio's. Mr. McGreevey used some of his most forceful language to date to describe the problem he now confronts. 
"During the course of the campaign I clearly stated it was my objective not to raise taxes," he said, thumping on the lectern to emphasize his words. "Then, upon seeing that, literally, this represents the largest deficit not only in the history of the State of New Jersey, this is the largest deficit of any state government in the history of the United States of America. This is the all-time record-breaker. One-quarter of budget."
Mr. McGreevey based that claim on projections that New Jersey will have a deficit equal to 25 percent of its total budget. No state has ever had a deficit as high on a percentage basis.
But Republicans, who have bristled at the governor's repeated criticism, accuse Mr. McGreevey of overstating the problem in order to lower expectations and allow himself to magnify his accomplishments once a balanced budget is finally adopted. The governor's office has projected a $6 billion shortfall; last year's budget was $23 billion.
"There can be no shortfall before a budget has been presented to us," said State Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican from Hunterdon. "I don't see how you can blame the Whitman administration or prior Legislatures for a budget that has yet to be written." 
The chief culprit in the state's budget problems was the economy, which brought a sharp drop in tax revenues during the past year. Mr. McGreevey has already taken steps to close the $3 billion shortfall in the fiscal year ending June 30 by laying off 600 state workers, enacting a 5 percent across-the-board cut and tapping into surpluses in an assortment of special funds. 
Now he must propose a budget at a time when income tax receipts are still down and automatic increases in state spending are likely to exceed projected revenues by $5 billion or more. The size of that gap, in a budget that will likely approach $24 billion, has forced Mr. McGreevey to consider a handful of steps that he had hoped to avoid. 
He said the state work force would likely be reduced by an early retirement program and more layoffs might be needed eventually. 
Despite his relentless complaints that Republicans borrowed money irresponsibly during the past decade, Mr. McGreevey is considering a plan to raise $1.5 billion by issuing bonds against the state's proceeds from the tobacco settlement.
But the most provocative parts of the program are the governor's two proposals to adjust the state tax code. In a reversal from two months ago, the governor said this week that he has not ruled out a 50-cent-per-pack increase in the cigarette tax, which would raise $200 million per year.
He is also likely to adjust the corporate business tax by closing loopholes that allow some major companies to pay as little as $200 per year in state taxes. Those changes could bring in an additional $500 million in tax revenues. The plan now being weighed by the governor does not call for an increase in the corporate tax rate.
"I think people have the reasonable expectation to have fairness and equity," Mr. McGreevey said, noting that the average New Jersey family pays more than $200 in state taxes. 
But Republicans have already branded the plan a tax increase, and warn that it might prolong the economic downturn by forcing companies to leave the state and costing workers their jobs. 
"New Jersey has learned the hard way that tax hikes cost jobs -- especially when they're aimed at our state's largest employers," said Senator Joseph Kyrillos of Middletown. "In fact, the last time our businesses faced a significant tax increase, over 200,000 New Jerseyeans lost their jobs."
Recent public opinion polls show that most New Jersey residents are not deeply opposed to higher corporate taxes. But they already pay some of the highest property tax rates in the country, so some political analysts warn that if the governor cuts the property tax rebate program, or if his reduction in aid to school districts and local governments leads to property tax increases, Mr. McGreevey could face political consequences. 
"If he doesn't raise the sales or income tax, I think he can finesse his way through this," said David Rebovich, a political science professor at Rider University. "But there's a second whammy in this budget crisis: How long will school district officials wait to say to their own constituents that they have to raise property taxes because their aid has been frozen by Jim McGreevey?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Volcker Proposes Andersen e Controlled by New Panel
Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, proposed that the government drop its case against Arthur Andersen and allow him to put a new oversight board in charge of the accounting firm. He said the board would make management changes and focus the firm almost exclusively on auditing.
 Mr. Volcker's proposal steps up the pressure on plaintiffs to settle their lawsuits against Andersen, something the accounting firm considers vital to restoring confidence in its viability. In separate action, a federal mediator was appointed to try to resolve civil cases against Andersen. Page A1. 

Spending Surge Eases Recession
An unexpected surge in government spending, which contributed to the swing in the federal budget from surplus to deficit, helps to explain why the recession has been so mild and may be ending. Some of the stepped-up spending went to the military and to fighting terrorism, but significantly more went to highways, school construction, Medicaid, unemployment insurance and municipal projects. A1.

Duties Planned on Canadian Lumber
Saying that Canadian trade practices have injured the American lumber industry, the Bush administration plans to impose duties totaling 29 percent on Canadian softwood lumber beginning May 8. Pierre Pettigrew, Canada's trade minister, left, said Ottawa would challenge the duties in the World Trade Organization and through the North American Free Trade Agreement. C2.

Canadian clothing manufacturers have taken advantage of free trade agreements to flood the United States with casual pants, suits and sport coats. The surge in imports has put pressure on American clothing companies, driving some manufacturers out of business. C2.

New Travelers Shares Rise Slightly
Shares of the Travelers insurance company rose just under 6 percent yesterday in their first day of trading. The performance disappointed some investors and suggested that the stock had been priced at close to its potential in its initial offering on Thursday. C3.

Questions About Verizon's Debt
The bond and share prices of Verizon Communications fell after two rating firms said the company needed to either reduce its dependence on short-term borrowing or increase its bank commitments backing that debt. C2.

Postal Rates Rise on Bulk Mail
Postal rates will increase this summer as part of an agreement, approved yesterday, between the postal service and businesses that use bulk mail. Rates on bulk mail are expected to increase as early as June 30. A11.

Markets Close Down for Week
The Dow Jones industrial average fell again, its first losing week after five consecutive winners. The Dow slipped 52.17 points, to 10,427.67. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 4.89 points, to 1,148.70. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 17.44 points, to 1,851.39. C4.

United Recalling 1,300 Workers
United Airlines said it was recalling 1,300 employees and hiring 900 more in certain markets as business began to pick up. C4.

Judge Allows DaimlerChrysler Suits
A judge in Detroit has refused to dismiss two lawsuits accusing DaimlerChrysler of lying to Chrysler shareholders. C2.

Technology Review for Police Dept.
Raymond W. Kelly, commissioner of the New York Police Department, is moving to update the department's computer equipment, asking I.B.M., Deloitte Consulting and Merrill Lynch to evaluate its troubled systems. B3.

HEADLINE: Broad Increase in Postal Rates Is Approved by Federal Panel 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22 

 BODY:
The cost of sending a first-class letter will increase this summer by 3 cents, to 37 cents, as part of a broad postal rate increase.
 The rate changes are part of an agreement, approved today by the independent Postal Rate Commission, between the financially struggling postal service and many of the businesses and organizations that send bulk mail. 
 The postal service's board of governors will decide later when the new rates take effect, probably the end of June, officials said. The board said it would take up the matter at its meeting in April. 
"This decision will allow the Postal Service an immediate influx of revenue while holding rate increases to a reasonable percentage for postal customers," said George A. Omas, chairman of the rate commission.
First-class stamps will rise to 37 cents from 34 cents, and postcards will increase to 23 cents, from 21 cents. The last increase in first-class stamps was a 1 cent rise in January 2001, to 34 cents. 
Postal officials said they had negotiated the agreement with as many as 60 major customers to raise bulk rates as early as June 30 -- three months earlier than expected -- to shore up the finances of the service. The Post Office has seen mail volume drop because of the economic downturn and has had unexpected expenses because of the discovery last fall of anthrax-tainted mail. 
The post office says it expects to lose more than $1 billion in this fiscal year, which ends Aug. 31
The Magazine Publishers of America has said the settlement is in the best interest of mailers and the industry, adding that without the agreement the service might have sought higher rate increases. 
But the American Postal Workers Union opposes the deal, which allowed the expedited rate decision without the usual prolonged course of hearings. 
"The new rates will require American citizens to subsidize giant mailers," said William Burrus, the union president. 
Since 1981, the union said, rates for consumers have risen 93 percent, while rates for large business mailers have increased 76 percent.

HEADLINE: Security-Prone Oscar Ceremony a Blight on Business 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 22 

 BODY:
The long-awaited return of the Oscars to Hollywood, after an absence of 42 years, was intended to incite development and symbolize the neighborhood's economic revitalization. Instead, its first act is to shut the place down.
 "It is ironic," said Leron Gubler, president of the Hollywood Chamber of Commerce. "But I think most of the merchants here realize that we have to go through a few days of pain in order to receive some long-term benefits." 
 Security, the watchword of the post-Sept. 11 world, has come to the Academy Awards, transforming the event into what promises to be a vastly different experience for everyone from stars to gawking fans.
Hundreds of officers from local and federal law enforcement agencies will ring central Hollywood on Sunday night, in at least three levels of security checks and keeping guard on a traffic-free perimeter of nearly two square miles. As a result, dozens of shops along Hollywood Boulevard and inside the new Hollywood and Highland retail complex -- site of the Kodak Theater, where the awards show will take place for the first time -- will be closed.
"All of the restaurants and nightclubs in the complex will be shut down, at least for this first year," said Bruce Davis, executive director of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the group that awards the Oscars. "And we're not allowing any of these Oscar-viewing parties in the complex this year. To do so would have tripled the amount of traffic coming into the area, and it would have meant that every bus boy in every restaurant would have to get a security clearance."
Not everyone is delighted with the impact of the Oscar's return to Hollywood. At a meeting of neighborhood merchants a few weeks ago, complaints were heard from several owners of some of the strip's souvenir shops, restaurants, hostels and tattoo parlors who were unconvinced of the benefits of losing customers for several days to help developers burnish the Hollywood brand name.
"I know a lot of these merchants who have been complaining about the security closures," said Raubi Sundher, whose family owns the Hollywood Wax Museum and another museum across the street, Guinness World of Records. "And I know, it's tough. A lot of them are already operating pretty close to the bone."
The problem has been a precipitous drop in the number of foreign tourists coming into Hollywood since Sept. 11. Mr. Sundher said the number of travelers' checks his museums are receiving from foreigners had dropped by 90 percent from this time last year. 
Laura Ziskin, producer of this year's Oscar show, warned at the annual nominees' luncheon this month that people should plan to arrive by mid-afternoon -- hours before the show starts -- to be sure of getting through the traffic and security checks. There will be metal detectors, as has become common at the Oscars over the last decade, but there will also be bag searches and identity checks. 
On Sunday, subway trains will buzz past the Hollywood station without stopping and bus service in the area will be truncated. Overhead, air space will be restricted. 
Even the people sitting out on the official red-carpet bleachers have been affected. Sandi Stratton, 59, a homemaker from Escondido, Calif., has been in the bleachers for each of the last 32 Oscars, going so far as to sleep in a tent for 10 days last year outside the Shrine Auditorium to guarantee a seat.
This year, her 33rd ceremony, Ms. Stratton will be among the 400 or so people in the bleachers, but to get there she had to apply to the academy in February and submit to a background check. She was among about 4,000 people who applied. There was no camping out and, frankly, she said, she misses it.
"It's nice to know we have a seat," Ms. Stratton said. "But it was a lot of fun in previous years to sit out there for days and watch how everything comes together. To be honest, this is a nuisance this year."
What makes this new venue a particular security concern is that it is in the middle of one of the region's most congested neighborhoods. Both the Shrine Auditorium and the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, the most recent Oscar venues, had plenty of open space around them to establish security perimeters. 
The post-Oscar parties given by the big winners may also be tossed a curve this year. Universal Pictures and DreamWorks, distributors of "A Beautiful Mind," one of the best-picture contenders, are giving a party jointly with USA Films, which distributed "Gosford Park," another top nominee. But their party is to be at the Renaissance Hotel, which is linked to the Kodak Theater inside the security perimeter, so if either of those films does take the top prize no one will be able to attend the celebration who does not already have an Oscar ticket or official credential.
"They're doing more than if it was a presidential visit," said Johnny Grant, known as the honorary mayor of Hollywood and long involved in efforts to resuscitate the neighborhood after decades of economic stagnation. "I know people who tell me they always put on a tuxedo and sneak into the Governor's Ball after the show. Well, if I was them, I wouldn't try it this year."

HEADLINE: Sharp Rise in Federal Spending May HaveHelped Ease Recession 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
When a bitterly divided Congress failed to pass an economic stimulus bill last fall, many predicted the recession would only worsen. But while few were paying attention, government spending surpassed the amounts envisioned in the stimulus measure, exceeding what even the most vociferous advocates wanted.
 The unexpected surge -- along with the remarkable strength in consumer spending -- helps to explain why the recession, to nearly everyone's surprise, has been so mild and may be ending. 
 The mood was much different last fall. Anticipating harder times, Democrats and Republicans pushed for an additional $80 billion to $100 billion in federal outlays. While they agreed on this goal, they deadlocked over how to allocate the money. Democrats wanted the government to spend nearly all of the money, while the Republicans emphasized new tax breaks for business and consumers, not outright spending. 
Despite the bill's failure -- a severely watered-down version finally passed this month -- government outlays rose sharply in response to dozens of uncoordinated decisions and fortuitous windfalls. The surge, which started in October, has continued into this month at a rate of more than $100 billion, new government data suggest. And income tax cuts that went into effect at the beginning of this year are expected to provide a further lift to the economy.
"You can reasonably argue that the recession, which seems to have ended, came to an end because of aggressive government spending," said Mark M. Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a forecasting and data gathering firm.
Some of the stepped-up outlays, of course, went to the military and to pay for domestic actions to fight terrorism in response to the Sept. 11 attacks. 
Significantly more, however, was delivered in the form of increased spending on highways, school construction, Medicaid, unemployment insurance and numerous municipal projects.
After shrinking last summer, the American economy reversed course and grew from October through December at an annual rate of 1.4 percent. The results of aggressive government spending -- not only at the federal level, but among states and cities as well -- accounts for much of the swing from contraction to expansion, even without adding in the tax breaks, the Bureau of Economic Analysis reports. The rise in government outlays, along with the remarkable bounceback in consumer spending after Sept. 11, more than offset declines in other sectors, particularly business spending on new equipment, offices and factories. 
Will that last? The hope is that the momentum from consumers and government, two powerful engines of demand, will restart business investment and the recovery will be on its way. The danger, however, is that both may falter before the economy picks up sufficient speed.
Mortgage refinancing, rising wages, bargain prices, falling energy costs, tax cuts and rebates, rock-bottom interest rates -- all these have sustained consumers through the recession, despite rising indebtedness. And while this year's income tax cuts promise to provide more stimulus, most of the other supports show signs of fading.
Something similar may be happening to government spending -- not at the federal level, where the outlays in response to terrorism seem open-ended, but in the states and cities. Most experts thought that spending at the state and local level would decline as tax revenue fell during the recession. Reflecting this view, the advocates of a stimulus package pushed last fall to include subsidies that would permit states and cities to keep up their spending.
To nearly everyone's surprise the states and cities found ways to sustain their spending anyway, despite balanced-budget laws that require them to keep spending in line with revenue. This rear-guard resistance, however, seems likely to give way by early summer when many new budgets, mandating cuts, go into effect for the fiscal year 2003. 
"You can expect the drop in state and local spending that did not occur last fall to begin to occur now," said Kevin Carey, an analyst at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities. 
So far, good luck and ingenuity have helped the states and cities dodge that bullet. There was, for example, a windfall in 1998 and 1999 from a federal excise tax on gasoline and autos. That tax, earmarked for the states, produced an unanticipated $10 billion during those boom years that is now being spent to build and repair highways.
"It takes time to arrange to pour concrete," said William Hoagland, a senior staff member of the Senate Budget Committee.
There were other tactics for sustaining spending, despite falling tax revenue. Reserve funds, built up to record levels during the boom, have been drawn down. Some spending cuts have been announced and then postponed. And some states and cities have simply crossed their fingers.
Consider Vermont. Faced with rising Medicaid costs and payments to needy families, cities in Vermont have drawn $750,000 from a $2 million account set aside to clean up oil spills. "The gamble is that there won't be a spill into our rivers," said Steven Jeffrey, executive director of the Vermont League of Cities and Towns, "or a leak from some aging storage tank, and we won't have to repay the money," 
The fortuitous surge in federal spending showed up in a report this month from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. The report compared federal outlays in the first five months of the current fiscal year -- October through February -- with spending in the same months in the previous year. Outlays were up 13.1 percent, double the usual percentage increase. Over 12 months, the additional surge, if it continues, will total $106 billion, or the equivalent of about one full percentage point in economic growth, even before counting spillover effects. 
"If you want to argue that we have had stimulus, without stimulus legislation last fall, I think that is certainly the case," said Barry B. Anderson, deputy director of the Congressional Budget Office.
The jump in federal spending has been most noticeable in rising outlays for the military, for internal security -- particularly at airports -- and in subsidies to airlines to keep them flying. New York has also received help paying for the cleanup at ground zero.
But an even greater amount has shown up as spikes in federal spending for Medicaid, for unemployment insurance, and, among other things, in outlays for education and highways. Some of this money was channeled to the states, which accounted for slightly more than half of the fourth-quarter surge in overall government spending.
The states and cities got their fattened subsidies after all, without having them mandated in an economic stimulus package, as the advocates had demanded last fall. The subject did not even come up in the brief debate this month over the very watered-down economic stimulus bill that Congress passed and President Bush signed. It will cut some business taxes and add only $8 billion to government spending, all of it for extended unemployment benefits. 
Economists and budget analysts are just beginning to offer explanations for the unanticipated part of the surge in government spending since October. The Medicaid increase, for example, is attributed mostly to rising costs for prescription drugs and to growing participation in a health insurance program for poor children. And stepped-up spending for education has helped.
"There are a multiplicity of reasons," said Richard Kogan, a senior fellow at the Center on Budget Priorities, "for this extraordinary increase in government spending."

HEADLINE: Mr. Bush Looks South 

 BODY:
Most Latin American nations are feeling a bit jilted these days. President Bush came into office pledging to make them a top foreign policy priority, but has found it hard to live up to his commitment. 
 The president's current trip to Mexico, Peru and El Salvador may be an effort to show his engagement with the region, but it also underscores his failure to advance the hemispheric agenda. Mr. Bush's friendship with President Vicente Fox of Mexico was once again manifest yesterday in Monterrey, but Mexicans are widely disappointed by the lack of progress on an immigration reform that would clarify the status of millions of undocumented workers in the United States. 
 Similarly, even though Mr. Bush becomes the first American president ever to visit their nation when he arrives today, Peruvians are disappointed that the United States has failed to renew the Andean Trade Preferences Act. The law exempts an array of exports from Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru from duties. It is vitally important to these countries, and relatively uncontroversial on Capitol Hill. The Senate's failure to extend it before the president's arrival in Lima was inexcusable. 
The administration's broader trade agenda, including the proposed Free Trade Area of the Americas, suffered a severe blow earlier this month when President Bush decided to impose new tariffs on steel imports. The president's top economic advisers have dismissed the move as a concession to domestic political concerns, but that will do little to alleviate simmering trade tensions with Brazil. The administration's passivity in the face of Argentina's financial crisis is a further signal that Washington is not overly concerned about the region's plight. That impression only emboldens populist leaders like Venezuela's Hugo Chavez, who appears eager to drive a wedge between the United States and Latin America. 
The fate of the Andean nations' fragile democracies is the most pressing concern. In Peru, a terrorist bomb set off outside the United States Embassy in Lima on Wednesday killed nine people. The attack brought back memories of Peru's painful struggle earlier in the 90's against the Shining Path guerrilla movement. 
In neighboring Colombia, of course, the war between the state and Marxist guerrillas is intensifying in the aftermath of the collapse of peace talks last month. Right-wing paramilitary groups, often allied with members of the military, are as much of a threat to that society. 
This week the Bush administration asked Congress to ease restrictions on military aid to Colombia that limits its use to the fight against drug trafficking. The issue deserves a thorough debate. Distinguishing between counterinsurgency and counter-narcotics is a phony exercise in the Colombian context, but Congress ought to remain wary of any assistance that is not conditioned on the Colombian Army's improving its human rights record.
All told, Latin America presents a distressing mosaic at the moment, one that Washington needs to be more concerned about.
