HEADLINE: As Options Shrink, New York Revisits Idea of Incineration 

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
In recent years, the idea of using incineration to dispose of some or all of New York City's daily tide of garbage seemed about as dead as Marley's ghost. 
 A plan in the mid-1980's to burn about half of the total in an archipelago of incinerators across the five boroughs was downsized, then killed. The last municipal incinerator closed in the early 1990's. Environmental objections, neighborhood politics, and perhaps most important, a bounty of other options, especially adequate and affordable landfill space to bury the trash, made incineration look like a footnote. 
 But now the idea of trash-into-ash is back, and part of the reason, as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials seemed to be warning New Yorkers this week, is that the once-abundant alternatives are becoming harder to come by, and to pay for. "We're going to have to take a look at all different possibilities," Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday on his weekly radio show when asked about the current state of incineration technology. "No matter what you hear about people yelling and screaming, an awful lot of this technology has gotten very much better." 
Mr. Bloomberg's sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, twice brought up the issue of incineration, without ever being asked about it, in testifying earlier this week before the City Council. "I don't know what the thoughts of the city are, what people's feelings are on it are, I don't know if things have changed," Mr. Doherty later told reporters. "But we have to think about it, we have to look at it again." 
Questions of cost are driving that search. Between 1998 and 2000, the cost of exporting the city's trash beyond its borders more than tripled, and is projected to more than double from that amount by 2004 to $238 million a year, according to the city's Independent Budget Office. 
But environmentalists, waste industry experts and government regulators say that many things have changed since New York last considered incineration as a serious option in the early 1990's. 
Like Rip Van Winkle, who emerged from a nap to find the world transformed, a new debate about incineration would take place on an altered terrain. And few doubt that the issue would be any less hard-fought. But from the rules of environmental regulation to the tactics of community opposition, and from the tarnished dreams of recycling to the concerns about the city's ability to be self-sufficient in uncertain times, just about everything else can be divided into columns of then -- a decade ago -- and now.
Back then, emissions from trash-burning plants, especially things like dioxins and mercury, prompted the most objections. Now, since new tighter federal regulations were imposed in the 1990's, the plants are far cleaner, state and federal regulators say. But the additional pollution-control technology is expensive, and many plants across the country have closed. The number of incinerators fell to 97 as of last year from a high of 150 in 1993, according to Governmental Advisory Associates, a research and consulting firm in Westport, Conn. 
Back then, city sanitation officials hoped that recycling would become a pillar of long-term disposal plans, making New York less dependent on things like landfills or incinerators. In 1992, for example, the City Council projected that recycling would divert 42 percent of the city's trash by the turn of the century. Now, with New York struggling to reach even a 20 percent diversion rate, Mr. Bloomberg has proposed cutting the program nearly in half to save money. Less recycling means more garbage that must be buried or burned.
Back then, New York's energy market was a regulated monopoly and there was little concern about long-term electricity supply. Now, with uncertain deregulated energy markets, some experts say that generating megawatts from trash could find new appeal.
Back then, the overarching environmental issue of garbage in New York was the festering landfill at Fresh Kills in Staten Island, which was closed last year. Now the questions are more diffuse and so are the environmental tradeoffs. Some environmentalists say that the vast fleets of diesel trucks that rumble every day across New Jersey, taking the bulk of the city's trash to landfills in Pennsylvania and Virginia -- and burning an estimated 10 million gallons of fuel a year in the process, according to a recent report from Columbia University -- are perhaps as big an environmental insult as anything at Fresh Kills, but far harder to measure.
Back then, the politics of trash centered on the question of the betrayal of Staten Island in the 1940's, when a supposedly temporary local dump became the city's only dump. Now, issues of economic vulnerability are behind the search for new solutions -- a note that could find particular resonance in a city still recovering from the impact of terrorism and a recession. 
Exporting the city's garbage to mostly out-of-state landfills, Mr. Doherty told a City Council committee this week, makes the city dependent and defenseless, especially if Congress passes legislation allowing states to regulate garbage exports.
Mr. Bloomberg added his voice to that message yesterday.
"There are two states, Virginia and Pennsylvania, that are willing to take it," Mr. Bloomberg said, referring to the city's trash. "But they charge a lot of money." He said he agreed with Mr. Doherty, and that down the line, those states would undoubtedly raise their prices. 
Some environmentalists say that a new battle over incineration would be as hard fought as anything in the past, and that while plants may well be cleaner now, more is known about the dangers of the pollutants they do produce. Other environmentalists say they could agree to put incineration back on the table, but that the price of their support would be high.
"Could we have that discussion? The answer is yes," said James T. B. Tripp, the general counsel at Environmental Defense, a national conservation group based in New York. 
Mr. Tripp said that any serious proposal to bring back incineration would have to be directly linked to a major new commitment by the city to reducing its waste through expanded composting and recycling. Government monitoring and testing of air emissions and ash, he said, would also have to be far more ambitious than anything contemplated in the 1990's.
"If we're going to think about it, we've got to be prepared to think about everything," Mr. Tripp said.
Other environmentalists say that advocates of incineration underestimate the costs, both financial and environmental, of trash-burning technologies. New tactics of community opposition have also been sharpened since the early 1990's, especially the link between environmental protest, civil rights and racial politics, generally lumped together under the heading of environmental justice.
David Higby, the solid waste project director at Environmental Advocates, a conservation and lobbying group in Albany, said that mercury emissions, in particular, were still a problem from trash combustion, and that the trend among many municipalities was toward a zero-emissions standard for mercury, which could make finding a place for new plants almost impossible. 
"They were marginal then," Mr. Higby said, referring to the trash plants of the early 1990's. "I think we're coming to the point where they're not practical any more at all."
A study released recently by Columbia University, on the other hand, paints an opposite picture -- that the current technology for converting waste to energy, as an environmental solution, is vastly preferable to landfills. The report, by an interdepartmental group of engineers, scientists, public policy experts and others, called "Life After Fresh Kills," says that landfills almost invariably leak pollutants over time and can also produce methane, a so-called greenhouse gas that has been linked to global climate change.
Burning trash, the report says, could also reduce the state's dependence on coal for generating electricity, which would reduce pollution because trash-burning regulations are so strict. The authors of the study also offered up some political advice: don't force a plant on any community in the city or the region, but open up a system of bidding so that a community, reachable ideally by barge so that trucks would not be needed, could negotiate a package of energy rebates, tax dividends or other incentives. 
The price of those incentives might be high, but they also might be, in the age of litigation and community organization, the only means of success, the report said.
Mr. Bloomberg said on his radio show yesterday that he thought part of the problem was how a debate over incineration would be framed and reported. In representing both sides of a controversy, scientific expertise can come off sounding like just one more opinion, he said. "The trouble is, it's one person's word against another," he said, "and all of the experts that really know what they're doing may say it's clean and one guy who knows nothing stands up because they want to grandstand."

HEADLINE: The Soul of George W. Bush 

BYLINE:  By BILL KELLER; E-mail: billkeller@nytimes.com

 BODY:
About a year ago, The Economist published an article under the smirky headline "George Bush, homme serieux." The British newsweekly argued that despite the new president's apparent intellectual weightlessness, the administration had in fact come to town with some serious thinkers in its entourage and some interesting ideas on its program. There might be more to the C-student president than we expected.
 In the flush of patriotic solidarity after Sept. 11, no one questions whether Mr. Bush is a serious man, meaning resolute and full of purpose. But what, besides defending us from villains, is he about? This is not a bad moment to subject Mr. Bush's White House to an intellectual wanding. He has logged 400 days of on-the-job training. He has begun to trust his own instincts more. And he has, by virtue of the terrorist threat, acquired the political standing to get away with saying what he really thinks. So is there an emergent Bush philosophy that suggests what we might expect for the remainder of his presidency? 
 I think there is, and it is very different from what many on the right and left expected, although it is easy to miss for three reasons. 
The first, of course, is the war on terror, which consumes Mr. Bush, defining him in some ways but obscuring him in others by overshadowing everything else on his agenda.
The second is that, to put it generously, Mr. Bush is not himself an intellectual. The sometimes skillful work of his speechwriters, which he sometimes delivers with conviction, cannot disguise the fact that he is not a deep thinker, a student of ideas, or even a very curious man. For all the spoon-fed portraits of the president exuding new gravitas since the war began, President Bush is still an easy man to take lightly.
Another confounding factor is the administration's extraordinary discipline in the cause of political longevity. This is a president who has no intention of dying the one-term political death of his father, even if that means selling out principles from time to time. Free-traders, who thought they had Mr. Bush's allegiance, are horrified by his imposition of tariffs on imported steel, for example, a naked move to shore up Republican support in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia. And a few conservatives swallowed their gum when they heard of the president's performance at the annual Gridiron dinner. Teasing Senator Tom Daschle about his presidential ambitions, Mr. Bush joked (or not): "What are you going to run on, Tom? Patients' bill of rights? I'm for it. Enron? I'm against it. Campaign reform? I'll sign it. Child care? Tom, I'm gonna expand child care to those who don't even have children."
Leave aside style and political expediency, and what is left at the core? On the theory that it takes one to know one, I spent a few days talking to right-of-center thinkers from various camps. Whether or not you share their ideology, their sense of the president is often shrewd and well informed, and it is remarkably consistent across the right wingspan.
To begin with, Mr. Bush is emphatically not from the libertarian school of conservative thinking. A year ago, at libertarian strongholds like the Cato Institute -- which favors minimalist government, a non-interventionist foreign policy and free markets -- hopes flickered that Mr. Bush might be the first true leave-us-alone president. They loved the big tax cut, on the principle that cutting off the oxygen of taxes is the most reliable way to cripple government. But the libertarians have grown deeply disenchanted. It turns out that Mr. Bush is an activist, deficit-spending, interventionist president.
Early on, the president's determination to expand the federal role in education hinted at this. Now the war at home and abroad has demanded big budgets, which Mr. Bush has allowed to become a pretext for copious pork-barrel spending in the guise of "stimulus." The president's instinctive readiness to curtail civil liberties was another wartime cause of libertarian alarm. Abroad, the man who as a candidate advocated "humility" in our dealings with the world has developed a passion for upending foreign governments and rebuilding damaged nations.
Nor can Mr. Bush be claimed by the culture warriors of the Christian right, although he gave them John Ashcroft and occasionally throws them a steak. The president is not a bigot, or a pessimist. He created an office to promote faith-based social services, but has let it languish.
He is not quite a classic big-business conservative, either, although he and corporate America vibrate to the same tuning fork and he has stocked his administration with former C.E.O.'s. He is reflexively pro-development, and he regards environmentalists as whinging elitists.
But Mr. Bush brings something to the job that makes country-club conservatives quiver with unease. He is a moralist. I think this was true before Sept. 11, but the attacks have galvanized his inner missionary. More precisely, Sept. 11 confirmed for him that God had chosen him for a purpose, and showed him what that purpose is.
On the domestic front, his moral streak is summed up in his persistent rhetoric about "a new culture of responsibility." Remember that Mr. Bush is a convert -- from alcohol and wild living to God and domesticity -- and he has a convert's faith that anyone else can do likewise. Although his faith is Christian, this is a moral outlook that sits comfortably with Jewish and secular conservatives. 
Look at his tough-standards education program, and especially at his new proposals to escalate the assault on welfare, and you see a Republican who is troubled by the legions of poor and prospectless but believes that what the government should offer them is self-reliance, a prosperous economy in which they can find a place, and a sermon about premarital sex. He proposes to add $300 million to the budget to, somehow, push unwed mothers into marriage, but nothing for day care so that single mothers can get to their mandatory jobs. If you've been wondering what "compassionate conservative" means, there you have it. It is not the liberal safety net or the noblesse oblige of the first President Bush, but the compassion of the strict parent who says, "This is for your own good." Or the drill sergeant who says, "Suck it up!"
"The message is a moral message: Let's cut the victimology, this is the land of opportunity," said Myron Magnet, editor of the neoconservative magazine City Journal and an early Bush policy tutor. "Of course everyone can succeed. The bars to success are now much more internal than external."
Mr. Bush's moralism is more ambitious, sometimes verging on messianic, when it comes to the world beyond our borders. It is encapsulated in two bits of presidential oratory that were widely written off as careless rhetorical flourishes -- the glib "axis of evil" and the Islam-offending description of America's "crusade," which the White House later retracted. Read Mr. Bush's lips, and he seems deeply convinced that America's great project is to combat evil and implant what he calls "universal values" throughout the world. Foreign policy is not just about defending oilfields.
In the tug of war between the go-get-'em, nuke-brandishing civilians of the Pentagon and the coalition-minded pragmatists of the State Department, conservatives are now convinced Mr. Bush's sympathies are gung-ho. The Weekly Standard, which has overcome personal strains with Mr. Bush to become something like the president's conservative superego, has taken to calling this "The Bush Doctrine."
"On tactics, he may be listening to Colin Powell," said Norman Podhoretz, the influential conservative editor and author. "But he's very clear as to his strategic objectives -- not just to clean up Al Qaeda cells but to effect regime changes in six or seven countries and to create conditions which would lead to internal reform and modernization in the Islamic world."
Whether the president will, in the end, take us to a multitude of wars in the cause of liberating the world from evil, or whether the mission will lose some of its energy when the cost (literal and political) grows, I can't tell. But I think Mr. Podhoretz correctly reads the president's heart. 
If you were hoping for the right-of-center moderate Mr. Bush campaigned as, or if you shared the patronizing view of the president as a good-natured boob tugged along by avuncular ideologues, this may strike you as chilling. But have no doubt, it is tres serieux.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Mexico Relations: Alliance Meets Boundaries 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 22 

 BODY:
In the courtship between President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico, images seem so convincing.
 At their third meeting in 13 months, Mr. Bush and Mr. Fox still walk casually together like friends and banter in English and Spanish like friends. Mr. Bush still says no nation is more important to the United States than this one, and Mr. Fox still spins visions of opening the border to a freer flow of immigrants. 
 But now, the relationship seems high on concept, low on content. Mexico's exalted position on the American list of allies has stirred imaginations but has so far deflated expectations.
The meeting today was billed as a fresh start on an ambitious Mexican agenda that American officials said had been sidelined six months ago by the terrorist attacks. Mr. Fox arrived here hoping for concrete progress on goals including immigration reforms that would legalize some 3.5 million undocumented Mexicans in the United States and expand guest worker programs.
Indeed, the two presidents announced new plans today for modernizing security measures along their 2,000-mile border and a series of joint public-private partnerships aimed at stimulating private investments in areas of Mexico with high immigration rates.
Mexico's rich neighbor has committed more than $1 billion in new money to United States agencies that manage the border. But United States officials did not say how much of that money would go to Mexico.
Light-years away from a general amnesty, the United States Senate has still not voted on a bill that would allow undocumented immigrants to stay in the United States while applying for permanent residency. Mr. Fox's campaign for open borders has turned into an effort to make the border more secure.
The limited progress has raised concerns that there is more than terrorism undermining Mr.Fox's bilateral agenda. With or without the terrorist strikes, some analysts say, the agenda was doomed to hit the wall of American politics. Mr. Fox, a former corporate executive, has come to understand that as president, he may be able to set agendas, but the forces of open government will define the timeline. 
"The relationship was as virtual before Sept. 11 as it is now," said Jorge Montano, a former Mexican ambassador to the United States. "But the terrorist attacks gave President Fox an excuse for not achieving his promises. Now he's having to accept that his friendship with President Bush has great limitations."
Another former Mexican ambassador, Andres Rozental, was more optimistic. "I don't think President Fox has given up on the U.S. relationship," he said. "I think simply that reality is setting in that this is going to be a long haul. The issues are more complicated than ever, but they are still on the agenda."
The links in the United States-Mexico relationship, have been built largely on the visions of Mr. Fox, a former governor of Guanajuato, a northern Mexican state largely emptied by immigration to the United States. Mr. Fox traveled to Washington six months ago and challenged the United States to quickly adopt his goals for a safer border where immigrant crossings would be controlled more by demands for labor than law enforcement.
Calling immigration a "shared responsibility," he persuaded the United States to consider economic support for industrial development in Mexico's poorest regions. Presenting dozens of ideas about the kinds of laws, programs and amounts of money needed, Mr. Fox pressed the United States to achieve the dream by year's end.
Eduardo Sojo, chief economic adviser to Mr. Fox, said that after a series of setbacks in domestic and foreign policy, the Fox administration has learned that "political agreements have their own rhythm." Mexico's increasingly independent Congress no longer answers to the president's whims, and has stalled proposals for tax reform and Indian rights. Meanwhile, the Supreme Court ruled that it would not allow suspects to be extradited to the United States in death penalty or life imprisonment cases.
So the administration has stopped measuring progress by deadlines.
"We think that in the course of this year, or the beginning of next year, we will be able to achieve a lot that was on our agenda with the United States," said Foreign Minister Jorge G. Castaneda. "Either we will have achieved specific results, or we will have moved forward on the negotiations or we will have conceptually identified strategies and begun to move forward on them."

HEADLINE: Bush, in Monterrey, Speaks of Conditional Global Aid 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico, March 22 

 BODY:
President Bush called today for a "new compact" for global development by insisting that rich nations give foreign aid to poor nations only if poor nations undertake a broad range of political, legal and economic reforms.
 "Pouring money into a failed status quo does little to help the poor, and can actually delay the progress of reform," Mr. Bush told the presidents and prime ministers of 50 nations gathered here for a conference on global aid to the developing world. "We must accept a higher, more difficult, more promising call." 
 Mr. Bush spoke on the closing day of the conference, when 171 nations signed the "Monterrey Consensus," an accord committing them to the goals of doubling development aid to the poor and halving world poverty by 2015.
Tonight, in a wide-ranging news conference, the president said no decision had been made on whether to begin a new round of drug interdiction flights over Peru. The flights, in which Peruvian fighter planes force down or shoot down suspected drug flights, were suspended last year when a plane carrying American missionaries was mistakenly shot down.
"We're analyzing not only what took place in the past, but the most effective way help Peru fight narcotics," he said. Mr. Bush will travel to Peru on Saturday.
The president also tried to lay to rest talk that Fidel Castro's abrupt departure from the conference on Thursday was the result of pressure from the United States.
Mr. Bush said there was "no pressure on anybody. Fidel Castro can do what he wants to do."
In his talk today, the president reiterated a promise of a 50 percent increase in American foreign aid over three years, and added that some money might be available as early as this year -- a counter to complaints from development agencies that the United States was moving too slowly in its new foreign aid commitments.
Mr. Bush's pledge meant that the total American foreign aid budget, if approved by Congress, would be $15 billion by 2006. The current American foreign aid budget is $10 billion.
Although Mr. Bush's pledge of aid fell short of the goals of the conference, the American commitment -- along with a promise of $4 billion more per year from the European Union -- was considered the most important developments of Monterrey, and proved, development experts said, that poor nations could exert powerful pressure on the richest nation in the world, particularly when the United States was asking many nations for help in the fight against terrorism. Mr. Bush's pledge of aid, which he first announced in a speech last week in Washington, was considered an abrupt change in Bush administration policy.
"It's a shift in political attitude that is very important," said Jorge G. Castaneda, Mexico's foreign minister. Mr. Bush, Mr. Castaneda added, clearly did not want to come to Monterrey "without anything to propose, without anything to put on the table."
Mr. Bush said that he would "jump start" his new aid program to make some funding available to nations that meet American standards of reform within the next year. Last week, development agencies had criticized him for delaying the start of the aid increase until 2004. 
But Congress must first approve that money, and the Bush administration must also develop the specific standards for economic, political and legal reform, making it unclear how much new money will actually flow from the United States to poor nations this year. Mr. Bush has given the task of developing those standards to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Secretary of the Treasury Paul H. O'Neill, who this week in Monterrey expressed considerable skepticism about foreign aid. 
"If we are going to have real economic development in the world, most of that will come from capital coming into those countries to create jobs," Mr. O'Neill said. "We are not going to do it with welfare."
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, called Mr. Bush's move to speed up the aid an "indication by the president to do a little more, a little earlier." Mr. Fleischer said that the White House had no specific number in mind, but that it might be "a couple hundred million." Adding additional aid this year would not be part of the president's proposal for a 50 percent increase, he said.
Under that proposal, the foreign aid budget would grow by $1.7 billion in 2004, by $3.3 billion in 2005 and by $5 billion in 2006. Taken together, that would amount to a $10 billion increase in the foreign aid budget over three years. But Mr. Bush, sounding a similar but more diplomatic call than his treasury secretary, said that trade and foreign investment were far more important to the economic health of a poor nation than any level of foreign aid.
"All of us here must focus on real benefits to the poor, instead of debating arbitrary levels of inputs from the rich," Mr. Bush said in his speech at the Monterrey International Business Center. He added that "to be serious about fighting poverty, we must be serious about expanding trade."
Mr. Bush, as he has before, linked development aid to the fight against terrorism and also cast it in terms of religious and moral obligations.
"We fight against poverty because hope is an answer to terror," Mr. Bush said. "We fight against poverty because opportunity is a fundamental right to human dignity. We fight against poverty because faith requires it and conscience demands it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush, speaking at a conference on the developing world in Monterrey, Mexico, promised more aid. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: From 'I Do' to 'I Don't' 

BYLINE:  By Patricia Cohen; Patricia Cohen is the editor of the Arts & Ideas pages of The Times.

 BODY:
 THE MARRIAGE PROBLEM
How Our Culture
Has Weakened Families.
By James Q. Wilson.
274 pp. New York:
HarperCollins Publishers. $25.95.
 In the 1970 movie "Lovers and other Strangers," Beatrice and Frank are sitting at the wedding of one son, trying to persuade their other son and his wife not to get divorced. Look at "Anthony and Anita -- cheek to cheek," Frank tells them. "Did you know that Anthony has not said one word to Anita for two years?" "But they're still together," Beatrice declares. 
In the more than 30 years since the movie's release, staying together, or, more precisely, staying married, has gone from a punch line to a national crisis. The decline in marriage, the rise in divorce and most of all the astounding number of babies born out of wedlock -- one-third of all births -- have unsettled religious conservatives, child welfare advocates, scholars, politicians and others. Even those who don't agree on the cause agree on the results: children who grow up with only one parent are more likely to be poor, drop out of school, have emotional problems and commit crimes.
These trends have precipitated a movement -- a marriage movement -- that has gained adherents in the statehouse and the White House. Oklahoma offers training courses on marriage and relationship skills; Louisiana offers a "covenant marriage," which requires premarital counseling and makes it tougher to get a divorce. And just last month, President Bush made strengthening marriages a centerpiece of his welfare plan, promising $300 million to finance experimental programs that teach the benefits of marriage and offer premarital counseling. 
Now James Q. Wilson, one of the most influential conservative thinkers around, who is best known for his work on crime prevention, has taken up the cause in "The Marriage Problem." He has outsize ambitions for this short volume: to review the research on marriage, divorce and children; to recount the biological, social, economic, political and cultural history of marriage and family life; and to offer policy recommendations.
That's a tall order for anyone, and the result is a book that careers from nuanced readings of social science research to silly generalizations based on pop opinion polls and episodes of "Sex and the City," from refreshing insights about our culture to none-too-subtle attacks on women's equality. 
To Wilson, the erosion of marriage is eating away at society's foundations. More than anything else, it is responsible for the poor, troubled and wretched corners of America. He offers a sobering look at the vast array of research on poverty and single-parent households. Being poor exacts a terrible toll. But rich or poor, white or black, children raised by one parent, whether divorced or never married, tend to have a tougher time. 
And it's not just the children who are worse off. Surveys have repeatedly shown that people who say "I do" are on the whole happier, healthier and wealthier than those who don't. So why don't people do what is obviously in their own best interest? 
To answer that question, Wilson recounts the familiar arguments of the evolutionary psychologists about men being biologically programmed to have sex with as many women as they can. Women, meanwhile, are geared toward finding a reliable provider for their children (never mind that giving birth and liking sex are not mutually exclusive activities). Wilson also says the marriage marketplace is out of whack: the fact that there are not enough stable, employed men to go around makes the desirable hunks even less likely to hook up with only one woman and shoulder the duties of a family.
More refreshing is Wilson's capsule history of marriage, which includes interesting tidbits like the 17th-century interest in liberalizing divorce. John Milton (who abandoned his wife a month after their marriage) and John Locke both believed that unhappy couples should be able to separate at will. Wilson also traces the changes in child welfare policy, showing how government assistance, once limited to the "suitable homes" of widows and abandoned wives, was eventually extended to unmarried women.
He is careful, though, not to dump the whole problem on welfare's doorstep. (He thinks the fact that unmarried motherhood is no longer shameful plays a bigger role than government checks in encouraging single women to have children.) And for once the 60's -- the favorite bugaboo of conservatives -- aren't blamed. "It would be remarkable if an institution as old and as universal as marriage could prove so vulnerable to one decade of cultural change," he says. Instead, he argues that one of the West's greatest achievements -- the Enlightenment -- and one of its greatest shames -- slavery -- are jointly responsible for the weakening of the family. 
Slavery, "that vast, cruel system of organized repression that denied to slaves the right to marry, vote, sue or take an oath" and "allowed their own children to be sold on the slave block," grievously injured family life, Wilson persuasively writes, countering critics who deny the connection. Certainly it is at least part of the explanation for why nearly 70 percent of African-American babies are born to single mothers, compared with 22 percent of white infants. 
Meanwhile, the glorious intellectual, scientific and personal liberation ushered in by the Enlightenment unhinged marriage from its traditional social moorings and turned it into a mere contract -- like any business agreement. What the Supreme Court called a "sacred obligation" in the 19th century was referred to as "an association of two individuals" by 1965.
The Enlightenment also opened the way for the emancipation of women, which Wilson calls the "single core event" underlying the questioning of marriage. Women were no longer forced to rely on men to provide them with a home or social status. Many finally had the financial and emotional wherewithal to leave abusive or neglectful relationships. 
But along with the dead-on insights are some batty assumptions and curious lapses. Why, for instance, does Wilson omit the work of E. Mavis Hetherington, one of the field's most respected researchers, who recently argued that the ill effects of divorce on children are not nearly as long-lasting as many feared? Why does he dabble in tinhorn biology to claim that men are better at climbing the corporate ladder and more likely to work longer hours because he-man aggressiveness was once an evolutionary advantage? Or declare that a mother wonders whom the baby resembles, while a father "suspects that the infant looks like -- well, a baby"? (Unless he's been watching one too many stand-up routines on Comedy Central.) 
And what about his portrayal of "career women" as bitter, frustrated spinsters, whose only boyfriends are likely to be married men or weirdos? Those who do marry, he adds, have a good chance of ending up divorced. (Not sure how I'll break this one to my husband.) No wonder women are often suspicious that calls to return to the traditional family cloak a desire to return them to second-class status. 
Of course the marriage debate isn't just about economic incentives and social policy but about values. Is living together immoral? Is having children outside marriage? Absolutely, Wilson says. Everyone wants to help children, but we should do it by encouraging marriage from the ground up, not by easing the burden on unmarried parents. Shame single women who get pregnant and clamp down on assistance to unwed mothers. He even suggests that sending fatherless children to orphanages might be better than giving aid to unmarried mothers -- once known as "morally unfit." In the end, though, government can do only so much. The "effort must be done retail, not wholesale, by families and churches and neighborhoods and the media, not by tax breaks or government subsidies."
Such views will not warm everyone's heart. Even hard-core welfare critics are likely to blanch at the notion of bringing back orphanages. Abusive fathers, not to mention uncaring, unconcerned ones, are as much (if not more) trouble inside a marriage as out. That's no reason for Wilson to shrink from his opinions. But his ideological slant will narrow the book's audience, which is too bad, because there is a lot here -- from his analysis of certain trends to his ideas of what to do about them -- that would persuade many people on the left and the right. Instead, the book can be too easily labeled as another volley in the culture war, rallying like-minded readers, alienating others and having about as much staying power as some of today's marriages.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 719 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 THE GARDENS OF KYOTO, by Kate Walbert. (Scribner, $13.) The middle-aged narrator of this elusive first novel recalls her coming of age in the 1950's, moving back and forth between America, Japan and Paris as she reconstructs her past in a way that is emotionally honest even as she withholds certain darker facts and violent episodes. Last year in the Book Review, Alida Becker admired the tale's "understated power," which "is expressed not only in quietly wrenching scenes . . . but in its narrator's wistful asides."

DOGS AND DEMONS: Tales From the Dark Side of Japan, by Alex Kerr. (Hill & Wang, $15.) A longtime resident of Japan catalogs what he perceives to be the many social, environmental and political dysfunctions of a declining, culturally empty nation that has been cursed by its own success. Even if he overstates his case, his "important and oddly romantic" book is "packed . . . with lucid observations," Richard J. Samuels wrote here in 2001.

A FEW CORRECTIONS, by Brad Leithauser. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.) In this clever novel, the obituary of a charming salesman is unraveled and revised by his son, who finds that his father's normal-sounding life was actually messy, painful and secretive. "Leithauser's story . . . has bite and humor and sadness -- like the mixed bag that is real life," Adam Begley said here last year.

STET: A Memoir, by Diana Athill. (Grove, $13.) The doyenne of English book editors looks back on her long career at Andre Deutsch, the distinguished publishing house whose authors included V. S. Naipaul, Mordecai Richler and Jean Rhys, and laments the changing economic forces that have plagued small independent publishers like hers. "Athill never moralizes, but she observes everything and everyone (including herself) with almost painful honesty," Evelyn Toynton wrote in these pages in 2001. Her account is "wryly humorous" and "notable for its extraordinary lucidity."

CAUSE CELEB, by Helen Fielding. (Penguin, $13.) In her first novel, published in 1994 (well before "Bridget Jones's Diary") but only released in the United States in 2001, Fielding orchestrates a tragicomic clash between do-gooders doing good in Africa -- mainly a plucky Bridget-like Londoner -- and pop stars with a highly fickle commitment to social justice. Our reviewer, Maggie Galehouse, called this "a serious story that doesn't take itself too seriously" and "a wonderful surprise."

NOTES FROM THE HYENA'S BELLY: An Ethiopian Boyhood, by Nega Mezlekia. (Picador USA, $14.) The author, an Ethiopian who fled to Canada in 1983, describes the famine, violence and feudal cruelties that defined his childhood, and his decision as a teenager to join a guerrilla army during a convulsive moment in his nation's history. "Mezlekia has summoned, with imaginative directness and impressive tonal range, a world of uncertainty in which politics is never just background but permeates ordinary life," Rob Nixon wrote here in 2001.

KILLING DRAGONS: The Conquest of the Alps, by Fergus Fleming. (Grove, $14.) This history of the exploration of the Alps employs a droll, detached tone of amusement as it recounts the follies, eccentricities and triumphs of mountaineers through the ages. "Combing books, articles, letters and journals going back to the 16th century," the author continually "holds up mirrors to our own times -- our obsession with adventure, altitude and risk," Elizabeth Hightower wrote here last year.

THE VIRTUOSO, by Margriet de Moor. (Overlook, $13.95.) Set in 18th-century Naples, this Dutch work of fiction revolves around a love affair between a castrato whose singing leaves his listeners in tears and a young noblewoman eager for instruction in both sex and music. In 2000 our reviewer, Julie Gray, called this a "resplendent novel" that is filled with "just the right amount of political and historical detail."

TROUBLING CONFESSIONS: Speaking Guilt in Law and Literature, by Peter Brooks. (University of Chicago, $15.) In this study of confession and its uses, the author traces the development of the concept of the self through the ages and the role that the act of confession has played in its formation. The result is "a book of questing and questioning," a work of "graceful erudition" that is "rich in fresh ideas," Richard Lourie wrote here in 2000. Scott Veale
