HEADLINE: Looking Beyond Books, Libraries Renovate 

BYLINE:  By ANNIE BLACHLEY 

 BODY:
IN a few weeks, flowers will be in bloom on the sun-washed veranda. People will gather, some to read, others to talk quietly, the rest to gaze out at Manhasset Bay in the distance. The cappuccino lounge and the art galleries will be open, as they are all year. And a staff of nearly 100 will be on hand, as usual.
 Despite the ambience, this is no exclusive country club. It is the expanded Port Washington Public Library, a beacon of community pride since its July 2001 opening. 
 "People have joyfully embraced the facility," said the library director, Nancy Curtin. "They're even asking why we can't stay open till 11 p.m."
Before the remodeling, the 30-year-old structure barely had room for its collection of more than 150,000 volumes. It lacked display areas for its extensive media holdings, there was no space dedicated to teenagers and the crucial places for quiet study were being filled with books or technological sprawl.
Other examples of overstuffed and underdeveloped libraries could be found across the Island. Now, many communities have taken steps to bring their libraries up to date, evolving into inviting, comfortable community centers with meeting rooms for uses as diverse as singles groups, walking clubs, hypertension screening programs and driver education. They provide private and group study spaces, auditoriums, art and photography galleries, computers, laptop plug-ins, CD-ROM's, DVD's and videos.
"There's been a marvelous renaissance in the last decade, a rediscovery by the community of how valuable the library is," said Gerald Nichols, director of the Suffolk Cooperative Library System. He said that of Suffolk County's 55 libraries, 32 have completed major renovations or expansions, 8 more "have a hole in the ground" and another 13 have been given the O.K. to rebuild or are seeking approval. If all the plans go through, 96 percent of the public libraries in the county will have been rebuilt.
In Nassau, half of the 54 public libraries have completed or are planning expansion, said Jackie Thresher, director of the Nassau Library System. "Most of the buildings in Nassau were built in the 1950's or 60's and are nearing the end of their useful life," she said, mentioning safety code problems and failures to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Such concerns are history at refurbished places like the Port Washington library, where customers luxuriate in the additional space and access to a variety of media.
"It's more efficient," Ambrose Walsh said of the Port Washington library's media center, where he was searching for videos of films nominated for Screen Actors Guild awards. In the computer center, Phil Lobato was surfing the Internet on a state-of-the-art Dell. "I come here all the time," said Mr. Lobato, who doesn't have a computer at home.
In the young adult room, 14-year-old Cailin Buondelmonte declared, "There's more places for us," while her friend, Jessi Miano, complained that "they won't let us use the study rooms." In consideration of what Ms. Curtin described as the "businessmen who come here and say, 'I just need to get away from my kids,' " library study room policy states that anyone younger than a high school graduate must be accompanied by an adult.
Ms. Curtin said the Port Washington library was also dedicated to reaching out to younger children. "Open the library to children who are one year old," she said. "It used to be 3."
The large, airy children's space next to a garden has a cozy carpeted area with books, toys and computers nearby. The library also reaches out through its Parent-Child Home Program, which sends facilitators to the homes of families considered at risk for educational failure.
The library's expansion, from 36,000 square feet to 48,000, also gave tutors representing 30 countries rooms to teach English to the area's increasing immigrant population. A pilot program places E.S.L. instructors in restaurants, teaching employees where they work.
The Port Washington library's expansion, funded by a $6 million bond issue, also provides cultural programs for a broad economic spectrum -- "from poverty level to some of the richest people in the world," said Corinne Camarata, the assistant library director. The schedule includes art, music and health programs, a series for children and a nautical archive with decoys and ship models. Oral history projects celebrate Port Washington's African-American population, sand mining, fisheries, aviation, and workers at Sands Point and other Gold Coast mansions.
Yet the ultimate measure of success lies in what these places bring to people. When the largely African-American community of Lakeview wanted a new library, it had just $1.8 million to renovate a former school. Acting as its own general contractor, the community of 5,500 people took 14 years to complete the project.
"People told us it couldn't be done," said the Lakeview library director, Blair Cummins. But the original 2,000 square feet of library space was expanded to 17,000, and the library will double as a landlord by renting another 12,000 feet of space on upper floors to tenants.
When the Lakeview Public Library held its grand reopening last Saturday, some 600 visitors came to see the expanded black experience collection, the community's first public computers connected to the Internet, and new meeting rooms. Mr. Cummins said the reaction was "overwhelmingly positive" for an area that is "seeking its own identity. This is a major milestone."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Morristown, N.J.; 
Carefully Vetted Addition for Century-Old Building

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J. 

 BODY:
RENOVATING a nearly-century-old, four-story office building and adding a fifth floor that is permitted by zoning rules would be relatively routine in most communities.
 But in this community, which cares deeply about its rich colonial heritage, even an apparently simple project permitted under zoning rules may not be routine. Such was the case of a recently completed plan to add a floor to 10 Park Place, which faces the town's central green. 
 Though a quiet park today -- described by town officials as the oldest park in the state -- the square is central to Morristown's history as the location of the earliest churches, taverns and courts. (Public hangings took place there until 1833 when a new courthouse was built several blocks away.) 
George Washington and his Army spent two winters here during the Revolutionary War, from January to May 1777 and December 1799 to June 1780 and reminders of his residence abound. Benedict Arnold was tried in absentia here after trying to tip off British commanders to American troop movements. Indeed, the symbol of the town is a reverse silhouette of a man in a Colonial-era triangular hat.
But while Morristown looks to its past, the world around it has been changing. The rolling hills of the northern part of the surrounding Morris County, which were the site of dairy farms into the 1960's and 70's, have been carpeted with town house developments and low-rise office parks. Pharmaceutical companies, many of which have made New Jersey their international headquarters, occupy office parks in the southern parts of the county.
The town itself, a community of 17,500 residents about 25 miles to the west of Manhattan, has felt the impact. The population swells to 60,000 to 80,000 on weekdays as workers flock to the area to work in 3 million square feet of office space in the town and nearby townships.
Since 10 Park Place is roughly on the site of the area's first Baptist church, which opened in 1771, some objections were raised to the placement of a modern steel and glass fifth floor to the existing stone and terra cotta structure.
The answer was, essentially, to hide it in plain sight, said George J. Kimmerle, the president of Kimmerle Architects, which designed the addition as well as the renovations to the existing building. The front wall of the fifth floor was pushed back from the parapet of the existing building, and its rounded mansard shape minimizes the disruption of the skyline.
"The building is in a historic district, and we all had to be sensitive to historic issues," said John J. DeLaney, Jr., Morristown's mayor. "But this is a regional commercial center as well. We had to balance the need for preservation with the need for development and growth."
Mr. Kimmerle said he and his associates spent a lot of time studying sightlines from the green to the top of the building, in seasons when the trees are in full leaf and when they are largely bare. The fifth floor is 8 feet high where it faces the green, before rising to its full height of 14 to 15 feet. "We did not want to compete with the classic facade," Mr. Kimmerle said.
A person walking or sitting on the green can see the addition, particularly if they are on the eastern side of the park, which is farthest away. But they would have to be specifically looking for it: it does not jump out.
"There is no question that the green is the jewel of Morristown," said Mr. DeLaney, a lawyer who is a part-time mayor. "This project is enhancing that jewel in a better way."
The tension between preservation and the desire for economic development is strong in Morristown between preservationists and those more concerned with economic growth. When a proposal was made to lower the height limit for new buildings in parts of the business district from five to three stories, officials of the historic preservation society applauded, saying new development often threatens old buildings because there is little open land.
But the director of the town's special improvement district complained that height limits could curb development and increase tax burdens on existing taxpayers. Like business improvement districts in New York City, the town's special improvement district levies charges to provide additional services to businesses in the area.
Although some elements of the town's history, like the buildings where Alfred Vail helped to perfect the telegraph and Morse Code, are likely to be preserved, Morristown has changed rapidly in recent years. It is moved away from not only the distant colonial era, but also the gilded age, when wealthy New Yorkers build magnificent dwellings to serve as summer residences.
Many have disappeared, but some have been converted to other uses. The 100-room mansion built for Florence and Hamilton Twombly became the home of Fairleigh Dickinson University. An indication of the family's land holding is reflected in a nearby municipality, whose name, Florham Park, derives from the first names of the Twomblys.
Over the past two decades, the town has absorbed an influx of recent immigrants, many of them from Central and South America. According to Mayor DeLaney, the Hispanic population of the town has increased from about 5 percent in 1980 to about 25 to 27 percent currently. Recent immigrants have provided labor for restaurants, cleaners and landscaping services, but some long-term residents have been disturbed by large groups of immigrant men who crowd sidewalks while seeking day work.
Morristown's downtown area suffered a blow in 1993 when the Macy's store, on the green adjacent to 10 Park Place, closed its doors. The long-empty store has had a depressing effect on other smaller retailers, just as closed department stores have had in Newark and Montclair.
THE old Macy's building is scheduled to reopen in April as the first New Jersey location of Century 21, a chain of stores noted for selling designer clothes at deep discounts. With the area expected to improve, the landlord of both buildings, a family partnership, decided to proceed with the renovation of 10 Park Place.
Mr. Kimmerle described the existing building as a 50,000-square-foot rabbit warren of corridors and tiny offices, with a dimly lighted, dingy lobby. "We originally were going to put carpeting in the lobby, since there didn't seem to be anything else to do," he said. But when thoroughly scoured, the floors were found to be of attractive stone, separated by brass dividers.
New lighting was installed in the lobby, much of it indirect, and wooden panels mounted on the walls for warmth. New elevators were also installed that run to the new fifth floor and, for the first time, to the basement as well. The second floor of the building is intended to connect to a recently built parking deck, which will help solve a persistent problem in a town that was laid out before the advent of the car. 
Mr. Kimmerle said a lot of care had been given to preserving and repairing the plaster detail work inside and the gothic terra cotta on the front facade.
He said the smaller spaces had been combined to produce offices that would be attractive to design and communications firms attracted to an urban, but small-scale location. "People working here can walk to transportation, to restaurants and shopping," Mr. Kimmerle said. "You can't do that from a building on Route 46," he said referring to a major commercial highway in the region.
The new layout has been attractive to tenants willing to pay higher rents than before. Before the remodeling, he said annual rents were in the low teens a square foot. The new tenants are paying in the low to mid-$20's, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: George J. Kimmerle, president of Kimmerle Architects, designed the fifth-floor addition to 10 Park Place. (Don Standing for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Who Will Feel the Pain In This Budget Squeeze 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
BY the time the dismissal bells ring in the public schools throughout New Jersey on Tuesday, educators will have a much clearer idea how much the more than one million students in the state will suffer because of a yawning budget deficit.
 The 600 school districts in New Jersey have already been told that they would probably receive the same amount of direct aid from the state for the 2002-3 school year as they did in the current year -- $5.8 billion, of which almost half will go to the poorest districts. 
 However, while working with the same slice of the pie, schools will be forced to make some hard choices since many districts are facing increasing enrollments, a skyrocketing number of special education students and increases of 10 percent to 25 percent in the cost of insurance and transportation.
"We have said no to everything that's not essential for enrollment," said Dr. Michael Osnato, the superintendent of schools in Montclair, noting that that included replacing instructional material, lowering class sizes and hiring additional guidance counselors. 
What Dr. Osnato is bracing for is hardly unique. The South Orange-Maplewood district, also in the northern part of the state, for instance, is planning to cut nine positions next year, to buy fewer supplies and to delay some building repairs. The Cherry Hill School District, in South Jersey, plans to remove six teaching positions from the two high schools, and jobs for two assistant principals will be eliminated. In addition, the purchase of new library books and textbooks will be delayed and six bus routes canceled.
From one end of the state to the other, school boards and parent-teacher organizations have over the past two weeks been meeting to sound the alarm that the 550 districts that vote on their budgets on April 16 will probably be asking for hefty property tax increases.
In New Jersey, the state pays an average of 40 percent of the school budget, with the other 60 percent coming from property tax revenue. But many districts do not receive that 40 percent. About half of the state aid goes to the 30 poorer districts, known as the Abbott districts, like Newark and Camden. The rest is divided up, with affluent districts like Princeton, Haddonfield and Hopewell Valley Regional Schools receiving less than 10 percent of their budget money from the state.
"I do expect to see layoffs around the state and delays in planned improvements," said James Murphy, executive director of the New Jersey Association of School Administrators who is a former superintendent himself. "We have a very difficult situation this year. It's a crisis. The last time we had a freeze on spending was in 1991."
It was in 1991 -- when Mr. Murphy was superintendent in Bayonne -- that he had to let 75 employees go in a district of 9,000 students. Class sizes went up, textbook orders were canceled and maintenance projects were postponed.
"If you have a growing number of kids, it's a problem," he said. "You will not get additional funding for more students."
Since 1991, the state's public school population -- currently about 1.3 million -- has risen by 130,000 students, yet during the same period the number of administrative positions has been reduced to 6,500 from 7,500, Mr. Murphy said.
Moreover, the new curriculum standards adopted by the state five years ago have put pressure on districts to hire foreign language teachers at the elementary school level and to do what is necessary to improve writing and math skills, yet in many districts there is little in the way of state aid to pay for these programs.
Despite the fact that a the belt-tightening has been looming for some time, the school districts will have much less time than in past years to draw up their plans, because the governor's budget figures for the schools were not released until late February rather than in January. With the state facing a budget deficit of almost $3 billion, the districts were told not to expect any more state aid than last year. It is for that reason that school boards are holding special budget meetings and parents are rallying to explain what is at stake in the April 16 elections.
"Its a big rush to get the word out," said Elaine Stagg, the mother of three children and president of the East Brunswick PTA President's Council, which is made up of PTA. officers from the district's 11 schools. "We'll do our best to make sure people know about it and what's actually in the budget and what we could lose without supporting the budget. It's no-frills in this budget, it's just the necessities. No extras or new programs, it's just maintenance."
In New Jersey, if a school board's proposed budget requires a larger property tax increase than the 3 percent cap that state law allows, a second ballot question must be put before the voters that specifies for what the additional funds will be used.
In 1991, just under 56 percent of the ballot questions passed, according to Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association. Those numbers are in sharp contrast with boom years like 1985, when 87 percent of the questions were approved, or in 2000, when 88 percent passed. Last spring, 81 percent of the 552 budgets voted on at the polls were approved, while 70 districts had second ballot questions.
Over the years, New Jersey has struggled with the issue of school financing. The 1996 Comprehensive Educational Improvement and Financing Act drew up a formula for financing the schools that -- depending on a school district's economic status -- was more in line with the state Supreme Court's Abbott decision, an attempt to achieve parity in poorer districts. New Jersey is one of only seven states in which residents vote on the school budget, and can therefore take their anger out on their neighborhood schools during bad economic times.
"The big problem in New Jersey is that on average the state pays 40 percent of the cost of education, and property taxes pay 60 percent," Mr. Yaple said, adding that in other states, the split is usually 50-50. Under this arrangement, it is the more affluent communities that bear the brunt of the property tax burden.
For example, Princeton Regional Schools receive only 8 percent of their school budget in state aid, Haddonfield receives 7 percent and Montclair 11 percent. On the other hand, a district like Willingboro -- though not among the state's 30 poorest districts but more blue-collar and middle-class -- receives 62 percent of its financing through state aid. The 30 Abbott districts themselves receive almost all their money from the state, and the state Department of Education is prohibited by court order from freezing those funds.
"No one is disagreeing that those districts didn't need the aid," Mr. Yaple said. "But other districts are also struggling."
One of the biggest problems facing most districts is the fact that in any given school budget, there is very little flexibility, with 85 percent to 90 percent of the money usually going toward salaries, utility costs, insurance and federally mandated special education. That leaves school supplies, instructional aides, maintenance, textbooks, computers, advanced placement classes and extracurricular activities on the chopping block.
"It's going to be an extremely tough year," Mr. Yaple said. "Enrollments are going up. Districts still have to pay contractual raises, and other expenses are going up -- from utility bills to health insurance. It's very likely that many districts will have to ask a second ballot question, and they go down when the economy is bad and up when it's good. It makes it difficult when the economy turns sour and the voters are frustrated. This is the only place to take out their frustration."
For example, school budgets were approved from 1996 to 2000 in East Brunswick. Yet last year, when the economy was softer, both budget questions failed and had to go to the Township Council, where the budget was upheld, said Jennifer Forbes, a spokeswoman for the district.
"I think everybody is concerned about this year," Ms. Forbes said.
In the 2001-2 school year, East Brunswick received 19 percent of its $91.4 million school budget in state aid, and taxpayers were assessed at a rate of $3.55 cents per $100 assessed property value. This year, the total proposed budget is $97.7 million for the 11 schools, and taxpayers will be asked to pay $3.81 per $100 assessed value of their homes.
Much of the additional money will go toward transportation costs, which are expected to rise to $7.3 million next year from $6.1 million in the current year. At the same time, health care benefits for full-time employees will eat up $12.4 million next year, as against $10.8 million in the current school year.
In addition, residents of East Brunswick will have a second ballot question seeking approval of $1.9 million in spending for such positions as chairs of the foreign language and the art education departments, part-time school aides, financing for the early-morning drop-off program and as well as part-time instructional aides, calculators and textbooks.
"We have to raise taxes or cut services," said Dr. Jamie Savedoff, the superintendent of schools in East Brunswick. "There is no other place to go."
In East Brunswick, a number of new teaching positions has helped to bring down class sizes in high school to an average of 25 students, but with 300 more high school students expected in the next four years, the student-to-teacher ratio could go up.
"I think it's going to be tough for a while," said Dr. Savedoff, noting that while the community wants a quality education for its children, some people lost money in the stock market and others simply lost their jobs.
Consequently, he predicted that the percentage of ballot questions that would pass would be "significantly less this year."
"It's not because people are anti-kids or anti-education," Dr. Savedoff said. "There's just no money left."
Like many other administrators, Dr. Peter P. Horoschak, the superintendent of schools in Maplewood-South Orange, said he hoped that the freeze on state financing would be a one-year proposition. For now, the district is looking at a budget of about $73 million next year, with only about $5 million coming from the state. 
"We're trying to keep the cuts away from the classroom," Dr. Horoschak said. "Unless something positive happens, we're going to be facing the same problems in the future and perhaps having to cut back programs. We're buying a year. We're trying to hold our staffing levels in place and serve a greater number of students with less staff."
To help avoid layoffs or doing without supplies, Maplewood plans to ask its board of school estimate to approve a 7.9 percent tax increase, meaning that the average homeowner in Maplewood would face an estimated tax increase of $272. In South Orange, taxpayers would have to shoulder an annual increase of $357. The Maplewood-South Orange district is one of about 50 in the state in which a board of school estimate rather than the voters approves the tax rate.
In addition, the Maplewood-South Organge district is expecting a 2 percent increase in enrollment and more than $13 million in special education costs.
Although administrators are hoping to get more help from the state in the 2003-4 school year, there are no signs indicating that more money will be available for school districts in the near future.
"It's impossible to project that far in advance," said Rich Vespucci, a spokesman for the state Department of Education. "Some people feel this is going to be a short-lived recession."
The problem is, many administrators say they are already operating on a tight rein financially. For instance, in East Brunswick, there were 7,225 students and 42 administrative and supervisory positions in the district in 1983. But by this year, with almost 1,500 additional students, the administrative staff had been reduced to 19.
"I hear this same stories from my colleagues left and right," said Dr. Savedoff, who is also president of the Garden State Coalition of Schools. "We run very efficiently."
For many districts like East Brunswick, special education -- which is mandated by federal law -- has eaten up a large percentage of the budgets.
"You are diverting resources from other areas to pay for special education," said Dr. Savedoff, noting that about 14 percent of his district's 8,700 students were classified with some type of learning disability.
In the Hopewell Valley Regional School District, the school board plans to ask voters to approve a budget of $49 million for 2002-3, an increase of more than $3 million from the current school year.
As a result, plans to initiate an alternative high school program for disenfranchised students, adding programs for preparation for the College Boards and improving technology throughout the district will have to be delayed even if voters approve the increased spending, said Dr. Robert Sopko, the superintendent in Hopewell.
The special education budget will also grow, with 29 percent of the proposed increase going toward those programs. There will be about $8 million to serve more than 570 classified students, including 37 children with some form of autism. Of that group, 16 students are attending out-of-district schools with tuitions ranging from $17,031 to $159,000. What's more, because 31 of the students are between the ages of 3 and 11, the outlays can be expected to continue for years to come.
While Dr. Sopko said he was optimistic that the budget would pass, he said he was disturbed nonetheless because of the way in which New Jersey's system fostered a division between the parents of special education students and more mainstream pupils as well as between working families and people on fixed incomes.
"The sad part is it pits the elderly against the young family," he said. "It's the only budget people have the right to express themselves on. My budget is not infinite and open-ended. There are a lot of competing values. I would try to cut anything else before the educational opportunities for the kids."
Then there is Cherry Hill, where voters will be asked to approve a 6.3 percent tax increase to finance a proposed $124 million budget, about $10 million higher than the current one. Cherry Hill, an affluent district, receives about 12 percent of its money from the state, and as in many other districts, enrollment is growing fast.
When Dr. Morton Sherman came to the district as superintendent five years ago, there were 10,200 students. Today, there are 11,400, of whom almost 11 percent, or 1,143, are classified as special education students. Two years ago, there were only 975 such students. The district budgeted $7.2 million for special education this year and is seeking $8.6 million for the 2002-3 school year. In addition, insurance costs for health benefits and liability will climb to $18 million from the current $15 million, Dr. Sherman said.
While the district is cutting back on some teaching and administrative positions, eliminating some bus routes and reducing textbook orders, administrators are still looking for creative ways to finance other programs. For example, a popular film course will raise money by having the teacher and the school play host to one or two evenings -- at a cost of $5 to $10 per person -- in which a filme will be shown, followed by a discussion.
Still, Dr. Sherman said, real changes in how education is financed will have to come at the state level.
"The way the taxing system is set up, it actually divides communities," he said. "Schools should be a binding force in the community. One hundred percent reliance on property tax is so off-base. The state has to review this."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 280 More Rooms for the Marriott; 
Hotel to Grow In Brooklyn

 BODY:
The New York Marriott Brooklyn hotel, which has been highly successful since it opened in 1998, will add 280 guest rooms, retail space and meeting rooms as a result of an agreement with the city's Economic Development Corporation.
 The $53 million expansion is to be based on the purchase of an 8,000-square-foot parcel of city-owned land at 345 Adams Street in downtown Brooklyn adjacent to the hotel, which now has 376 rooms. 
The 23-story addition is to contain 180,000 square feet of space and will be joined to the older structure by a short enclosed bridge over an existing promenade connecting Adams Street to Jay Street. The hotel is part of Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza, a development that also includes 800,000 square feet of office space. 
 It took the hotel's developer, Joshua L. Muss of the Muss Development Company, 13 years from the initial announcement to the start of construction, and the hotel has been nearly full from almost the day it opened. According to the city's Economic Development Corporation, the occupancy rate in 1999 was 87.6 percent; it was 91 percent in 2000 and 86.4 percent in 2001. Andrew W. Alper, the agency's president, said that the existing hotel had brought more than 2,000 jobs to downtown Brooklyn and that the addition would generate 100 more jobs. Mr. Muss said he expected construction of the addition to begin in spring 2003.
